**The Inner Canon of *Yin-Fu* – Seven Chapters (Continued)**

**Yin-Fu** is the private intention within, the response of things without.
Like matching seals and contracts, hence it is called *Yin-Fu*.
From its root to its unfolding, hence it is called the **Root Canon**.
It embodies the **Five Dragons**—the Dragons of the Five Phases.
The Dragon transforms without end, the **qi** is unfathomable in yin and yang—
thus the **Way** of nurturing the **spirit** follows the Five Dragons.

Within nurturing the **spirit** are the Five **qi**:
the **spirit** is their sovereign,
the **heart** their dwelling,
**virtue** their envoy.
The **Way** is where nurturing the **spirit** ultimately returns.

The Five **qi** are the **qi** of the Five Zang:
the **spirit**, the **hun**, the **po**, the **jing**, and the **zhi**.
The **spirit** dwells among the four others, hence it is their sovereign.
The **heart** can harmonize and contain, hence it is their dwelling.
**Virtue** can subdue evil #1, hence it is their envoy #2.
Yet matters of nurturing should return to the **Way**.

The **Way** is the origin of heaven and earth,
the single thread of all things.
It is the source of all things, what heaven generates,
encompassing boundless formless **qi**,
existing before heaven and earth,
its form unseen, its name unknown—
thus it is called **spirit-soul**.
Without name, it is the origin of heaven and earth.
Hence it is said: The **Way** is the origin of heaven and earth.
The **Way**’s initial generation is One,
hence it is called the **single thread**.
Speaking of the **Way**’s mixed creation,
how yin and yang mold and refine—
all things are born and transformed through it,
heaven and earth generated by it,
boundless and vast, its form unseen.
As for the **qi** of nurturing and growth,
it precedes heaven and earth in formation,
cannot be described by form or defined by name,
yet it subtly permeates all things—
thus it is called **spirit-soul**.
Therefore, the **Way** is the source of **spirit-brightness**,
the single principle of transformation.
Thus **virtue** nurtures the Five **qi**.

The **heart** can attain the One,
and thus its **wei** #4 arises.
**Spirit-brightness** discerns the **Way** and is born—
hence it is said: The **Way** is the source of **spirit-brightness**.
If the principle of transformation is not singular,
there are times when transformation does not occur—
hence it is said: the **single principle of transformation**.
Following principle to completion is called **virtue**.
Each of the Five **qi** follows principle,
and thus success can be achieved—
hence it is said: **virtue** nurtures the Five **qi**.

The One is that which acts without action and is naturally so.
The **heart** can act without action,
and its unfolding arises spontaneously—
hence it is said: The **heart** attains the One,
and thus its unfolding arises.

**Wei** is the **Way** of the **heart’s qi**,
the path by which it dwells—
the **spirit** is its envoy.
When the **heart’s qi** aligns with the natural **Way**,
unfolding arises.
The unfolding’s **Way** comes from alignment #4—
thus the **spirit** is its envoy.

The nine orifices and twelve dwellings are the gates and thresholds of **qi**,
the **heart’s** total governance.
Received from heaven at birth, it is called the **True Person**.
The **True Person** is one with heaven.
The twelve alignments are:
the eyes seeing color,
the ears hearing sound,
the nose receiving fragrance,
the tongue tasting flavor,
the body sensing touch,
the mind contemplating affairs—
the roots and fields mutually interpenetrating and aligning,
hence called the twelve alignments.
**Qi** enters and exits through them,
hence they are the gates and thresholds of **qi**.
Only the **heart** governs them,
hence they are the **heart’s** total governance.
All these are received from heaven,
unspoiled in their original nature—
hence it is called the **True Person**.
The **True Person**’s body is identical to heaven,
hence it is said: one with heaven.

Yet those who know this internally refine and cultivate,
and are called **Sages**.
The **Sage** knows by analogy.
Internal refinement is learning through study—
though the **Sage** is wise, still relying on learning.
Learning is not natural—
hence it is said: knowing by analogy.

Thus, when people are born,
they all emerge from the transformation of things.
Speaking of people born together in heaven and earth,
they share the One.
After emerging, they follow things and transform—
thus they differ.

Knowing by analogy at home,
there are doubts and confusions.
The orifices #5 pertain to the nine openings,
yet their doubts also connect with unfolding.
If the **heart** lacks unfolding,
the **wei** is blocked.
When it is unblocked,
the Five **qi** are nurtured—
the task is to dwell the **spirit**,
this is called transformation.

When the **heart’s** unfolding is unblocked,
the Five **qi** are naturally nurtured.
Yet nurturing the Five **qi** requires
the **spirit** to return and dwell.
When the **spirit** returns and aligns,
transformation follows principle naturally.

The Five **qi** of transformation are:
**zhi**, **sī** #6, **spirit**, and **virtue**.
The **spirit** is their sovereign—
calm and harmonious, it nurtures **qi**.
When **qi** is nurtured in harmony,
the four do not decay.
Their fourfold influence and power
achieves all things.
Preserving and dwelling them is called **spirit-transformation**.
Returning to the body, it is called the **True Person**.

Speaking of those who can transform:
it lies in perfecting the Five **qi**.
The **spirit** is their sovereign—
speaking of unifying **zhi** and **sī** to rule them.
The **spirit** being sovereign,
it can be calm and harmonious, nurturing **qi**.
When **qi** is nurtured,
**virtue** is also harmonized.
The four are **zhi**, **sī**, **spirit**, and **virtue**.
If the four do not decay,
their fourfold influence and power
achieves all things.
Constantly preserving and aligning them,
the **Way** of the **spirit** transforms and returns to the body.
When **spirit-transformation** returns to the body,
it is called the **True Person**.

The **True Person** aligns with heaven and harmonizes with the **Way**,
holds the One to nurture all things,
embracing the **heart** of heaven,
applying **virtue** and nurturing—
without action, encompassing all,
using **zhi**, **sī**, thought, and intention
to wield influence and power.

The **scholar** is one whose **spirit** is fully awakened,
thus able to nurture **zhi**.
The One is without action.
Speaking of the **True Person** nurturing all things,
embracing the **heart** of heaven,
applying **virtue** and nurturing—
all done without action.
Hence it is said: holding the One to nurture all things.
As for **zhi**, thought, and intention,
moving influence and power—
all are natural and follow principle.
Hence it is said: without action, encompassing all.

Yet who can fully grasp this **Way**?
Only the virtuous **scholar** can.
Having awakened the **spirit**,
only then can **zhi** be nurtured.

Nurturing the **zhi** follows the **Linggui** [灵龟].

**Zhi** discerns right and wrong,
while the **Linggui** foretells auspicious and inauspicious omens.
Hence it is said: nurturing **zhi** follows the **Linggui**.

Nurturing **zhi** means harmonizing and unifying,
so that the **heart-qi**’s thoughts are unrestricted.
It is said: the **heart-qi** is unrestricted.
Thus, one must nurture **zhi** to seek unification.

When there is desire, **zhi** is stored and pondered.
**Zhi** is the guide of desire.
If desires multiply, **zhi** scatters;
when **zhi** scatters, it becomes weak;
when **zhi** weakens, thoughts are not realized.
This shows that those who indulge desires cannot nurture **qi** and **zhi**,
and thus their thoughts are not realized.

When the **heart-qi** is unified, desires do not overwhelm;
when desires do not overwhelm, **zhi** and intention do not weaken;
when **zhi** and intention do not weaken, thoughts reach their essence.
This shows that those with few desires can nurture their **zhi**,
and thus their thoughts reach their essence.

When essence is realized, harmony and unification arise,
and turbulent **qi** does not vex the chest.
Harmony and unification mean all things are attuned and unrestricted,
so turbulent **qi** naturally dissipates.

Thus, internally one nurtures **qi**,
externally one knows others.
Nurturing **zhi** makes the **heart** unified,
knowing others clarifies their roles.
A unified **heart** brings tranquility to the self,
clear roles bring peace to the world.

To employ others, one must first know their nurtured **qi** and **zhi**,
discern their strengths and weaknesses to nurture their **qi** and **zhi**,
and observe their comfort to know their capabilities.
To employ others is called the **Wei** [卫] of nurturing **zhi**.

Nurturing **zhi** strengthens **qi**,
neglecting it weakens **qi**.
When strength and weakness manifest,
their comfort and capabilities become known.

Thus, those skilled in nurturing **zhi** are those with few desires.
If **zhi** is not nurtured, the **heart-qi** is not steadfast;
if the **heart-qi** is not steadfast, thoughts are not realized;
if thoughts are not realized, **zhi** and intention are not firm;
if **zhi** and intention are not firm, responses lack vigor;
if responses lack vigor, **zhi** is lost and **heart-qi** becomes hollow;
if **zhi** is lost and **heart-qi** is hollow, the **spirit** is forfeited.
This shows that losing the **spirit** begins with failing to nurture **zhi**.

When the **spirit** is lost, the hair and beard wither,
and the convergence of **zhi**, **heart**, and **spirit** is disjointed.
Withered hair and beard signify a lack of clarity.
Convergence refers to the interplay of **zhi**, **heart**, and **spirit**.
If the **spirit** lacks clarity, errors multiply,
and thus the three cannot align in unity.

The beginning of nurturing **zhi** lies in self-cultivation.
When self is cultivated, **zhi** and intention become firm.
When **zhi** and intention are firm, **virtue** and power are undivided.
**Spirit** and clarity must be steadfastly guarded to divide them.
Cultivation means few desires and a tranquil **heart**.

When **virtue** and power are not divided,
**spirit** and clarity are ever-present and steadfast.
Thus, **virtue** is refined and power moves all things.
**Virtue** refined means dispersion is lost,
power moving means one’s **virtue** can influence others.
Hence it is said: only then can they be divided.

Firm intention follows the **Tengshe** [腾蛇].
Intention has twists and turns,
while the **Tengshe** bends and stretches,
hence firm intention follows the **Tengshe**.

Firm intention is the **qi**’s contemplation.
When intention is firm, **qi** is balanced;
when **qi** is balanced, contemplation is precise.
Thus it is said: firm intention is the **qi**’s contemplation.

The **heart** desires tranquility,
contemplation desires depth.
A tranquil **heart** honors **spirit** and clarity,
deep contemplation perfects strategies.
When **spirit** and clarity are honored, **zhi** cannot be disordered;
when strategies are perfected, achievements cannot be obstructed.
**Zhi** cannot be disordered, so strategies are fulfilled.
Achievements cannot be obstructed, so the realm is secured.

When intention and contemplation are settled,
the **heart** naturally becomes tranquil,
and all actions are without error.
The **spirit**, when obtained, becomes concentrated.
When the **heart** is tranquil,
things act without effort and follow their nature,
requiring no thought yet perceiving the profound.
Thus, even if the **heart**’s actions are without error,
the **spirit** naturally attains it.
When attained, nothing remains unaccomplished.
Concentration means fulfillment.

If **qi** is lodged externally,
the deceitful gain leverage,
and false schemes cause confusion,
so words no longer emanate from the **heart**.
Lodged means guest lodging—**qi** is not genuine, only borrowed.
Thus, the deceitful gain leverage,
and false schemes cause confusion.
So words become mere chest utterances, no longer from the **heart**.

Thus, one must uphold **heart**-methods,
guard the **True One** without transformation,
and await the convergence of others’ intentions and contemplations,
listening and observing them.

It is said: the **heart** guards sincerity and clarity without loss,
the **True One** is steadfast and unchanging.
Only then, when interfacing with others,
do sincere and earnest individuals fully express their intentions,
the wise offer their strategies,
and the enlightened present their plans,
so that all align in harmony.

Using the **heavenly ear** to listen,
one can discern the omens of things.
Strategies are the pivot of life and death;
if contemplation does not converge,
listening will not be precise.
If observation fails, strategies are lost,
and intention finds nothing to rely on—
only emptiness remains, devoid of substance.
Strategies succeed, life is preserved;
strategies fail, death ensues.
Hence it is said: strategies are the pivot of life and death.

If contemplation does not align with things,
listening serves no purpose.
If listening is not precise,
how can observation succeed?
Contradicting observation while scheming—
what else is this but failure?
If strategies fail, on what can intention depend?
Only hollow pretense remains, no longer sincere.

Thus, the contemplation of strategies
must begin with firm intention.
Firm intention originates from the **heart**’s **Wei** [卫].
Without action yet seeking,
cultivating tranquility for the five **zang** [脏],
harmonizing the six **fu** [腑],
so that **spirit**, **shen**, **hun**, and **po** guard their domains unmoving,
one can then internally gaze and reflectively listen,
settling **zhi** in the boundless void,
awaiting the **spirit**’s comings and goings.

It is said: to seek the way of tranquil **heart**,
one must be serene and without action.
Thus, the five **zang** are tranquil,
the six **fu** are harmonized,
**spirit**, **shen**, **hun**, and **po** each guard their roles,
calm and unmoving,
so one can internally perceive the formless
and reflectively hear the soundless.
When **zhi** and contemplation are settled,
the **Great Void** arrives,
and myriad **spirits** and clarities converge upon oneself.

Through observing the unfolding of Heaven and Earth,
one knows the myriad things’ creation and transformation,
sees the completion and origin of **Yin** and **Yang**,
and grasps the principles of human affairs.
Without stepping outside, one knows the world;
without peering through windows, one sees the **Dao** of Heaven.
One issues decrees unseen,
and attains without movement.

Only the **spirit** does this—
serene and unmoving,
yet responsive and thus in harmony with the world’s essence.
To know what is unknown,
to see what is unseen,
does one truly need to step outside or peer through windows and doors?
No, for decrees are issued unseen,
and attainment comes without movement.

This is called **Dao-knowing**,
which harmonizes with **spirit** and **ming**,
responding to the boundless while the **spirit** abides.

The **Dao** is without thought,
without action.
Yet **Dao-knowing**—
does it require knowing to know?
Because it is without knowing,
it can harmonize with **spirit** and **ming**,
respond to the boundless,
and welcome the **spirit**’s arrival.

**Abiding** is akin to **dwelling**.
The **Wei** [威] and **division** of **law** [法] subduing the bear:
**Qi** [精] and **emptiness** [虚] moving creatures is called **Wei**,
and **near** or **far** is called **division**.

When the bear strikes,
the **spirit** first **dwells** and then moves,
thus the **division** of **Wei** and **law** subdues the bear.
**Wei** is the **spirit**’s **covering**—
**covering**, like **garments** and **cloaks**.
When **spirit** and **ming** are **cloaked** in stillness,
then their roles can be **divided**.

Thus, when one cultivates **serene** stillness and **firm** resolve,
the **spirit** returns to its **dwelling**,
and the **Wei**’s **covering** flourishes.
To perfect the **spirit**’s return,
one must cultivate **serene** stillness and **firm** resolve,
so that the **spirit**’s **Wei** and **covering** are grand and resplendent.

**Dwelling** is the **abode** of resolve and intent.
When **Wei** and **covering** are flourishing,
then the **inner substance** [内实] is firm.
If the **inner substance** is firm,
then nothing can oppose it.

「If nothing opposes it,
then one can **divide** the **Wei** of others,
and move their **effort** like the **Heavenly** [天].
When **Wei** is flourishing externally,
then the **inner resolve** is firm and solid.
**Form** and **covering** complement each other—
who dares oppose it?
No thing can oppose it.
If no thing can oppose it,
then the **Wei’s division** is complete.

When **Wei’s division** moves,
then all things stand in solemn reverence,
fearing the person as if they were **Heavenly**.
To grasp the **real** and discard the **empty**,
to take the **possessed** and leave the **void**,
is like weighing **pearls** with a **standard measure**.
When **Wei** and **effort** are grand and resplendent,
and figures stand in solemn reverence,
it means I am **real and possessed** while they are **empty and void**.
Thus, one can take their **empty** with my **real**,
and leave their **void** with my **possessed**.
The **taking** [取] is like the **moving of the stalks** [动爻] in response—
just as weighing **pearls** completes the **standard measure**.
Twenty-four **candareens** [铢] make one **standard measure** [镒].
Thus, the **moved** must follow,
the **sung** must harmonize.
**Twist** one finger,
observe the rest—
when the **moving** and **changing** appear in **form**,
no one can intervene.
When **Wei’s division** and **effort** shake things like the **wind**,
then the **moved** has **followers**,
and the **sung** has **harmonizers**.
But **twist** their fingers,
and call them by name,
then the **Wei** and **things** all arrive,
gradually in order,
like **calming nature** [性安],
each allowed to find its place.

Thus, the **wind** moves them,
the **changing** transforms them—
like clay in the potter’s hands,
the **Wei** and **instruments** of **things** reveal their **forms**.
So, the world rejoices,
and it is **pushed** without **satiation**,
who could **question** it?
To **examine** the **harmonizing** and **responding**,
and **question** reveals the **question**—
when the **moving** and **changing** are clear,
then **Wei** can be **divided**.

When one **examines** the **harmonizing** and **responding**,
and **knows** the **question**,
then one can **question**—
thus, one can **clearly** move and change,
and **Wei** can be **divided**.
Before **moving** and **changing**,
one must first **nurture resolve**,
and **conceal intent** to observe the **question**.
Once able to **nurture resolve**,
and **conceal intent** to see the **question**,
then the **unfolding** of **moving** and **changing** can be achieved.

**Knowing** their **fixed resolve** is self-**nurturing**,
**yielding** to others is **nurturing** others.
Thus, **spirit** remains **internal** while **effort** is **external**,
and **form** and **effort** can be established.
This is like the **method of dispersing effort** to startle the **crow** [乌].
**Effort** is dispersed only after **things** submit—
just as the **crow** strikes prey and gains.

Thus, **dispersing effort** is the **spirit’s deployment**.
**Effort** arises from the **spirit’s** movement,
so **effort** is the **spirit’s** deployment.
When used,
it must follow the **question** to move.
Without the **question**,
**effort** cannot proceed—
thus, when used,
it must also follow the **question** to move.
When **Wei** is solemn and **internal resolve** is resplendent,
and it is **pushed** through the **question**,
then **effort** is dispersed.

**Dispersing effort** is when the **heart** is **empty** and **resolve** overflows.
If the **heart** is **empty**,
then **things** are all **encompassed**;
if **resolve** overflows,
then **matters** proceed without **obstruction**—
thus, one can disperse **effort**.
When **intent** is lost to **Wei** and **effort**,
**spirit** is not **concentrated**,
then their **words** are **external** and **deceptive** in **change**.
If **resolve** and **intent** are **weakened** and **lost**,
then **effort** is **defeated**;
if **spirit** is **damaged** and **unfocused**,
then **words** are **loose** and **deceptive** in **change**.

Thus, **observe** their **resolve** and **intent** as **measurements** [度数],
then **infer** and **explain** their **plans** and **matters**.
**Measurements** are fully **rounded** and **square**,
**leveling** the **short** and **long**.
**Know** their **resolve** and **intent** as **ascending** or **declining**,
then one can establish the **measurements**.
Once the **measurements** are set,
then one can **infer** and **explain** them.
To **map** their **matters**,
one must also **fulfill** the **logic of roundness** and **squareness**,
and **harmonize** the **uses of short** and **long**.
Without **measurements**,
**effort** cannot be dispersed.
**Dispersing effort** is waiting for the **question** to move—
when **effort** moves,
it is **divided**.
If **effort** cannot **observe** the **question**,
then it does not proceed.
Thus, **dispersing effort** is waiting for the **opportunity** to move.
When it moves and **obtains** the **question**,
then **effort** is **divided**.

Therefore, those skilled in **thinking through the question**,
must **refine** the **Five Qi** [五气] **internally**,
and **observe** the **empty** and **real** **externally**—
when they move,
they do not lose the **truth** of **division** and **dispersion**.
The **Five Qi** must be **refined internally**,
then one can **externally** **discern**.
If the **logic of empty** and **real** is not **lost**,
then the **question** can also be **known**.
If there is a **question** and one **knows** it,
then one can **not lose** the **truth** of **division** and **dispersion**.

When one moves,
they follow their **resolve** and **intent**,
and **know** their **strategies** and **plots**.
**Strategies** and **plots** are the **forms** of **resolve** and **intent**,
so one follows their **resolve** and **intent** to **know** their **strategies**.

**Effort** is the **pivot** of **benefit** and **harm**,
the **Wei** of **strategic adaptation**.
The **defeated in effort** are those who do not **solemnly observe** with **spirit**.
If **spirit** does not **solemnly observe**,
then **effort** is **defeated**.
The **method of turning roundness** is like the **fierce beast**.
When **strategies** are **endless** and **unfathomable**,
they are like the **fierce beast**.

**Turning roundness** is when **matters** arrive,
like the **endless roundness** of turning.
**Turning** is like the **unending威** of beasts.
**Turning roundness** is the **method** of **unfathomable strategies**.
The **unfathomable** **heart** and **unmeasurable** **mind**,
with **original** and **unfathomable** **techniques**—
the **sage’s heart** is like a **mirror**,
**things** respond as they are **sensed**,
so the **unfathomable** **mind** and **techniques** of the **heart’s unfolding** can be **communicated**.

Yet, the **Dao/Way** of **spirit** is **mixed and indistinct** as one **principle** without **end**.
To **discuss** the **ten thousand variations** of **meaning**,
once the **sage’s heart** **originally** **unfathomably** **mixes** the **indistinct**,
and **wonders** at **things** in **dimness** and **change**,
then the **unfathomable** **meaning** can be **explained**.
**Wisdom** and **strategies**, **plots** and **calculations**,
each have **manifestations**—
either **yang** or **yin**,

chunks.original_text: 鬼谷子 经名：鬼谷子。 梁陶弘景注。 三卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》太玄部。 参校版本：一、四库全书文渊阁本（简称《四库》本）。 二、嘉庆十年江都泰氏刻本（简称嘉庆本）。 目录 卷上 摔阖第一 反应第二 内挞第三 抵铁第四 卷中 飞箝第五 件合第六 揣篇第七 摩篇第八 权篇第九 谋篇第十 央篇第十一 符言第十二 转丸、肚乱二篇皆亡 卷下 本经阴符七篇 鬼谷子卷上 摔阖第一 摔，拨动也。 阖，闭藏也。 凡与人之言道，或拨动之，令有言示其同也； 或闭藏之，令自言示其异也。 粤若稽古，圣人之在天地问也， 若，顺； 稽，考也。 圣人在天地问，观人设教，铃顺考古道而为之。 为众生之先， 首出万物以前人，用先知觉后知，用先觉觉后觉，故为众生先。 观阴阳之开阖以名#1命物， 阳开以生物，阴阖以成物。 生成既着，须立名以命之也。 知存亡之门户， 不忘亡者存，有其存者亡。 能知吉西之先见者，其惟知机乎。 故日：知存亡之门户也。 筹策万类之终始，达人心之理，见变化之朕焉。 万类终始，人心之理，变化朕逵，莫不朗然，玄悟而无幽不测，故能筹策达见焉。 朕，迸也#2。 而守司其门户， 司，主守也。 门户，即上存亡之门户也。 圣人既达物理，终始知存亡之门户，能守而司之，令其背亡而趣存也。 故圣人之在天下也，自古至今，其道一也。 莫不背亡而趣存，故日其道一也。 变化无穷，各有所归。 其道虽一，行之不同，故日变化无穷。 然有条而不紊，故日各有所归也。 或阴或阳，或柔或刚，或开或闭，或弛或张。 此二者法象各异，施教不同。 是故圣人一守司其门户，审察其所先后！ 政教虽殊，至於守司门户则一，故审察其所宜先者先行，所宜后者后行之也。 度权量能，校其仗巧短长。 权谓权谋，能谓村能，使巧谓百工之役。 言圣人之用人，铃量度其谋能之优劣，校考其仗巧之长短，然后因村而用。 夫贤不肖、智愚、勇怯、仁义有差，乃可摔，乃可闱，乃可进，乃可退，乃可贱，乃可贵，无为以牧之。 言贤不肖、智愚、勇怯村性不同，各有差品。 贤者可牌而同之，不肖者可阖而异之，智之与勇可进而贵之，愚之与怯可退而贱之。 贤愚各当其分，股肱尽其力，但恭己无为牧之而已矣。 审定有无以#3其实虚，随其嗜欲以见其志意。 言任贤之道，铃审定其村衍之有无，性行之虚实，然后随其嗜欲而任之，以见其志意之真伪也。 微排其所言而掉反之，以求其实，贵得其指阖而摔之，以求其利。 凡言事者，则微排抑其所言，拨动以反难之，以求其实情。 实情既得，又自闭藏而拨动之，彼以求其所言之利何如耳。 或开而示之，或阖而闭之。 开而示之者同其情也，阖而闭之者异其诚也。 开而同之所以尽其情，阖而异之所以知其诚也。 可与不可，审明其计谋，以原其同异。 凡有所言有可有不可，爻明审其计谋，以原其同异。 离合有守，先从其志。 计谋虽离合不同？ 但能有所执守，则先从其志以尽之，以知成败之归也。 即欲掉之贵周，即欲阖之贵密。 周密之贵，微而与道相追。 言拨动之，贵其周遍； 闭藏之，贵其隐密。 而此二者皆须微妙合於道之理，然后为得也。 掉之者料其情也，阖之者结其诚也。 料而#5简择，结谓系束。

**Ghost Valley Master (Guiguzi) – *The Canon of Ghost Valley***

**Title:** *Ghost Valley Master (Guiguzi)*
**Commentary by:** Tao Hongjing of Liang
**Three Scrolls**
**Source Text:** *Zhengtong Daozang* (Orthodox Daoist Canon), *Taixuan* (Great Mystery) Section
**Collated Editions:**
1. *Siku Quanshu* (Complete Library of the Four Treasuries) from the Wenyan Pavilion (hereafter *Siku* edition)
2. Jiangdu Tai Family engraving, Jiaqing 10th year (hereafter *Jiaqing* edition)

---

**Table of Contents**
**Scroll One**
1. *Shuaihé* (Disrupting and Concealing)
2. *Fanying* (Responding in Reverse)
3. *Neitā* (Internal Subduing)
4. *Dǐtiě* (Blocking and Repelling)

**Scroll Two**
5. *Fēizhēn* (Flying Snares)
6. *Jiànhé* (Articulating Unity)
7. *Xuānpian* (Probing Discourse)
8. *Mópiān* (Friction Discourse)
9. *Quánpiān* (Weighted Discourse)
10. *Móupiān* (Strategic Discourse)
11. *Yāngpiān* (Central Discourse)
12. *Fúyán* (Symbolic Speech)
(*Note: "Zhuǎnwán" and "Dùluàn" are lost*)

**Scroll Three**
*The Seven *Yīnfú* Treatises of This Canon*

---
**Ghost Valley Master – Scroll One**

**1. Shuaihé (Disrupting and Concealing)**
*Shuai* means to agitate or unsettle.
*Hé* means to conceal or withdraw.

When engaging with others in discourse, one may either **agitate them**, prompting them to reveal their alignment, or **conceal them**, prompting them to reveal their divergence.

**If one examines antiquity**, the Sage, when questioning the cosmos, followed (*ruò*) and considered (*qǐ*) the ancient Dao, teaching accordingly.

The Sage, as the first among all beings, emerged before all things, using **prior knowledge to enlighten the unknowing**, and **prior enlightenment to awaken the unenlightened**. Thus, the Sage is first among all beings.

Observing the **opening and closing of Yin and Yang**, the Sage named and commanded all things.
Yang opens to generate life; Yin closes to complete it.
Once generation and completion are established, names must be assigned to them.

Knowing the **gates of existence and annihilation**—
Do not forget that those who perish are those who exist, and those who exist are those who perish.
Only those who perceive the **omens of fortune and misfortune beforehand** truly grasp the *machine* (critical junctures).

Thus it is said: **"Know the gates of existence and annihilation."**

Calculating the **termination and origin of all things**, penetrating the logic of human hearts, and perceiving the **portents of transformation**—
The termination and origin of all things, the logic of human hearts, and the portents of transformation are all clearly manifest. Through profound insight, nothing remains obscure or unmeasured. Thus, one can calculate, penetrate, and perceive.

*Zhèn* (portents) means **sudden emergence**.

And one **guards and oversees these gates**—
*Shǐ* means to **maintain and govern**.
The gates refer to the **gates of existence and annihilation** mentioned above.

Having penetrated the principles of things, knowing the termination and origin of existence and annihilation, the Sage guards and oversees them, ensuring all turn away from annihilation and toward existence.

Thus, the Sage’s Dao in the world, from ancient times to today, remains **one**.

Though all turn away from annihilation and toward existence, the Dao is one.

**Transformation is boundless**, yet all things return to their proper place.
Though the Dao is one, its practice varies, hence **transformation is boundless**. Yet it remains orderly, hence **all things return to their proper place**.

Sometimes **Yin**, sometimes **Yang**; sometimes **soft**, sometimes **hard**; sometimes **open**, sometimes **closed**; sometimes **relaxed**, sometimes **tense**.
These two aspects—**law and symbol**—differ in form, and their teachings vary accordingly.

Thus, the Sage, though **one in guarding and overseeing the gates**, must **carefully examine what comes first or last**!
Though governance may differ, in guarding and overseeing the gates, the Sage remains consistent. Therefore, one must carefully examine what should be prioritized and what should follow.

**Measuring ability and assessing skill**, comparing their strengths and weaknesses.
*Quán* refers to **strategic calculation**; *néng* refers to **inherent ability**; *zhàngqiǎo* refers to **artisan craftsmanship**.

The Sage, in employing people, measures their **strategic acumen and abilities**, assesses their **craftsmanship and skill**, and then assigns them accordingly.

Among the **virtuous and unvirtuous, the wise and foolish, the brave and cowardly, the benevolent and righteous**, there are differences. Thus, one may:
- **Agitate** the virtuous to align them,
- **Conceal** the unvirtuous to reveal their divergence,
- **Advance** the wise and brave to honor them,
- **Retreat** the foolish and cowardly to degrade them,
- **Elevate** or **debase** them as needed,
Yet **do nothing** (*wuwei*) and **shepherd them with humility**.

The virtuous and foolish each fulfill their roles; ministers and officials exert their strengths. The only requirement is **humility and non-action** in guiding them.

**Carefully determine presence and absence** to discern their **substance and emptiness**, and **follow their desires** to reveal their **intentions**.
In employing the worthy, one must first **carefully determine their substance and emptiness**, their **honesty and deceit**, then follow their desires to discern their **true intentions**.

**Subtly challenge their words** and turn them back upon themselves to seek the truth, valuing **obtaining their alignment through agitation** to seek their advantage.
When others speak, one must **subtly challenge and invert their words**, agitating them to reveal their true sentiments. Once the truth is obtained, one may **conceal and agitate them further**, prompting them to seek the **advantage of their own words**.

Sometimes **open and reveal**, sometimes **conceal and close**.
Opening and revealing aligns their sentiments; concealing and closing reveals their sincerity.
Opening aligns to **exhaust their sentiments**; concealing diverges to **test their sincerity**.

**What is permissible and what is not**—carefully examine their strategies to **trace their alignment or divergence**.
In all speech, what is permissible and what is not must be **clearly examined**, their strategies scrutinized to **determine their true alignment or divergence**.

**Unity and separation have their principles**; first, follow their intentions.
Though strategies may vary in unity or separation, if one **holds fast to principle**, they may first follow their intentions to **fulfill them**, thereby knowing the **outcome of success or failure**.

If one seeks to **agitate**, **thoroughness is paramount**; if one seeks to **conceal**, **secrecy is paramount**.
The value of **thoroughness and secrecy** lies in their subtlety, aligning with the Dao.

Agitation **probes their sentiments**; concealment **binds their sincerity**.
Probing while **selecting and choosing**, binding while **tying and restraining**.

chunks.original_text: 情有真伪，故须简择。 诚或无终，故须系束也。 皆见其权衡轻重，乃为之度数，圣人因而为之虑； 权衡既陈，轻重自分，然后为之度数，以制其轻重。 轻重因得所，而为设谋虑，使之遵#5行也。 其不中权衡度数，圣人因而自为之虑。 谓轻重不合於斤两，长短不充於度一数，便为废物，何所施哉。 圣人因是自为谋虑，更求其反也。 故摔者或摔而出之，或摔而纳之； 谓中权衡者出而用之，其不中者纳而藏之也。 阖者或闱而取之，或阖而去之。 诚者阖而取之，不诚者阖而去之。 摔阖者，天地之道。 阖户谓之坤，辟户谓之乾。 故谓天地之道。 掉阖者以变动阴阳、四时开闭以化万物纵横。 阴场变动，四时开闭，皆牌阖之道也。 纵横，谓废起也。 万物或开以起之，或阖而废之。 反出、反覆、反性，必由此矣。 言牌阖之道，或反之，令出於彼； 或反之，覆来於此； 或反之於彼，性之於此，皆从牌阖而生。 故曰叉由此也。 摔阖者，道之大化，说之变也，必豫审其变化。 言事无开阖，则大道不化。 言说无变，故开闭者所以化大道。 变言说事虽大，莫不成之於变化。 故爻豫之。 吉凶系焉#6。 口者，心之门户也； 心者，神之主也。 心因口宣，故口者心之门户也。 神为心用，故心者神之主也。 志意喜欲，思虑智谋，此皆由门户出入。 几此八者皆往来於口中，故日由门户出入也。 故关之掉闱，制之以出入。 掉之者，开也，言也，阳也。 闱之者，闭也，默也，阴也。 言八者若无开闭，事或不节，故关之以牌阖者，所以制其出入。 开言於外，故日阳也。 闭情於内，故日阴也。 阴阳其和，终始其义。 开闭有节，故阴阳和。 先后合宜，故终始义。 故言长生、安乐、富贵、尊荣、显名、爱好、财利、得意、喜欲为阳，曰始。 几此皆欲人之生，故日始日阳。 故言死亡#7、忧患、贫贱、苦辱、弃损亡利、失意有害、刑戮诛罚为阴，日终。 几此皆欲人之死，故日阴日终。 诸言法阳之类者，皆曰始，言善以始其事。 诸言法阴之类者#8，皆日终，言恶以终为谋。 谓言说者有於阴言之，有於阳言之，听者宜知其然。 掉闱之道，以阴阳试之。 谓或拨动之，或闭藏之。 以阴阳之言试之，则其情慕可知。 故与阳言者依崇高，与阴言者依卑小， 谓与情阳者言，高以引之； 与情阴者言，卑以引之。 以下求小，以高求大。 阴言卑小，故日以下求小； 阳言崇高，故日以高求大。 由此言之，无所不出，无所不入，无所不可， 阴阳之理尽，小大之情得，故出入皆可，何所不可乎。 可以说人，可以说家，可以说国，可以说天下。 无所不可，故所说皆可。 为小无内，为大无外。 尽阴则无内，尽阳则无外。 益损、去就、倍反，皆以阴阳御其事。 以道相成日益，以事相贼日损，义乖日去，志同日就，去而遂绝日倍，去而复来日反。 凡此不出阴阳之情，故日皆以阴阳御其事也。 阳动而行，阴止而藏。 阳动而出，阴随而入。 阳还终始，阴极反阳。 此言上下相成，由阴阳相生也。 以阳动者德相生也，以阴静者形相成也。 以阳求阴，苞以德也； 以阴结阳，施以力也。 此言上以爵禄养下，下以股肱宣力。 阴阳相求，由摔阖也。 上下所以能相求者，由开闭而生也。

Emotions may be true or false, hence the need for **selection and discernment**. Sincerity may lack constancy, hence the need for **binding and restraint**.

All this reveals the **weights and measures** of their **calculations**—thus the Sage **deliberates accordingly**. When the **weights and measures** are laid out, the **light and heavy** naturally distinguish themselves, and only then are **standards** established to **regulate their lightness and heaviness**. Once **light and heavy** find their proper place, **strategies and deliberations** are devised to **guide them along**.

Those who do not conform to the **weights and measures** and **standards** are thus considered by the Sage to be **flawed**—their **lightness and heaviness** do not align with the **true measure**, their **length and shortfall** do not fulfill the **proper count**. Such are **worthless**; what use are they?

The Sage therefore **reconsiders and devises new strategies**, seeking their **opposite**. Thus, when **agitating**, one may either **cast forth** or **withdraw and store**; those who conform to the **weights and measures** are cast forth for use, while the unworthy are withdrawn and hidden.

When **concealing**, one may either **retain** or **reject**. The sincere are retained, the insincere are rejected. **Agitation and concealment** are the **Dao of Heaven and Earth**.

**Closing the door** is called **Kun (receptive)**, **opening the door** is called **Qian (creative)**—thus, they are the **Dao of Heaven and Earth**.

**Agitation and concealment** shift **yin and yang**, the **opening and closing of the four seasons**, to **transform all things** in their **longitudinal and latitudinal** ways. The **yin field** shifts, the **four seasons** open and close—all this is the **Dao of agitation and concealment**.

**Longitudinal and latitudinal** refer to **decay and renewal**. All things are either **opened to rise** or **concealed to decay**. **Reversal, inversion, and transformation** must arise from this.

Speaking of the **Dao of agitation and concealment**, it may **reverse** to emerge from one place, or **reverse** to return from another, or **reverse** to transform here while its **nature** manifests there—all this stems from **agitation and concealment**. Hence it is said: *"This is how it arises."*

**Agitation and concealment** are the **great transformations of the Dao**, the **variations of speech**—one must **forewarn and examine** their transformations. If there is no **opening and closing**, the **great Dao** would not transform. If there is no **variation in speech**, then **opening and closing** are what **transform the great Dao**. Though **speech and affairs** may be vast, they all **achieve completion through transformation**. Hence, **divination is prepared**.

**Fortune and misfortune depend on this**. The **mouth** is the **gatekeeper of the heart**; the **heart** is the **master of the spirit**. The heart **expresses itself through the mouth**, hence the mouth is the **gatekeeper of the heart**. The spirit **serves the heart**, hence the heart is the **master of the spirit**.

**Desires, intentions, joys, and appetites**, **thoughts, wisdom, and strategies**—all these **pass through the gate** in and out. These **eight aspects** all **traverse the mouth**, hence it is said they **enter and exit through the gate**.

Thus, **controlling agitation and concealment** regulates their **entry and exit**. **Agitation** is **opening, speaking, yang**; **concealment** is **closing, silence, yin**.

If these **eight aspects** lack **opening and closing**, affairs may become **unregulated**, hence **agitation and concealment** are used to **govern their entry and exit**. **Speaking outward** is **yang**; **concealing emotions inward** is **yin**. When **yin and yang** are harmonized, their **beginning and end** are complete.

**Opening and closing** are **regulated**, hence **yin and yang** are harmonized. **Sequence and order** are appropriate, hence their **beginning and end** are complete.

Thus, **longevity, peace, wealth, honor, fame, affection, profit, satisfaction, joy, and desire** are called **yang**—**beginning**. These all **seek life**, hence they are called **beginning, yang**.

**Death, sorrow, poverty, humiliation, loss, harm, punishment, and execution** are called **yin**—**end**. These all **seek death**, hence they are called **yin, end**.

All **speech that follows yang** is called **beginning**, meaning **goodness initiates affairs**. All **speech that follows yin** is called **end**, meaning **evil concludes strategies**.

It is said that **speech** may be **yin** or **yang**; the listener must **know this distinction**. The **Dao of agitation and concealment** is tested through **yin and yang**.

Whether one **probes** or **conceals**, using **yin and yang speech** to test them reveals their **true intentions**. Thus, when speaking to those of **yang disposition**, one **elevates** them; when speaking to those of **yin disposition**, one **lowers** them.

To those of **yin disposition**, speak **lowly** to seek the **small**; to those of **yang disposition**, speak **highly** to seek the **great**. **Yin speech** is **low and small**, hence *"seek the small with lowliness"*; **yang speech** is **elevated**, hence *"seek the great with height."*

From this, **nothing is excluded**, **nothing is barred**, **nothing is impossible**. When **yin and yang** are exhausted, **small and great** are revealed—thus **entry and exit are all permissible**; what is there that cannot be?

One may **speak to individuals**, to **families**, to **nations**, to **the world**. There is **nothing impossible**, hence all that is spoken is **permissible**.

To act **small** is to have **no interior**; to act **great** is to have **no exterior**. Exhausting **yin** leaves **no interior**, exhausting **yang** leaves **no exterior**.

**Gain and loss, departure and arrival, doubling and reversal**—all are governed by **yin and yang**. **Following the Dao** is called **gain**; **harming affairs** is called **loss**; **contradicting principle** is called **departure**; **aligning with intention** is called **arrival**; **departing utterly** is called **doubling**; **departing and returning** is called **reversal**.

All this does not exceed the **nature of yin and yang**, hence it is said: *"All are governed by yin and yang."*

**Yang moves and acts**; **yin stops and conceals**. **Yang moves outward**; **yin follows inward**. **Yang returns to its beginning and end**; **yin reaches its limit and reverses to yang**.

This speaks of **upper and lower** completing each other through **yin and yang generation**. **Yang moves** to **generate virtue**; **yin remains still** to **form substance**. **Seeking yin with yang** is **enveloping with virtue**; **binding yang with yin** is **applying force**.

This means the **noble nourishes the commoner with rank and rewards**, while the **commoner responds with strength and labor**. **Yin and yang seek each other** through **agitation and concealment**. The **upper and lower** can **seek each other** because **opening and closing** give rise to this.

chunks.original_text: 此天地阴阳之道而说人之法也， 言既体天地，象阴阳，故其法可以说人也。 为万事之先，是谓圆方之门户。 天圆地方，上下之义也。 理尽开闭，然后生万物，故为万事先，上下之道，自此出入。 故日圆方之门户。 反应第二 听言之道，或有一不合，必反以难之，彼因难以更思，必有以应也 古之大化者，乃与无形俱生， 大化者、谓古之圣人以大道化物也。 无形者，道也。 动叉由道，故日无形俱生也。 反以观往，覆以验今； 反以知古，覆以知今； 反以知彼，覆以知己。 言大化圣人稽众拾己，举事重慎，反覆详验，欲以知来，先以观往； 欲以知今，先以考古； 欲以知彼，先度於己。 故能举无遗策，动铃成功。 动静虚实之理，不合来#9今，反古而求之。 动静由行止也，虚实由真伪也，其理不合於今，反求於古者也。 事有反而得覆者，圣人之意也， 事有不合，反而求彼，翻得覆会，於此成此，在於考彼。 契今由於求古，斯圣人之意也。 不可不察。 不审则失之於几，故不可不察。 人言者动也，己默者静也。 因其言，听其辞。 以静观动，则所见审。 因言观辞，则所得明。 言有不合者，反而求之，其应必出。 谓言者或不合於理，未可即斥，但反而难之，使自求之，则契理之应怡然自出。 言有象，事有比，其有象比，以观其次。 应理既出，故能言有象，事有比。 前事既有象比，更当观其次，令得自尽。 象谓法象，比谓比例。 象者象其事，比者比其辞也。 以无形求有声， 理在玄微，故无形也。 无言则不彰，故以无形求有声。 声即言也，比谓比类也。 其钓语合事，得人实也。 得鱼在於投饵，得语在於发端。 发端则语应，投饵则鱼来，故日钓语。 语则事合，故日合事。 明试在於敷言，故日得人实也。 其犹#10张买网而取兽也，多张其会而司之，道合其事，彼自出之，此钓人之网也。 张网而司之，彼兽自得。 道合其事，彼理自出。 理既彰，圣贤斯辨。 虽欲自隐，其道无由，故日钓人之网也。 常持其网驱之，其不#11言无比，乃为之变。 持钓人之网，驱令就职事也。 或乖彼，遂不言无比。 如此则为之变常易网，更有以勇#12之者矣。 以象动之，以报其心，见其情，随而牧之， 此言其变也。 报，犹合也。 谓更开法象以动之，既合其心，其情可见，因随其情而牧养也。 己反往，彼覆来，言有象比，因而定基。 己反往以求彼，彼叉覆来而就职，则奇策铃申。 故言有象比，则口无择言。 故可以定邦家之基矣。 重之袭之，反之覆之，万事不失其辞。 谓象比之言，既可以定基，然后重之袭之，反覆之，皆谓再三详审，不容谬妄。 故能万事允惬，无复失其辞者也。 圣人所诱愚智，事皆不疑。 圣人诱愚，则闭藏之，以知其诚； 诱智，则拨动之，以尽其情，咸得其实。 故事皆不疑也。 古善反听者，乃变鬼神以得其情。 言善反听者，乃坐忘遗鉴，不思玄览，故能变鬼神以得其情，洞幽微而冥。 夫会鬼神本密，今则不能，故日变也。 其变，当也； 而牧之，审也。 言既变而当理，然后牧之道审也。 牧之不审，得情不明； 得情不明，定基不审。 情明在於审牧，故不审则不明； 审基在於情明，故不明则不审。 变象比，必有反辞，以还听之。

The principles of **movement and stillness, emptiness and substance** do not align with the present—then one seeks them in antiquity. **Movement and stillness** arise from **action and cessation**; **emptiness and substance** arise from **truth and falsity**. To **seek the voiced from the formless**—principle lies in **profound subtlety**, hence it is **formless**. When the **baited words** align with the affair, one obtains the **truth of the person**.

When the **Dao/Way** aligns with the affair, the principle emerges on its own. Once the principle is manifest, the **sage and worthy** distinguish it.

Even if one seeks to conceal themselves, the **Dao/Way** provides no escape—hence, it is called the **net for capturing people**. If one **constantly holds the net** to drive them toward their duties, those who **defy** will inevitably **speak without restraint**, and one must then **adapt the net**.

To **hold the net for capturing people** is to drive them toward their duties. If they **contradict**, they will **speak without restraint**. Thus, one must **change the net** and further **urge them with boldness**.

To **stir with symbols**, to **respond to their intent**, to **see their emotions**, and to **guide them accordingly**—this speaks of **adaptation**. **Respond** means to **align**. **I reflect upon the past**; **they invert to come forward**. When speech has **symbols and analogies**, one establishes the **foundation** accordingly. The ancient masters of **inverted listening** transformed **ghosts and spirits** to obtain their emotions. The **gathering of ghosts and spirits** is inherently **secretive**; now, it cannot be done—hence, it is called **transformation**. When **symbols and analogies** are transformed, there will surely be **inverted speech** to return and listen to.

chunks.original_text: 谓言者於象比有变，叉有反辞以难之，令其先说，我乃还静以听之。 欲闻其声反默，欲张反睑，欲高反下，欲取反与。 此言反听之道，有以诱致之。 故欲闻彼声，我反静默； 欲彼开张，我反睑敛，欲彼高大，我反卑下； 欲彼收取，我反施与，如此则物情可致，无能自隐也。 欲开情者，象而比之，以牧其辞，同声相呼，实理同归。 欲开彼情，先设象比而动之。 彼情既动，将欲生辞，徐徐牧养，令其自言，譬犹鹤呜于阴，声同叉应。 故能以实理相归也。 或因此或因彼，或以事上或以牧下， 谓所言之事，或因此发端，或因彼发端。 其事有可以事上，可以牧下者也。 此听真伪，知同异，得其情诈也。 谓真伪、同异、情诈，因此上事而知也。 动作言默与此出入觔喜怒由此以见其式， 谓动作言默，莫不由情与之出入。 至於或喜或怒，亦由此情以见其式也。 皆以先定为之法则，' 谓上六者皆以先定於情，然后法则可为。 以反求覆观其所托。 故用此者， 反於彼者所以求覆於此，因以观彼情之所托，此谓信也。 知人在於见情，故言用此也。 己欲平静，以听其辞，察其事，论万物，别雄雌。 谓听言之道，先自平静。 既得其辞，然后察其事＇，或论序万物，或分别雄雌也。 虽非其事，见微知类。 谓所言之事虽非时要，然观此可以知微#13，故日见微知类。 若探人而居其内，量其能，射其意也。 符应不失，如剩蛇之所指，若羿之引矢。 闻其言，则可知其情。 故若探人而居其内，则情原叉尽。 故量能射意，乃无一失。 若合符契，胜蛇所指，祸福不差； 羿之引矢，命处辄中。 听言察情，不异於此，故以相况也。 故知之始，己自知而后知人也。 知人者智，自知者明。 智从明生，明能生智。 放欲知人铃须自知。 其相知也，若比目之鱼； 见形也，若光之与影也。 我能知己，彼须我知，叉两得之，然后圣贤道合，故若比目之鱼。 圣贤合，则理自彰，犹光生而影见。 其察言也不失，若磁石之取缄，舌之取墦骨。 以圣察贤，复何所失。 故若磁石之取缄，舌之取翻骨。 其与人也微，其见情也疾。 圣贤相与，其道甚微； 不移寸阴，见情甚疾。 如阴与阳，如阳与阴，如圆与方，如方与圆。 上下之道，取类股肱，比之一体，其来尚矣。 故其相成也，如阴与阳。 其相形也，犹圆与方。 未见形，圆以道之； 既见#14形，方以事之， 谓向晦入息，未见之时，当以圆道导之； 亦既出港离隐，见形之后，即以方职任之。 进退左右，以是司之。 此言用人之道，或升进或黜退，或贬左或崇右，一惟上圆方之理。 故日以是道司之。 己不先定，牧人不正， 方圆进退，若不先定，则於牧人之理不道#15其正也。 事用不巧，是谓忘情失道。 用事不巧，则操末续颠，圆凿方柄，情道两失，故日忘情失道也。 己审先定以牧人，策而无形容，莫见其门，是谓天神。 己能审定，以之牧人，至德港畅，玄风远扇，非形非容，无门无户，见形而不及，道日用而不知，故谓之天神也。 内键第三 挞者，持之令固也。 得，然后结圆而不离。 君臣上下之事道合则远而亲就之不用非其意则就之而不用，顺其事则去之而反求。 日进前而不御，遥闻声而相思。 分违则日进前而不御声而相思。

「When one speaks, **symbols and analogies** are transformed, and **inverted speech** arises to challenge them. One should let them speak first, then return to **stillness** to listen.

To hear their words, one must remain **silent**; to make them reveal themselves, one must **close one’s eyes** and feign indifference. To raise their voice, one must lower one’s own; to take from them, one must offer instead. This is the **Dao/Way of inverted listening**, by which one can **entice and draw forth** their true emotions.

Thus, when one desires to hear their voice, one must **return to stillness** and **silence**; when one desires them to speak openly, one must **close one’s eyes** and **compress one’s gaze**; when one desires them to be lofty, one must appear **humble**; when one desires them to withdraw, one must **give freely**. In this way, their **emotions** can be **drawn out**, and nothing will remain **hidden**.

To **open their emotions**, one must first **transform symbols and analogies** and **stir them** through **guiding speech**. When voices resonate in harmony, **true principle** converges. If one wishes to **open their emotions**, first **present symbols and analogies** to **move them**. Once their emotions are stirred, **guiding speech** must be **nurtured gradually**, allowing them to speak naturally—like cranes calling in the shade, their voices echoing in response.

Thus, **true principle** can be **drawn together**.

Sometimes this arises from one thing, sometimes from another; sometimes by **attending to the superior** (*shàng*), sometimes by **guiding the inferior** (*xià*). The **Dao/Way of inverted listening** is to know whether their words stem from this or that, or whether they are **attended to from above** or **guided from below**. This is how one **discerns truth from falsehood**, knows **harmony from discord**, and **detects their deceit**.

For **truth and falsehood**, **harmony and discord**, and **deceit**, one discerns them through **attending to the superior** (*shàng*). Their **actions, words, and silences** all emerge from **emotions**; their **joy or anger** reveals their **intentions**.

All this depends on **first establishing clarity within oneself**—this is the **method** for **guiding speech**. One must **invert and probe** to observe where their **emotions** are **lodged**, thus **testing their sincerity**.

To **know others**, one must first **see their emotions**; hence, this **Dao/Way of inverted listening** is employed. If one seeks **inner stillness**, one must listen to their words, examine their **affairs**, **discuss all things**, and **distinguish between strength and weakness**.

Though their words may not be of immediate concern, one can **perceive the subtle** and **know the general** (*lèi*). When one **investigates others** and **dwells within their intentions**, one can **measure their capacity** and **shoot their intent**—like a snake’s mark never missing, or **Yì’s arrow** striking true.

If their **words and emotions align**, their **fortune or misfortune** will not stray—like **Yì’s arrow** finding its mark without fail. **Listening to speech** and **observing emotions** is no different; hence, they are compared thus.

Thus, the **beginning of knowing** lies in **self-knowledge** before knowing others. The one who **knows others** is **wise**; the one who **knows oneself** is **enlightened**. **Wisdom** arises from **enlightenment**, and **enlightenment** can **generate wisdom**. To **know others**, one must first **know oneself**.

Their **mutual understanding** is like **eyeless fish** (*bǐmù*)—each depends on the other. Their **manifestation** is like **light and shadow**—one cannot exist without the other. I can **know myself**; they must **rely on my knowing them**—both gain, and only then do the **Dao/Way of the sages** converge, hence like **eyeless fish**.

When **sages** unite, **principle** naturally **shines forth**, like light giving rise to shadow. Their **words are never lost**—like **magnets drawing nails** or **tongues touching the palate**. If one **discerns the sage** with **sagely wisdom**, what more is there to lose? Hence, like **magnets drawing nails** or **tongues touching the palate**.

Their **interaction with others** is **subtle**; their **perception of emotions** is **swift**. The **Dao/Way of sages** in dealing with others is **refined and elusive**; yet in an instant, they **see emotions** with precision—like **yin** and **yáng**, or **yáng** and **yin**, like **roundness** and **squareness**, or **squareness** and **roundness**.

The **Dao/Way of ascending and descending** (*shàngxià*) is to **take their type** as one’s own **arms and legs**—to **compare them as parts of a single body**. This **principle** has been **long-standing**.

Thus, their **mutual fulfillment** is like **yin** and **yáng**. Their **mutual manifestation** is like **roundness** and **squareness**. Before their **form is seen**, one **guides them with the Dao/Way of roundness**; once their **form is manifest**, one **tasks them with the square method**.

Their **advancement or retreat**, **left or right placement**, is governed by this. This is the **Dao/Way of employing others**—whether **promoting them**, **demoting them**, **assigning them to the left**, or **elevating them to the right**—all is determined by the **principle of ascending and descending** (*shàngxià*).

If one does not **first establish clarity within oneself**, then **guiding others** will be **improper**. Their **advancement or retreat**, **left or right placement**, if not **first established**, will not align with the **proper method** of **guiding others**.

If their **employment** is **unskillful**, it is called **forgetting emotions** and **losing the Dao/Way**. When **employment is unskillful**, one **operates from the superficial** (*mò*), **continues without pause** (*xù*), **uses round tools for square holes** (*záo*), and **square tools for round holes** (*bǐng*), thus **losing both emotions and the Dao/Way**.

If one **first establishes clarity** and **guides others** with **perfect virtue**, then one **drives without visible trace** (*míngxiàng*), **no one sees one’s approach** (*mén*), and it is called **heavenly and divine**.

If one can **first establish clarity**, then **guiding others** becomes **virtuous and boundless**—**mysterious winds** (*xuánfēng*) **blow far and wide**, neither **form nor trace** is seen, neither **door nor entrance** (*ménhù*) is apparent. One **sees their form** yet cannot **grasp it**; the **Dao/Way** is **ever-applied** yet **unknown**. Hence, it is called **heavenly and divine**.

**Inner Harmony, the Third Chapter**

**Binding** (*chà*) means **holding fast** so that it remains **secure**. One **secures** only after **obtaining**—then **roundness is joined** without separation.

In matters of **ruler and subject**, **superior and inferior**, if the **Dao/Way aligns**, they **draw near despite distance**; if it does not align, they **stay distant despite closeness**, and **reject what is not their intent**. If their **affairs are in accord**, they **depart yet return** in seeking **harmony**.

They **advance yet do not approach**; they **hear voices from afar** yet **ponder them in return**. When **separated**, they **advance yet do not approach**, and **hear voices** while **pondering in return**.»

chunks.original_text: 事皆有内挞言或有远之而相亲故日皆有内挞，结以道德，之，友，为臣也言上下之交，必内情相有远而亲，近而疏，，情乖则近而疏。 去之反求，素结本始。 理契则遥闻去之反求，闻声而思者，皆由内合相待素结本始也。 或结以道德，或结以党友货，或结以采色。 素结其始。 或结以财谓以道德结连於君臣名为臣，实为师也。 谓以友道结连於君鬼谷子卷上结以党王者之臣名实为友也。 结以货财结以采色，谓若桀纣之臣费仲、恶来之类是也。 用其意，欲入则入，欲出则出，欲亲则亲，欲疏则疏，欲就则就，欲去则去，欲求则求，欲思则思。 自入出已下八事，皆用臣之意，随其所欲。 故能固志於君，物莫能间也。 若鴂母之从其子也，出无问，入无朕，独往独来，莫之能止。 扶母，蝗蜡也，似蜘蛛，在穴中，有盖。 言蚁母养子以盖覆穴，出入往来，初无问眼，故物不能止之。 今内挞之臣，委曲从君，以自结固，无有问隙，亦由是也。 内者进说辞，挞者挞所谋也。 说辞既进，内结於君。 故日内者进说辞也。 度情为谋，君不持而不拾，故日挞者挞所谋也。 欲说者务隐度，计事者务循顺。 说而隐度，则其说铃行。 计而循顺，则其计叉用。 阴虑可否，明言得失，以御其志。 谓隐虑可否，然后明言得失，以御君志也。 方来应时，以合其谋。 方，谓道衍，谓以道卫来进，铃应时宜，以合会君谋也。 详思来挞，往应时当也。 详思计虑，来进於君，可以自固，然后往应时宜，必当君心也。 夫内有不合者，不可施行也。 计虑不合於君，则不可施行也。 乃揣切时宜，从便所为，以求其变。 前计既有不合，乃更揣量切摩当时所为之便，以求所以变计也。 以变求内者，若管取挞。 以管取挞，挞叉离，以变求内，内铃合。 言往者，先顺辞也； 说来者，以变言也。 往事已着，故言之贵顺辞； 来事未形，故说之贵通变也。 善变者审知地势，乃通於天，以化四时，使鬼神合於阴阳。 善变者，谓善识通变之理。 审知地势，则天道可知。 故日乃通於天。 知天，则四时顺理而从化。 故日以化四时。 鬼神者，助阴阳以生物者也。 道通天地，乃能使鬼神合德於阴阳也。 而牧人民，见其谋事，知其志意。 既能知地通天，化四时，合阴阳，乃可以牧养人民。 其养人也，铃见其谋事而知其志意也。 事有不合者，有所未知也。 谓知之，即与合； 未知，即不与合也。 合而不结者，阳亲而阴疏。 或有离合而不结固者，谓以阳外相亲，阴内相疏也。 事有不合者，圣人不为谋也。 不合，谓圆凿而方柄； 故圣人不为谋也#16。 故远而亲者有阴德也，近而疏者志不合也； 阴德，谓阴私相德也。 就而不用者策不得也，去而反求者事中来也。 谓所言当时未合，事过始骇，故日中来事。 日进前而不御者，施不合也； 遥闻声而相思者，合於谋待决事也。 谓所行合於己谋，待之以次其事，故曰遥闻声而相思也。 故日：不见其类而为之者见逆，不得其情而说之者见非。 言不得其情类而说之者，叉北辕适楚，陈秒游秦，所以见非逆也。 得其情，乃制其卫， 得其情，则鸿遇长风，鱼纵大壑，沛然莫之能御，故能制行其卫也。 此用可出可入，可挞可开。 此用者，谓其情也，则出入自由，挞开任意也。

「All affairs possess **inner harmony** (*nèijiàn*). Words may **draw near despite distance**, or **stay distant despite closeness**—hence, all affairs possess **inner harmony**. They are **bound** by **virtue/power** (*dé*) and **Dao/Way** (*lǜ*), or by **factional ties and wealth**, or by **beauty and favor**. **Binding** from their very **beginning**.

Some are **bound** by **virtue/power** and **Dao/Way**—when **Dao/Way** connects them to the **ruler and subject**, they are called **subjects** in name, but in reality, they are **masters**. When **Dao/Way** binds them through **friendship**, they are called **friends**—as seen in the case of **Guiguzi**’s disciples in *Ghost Valley Master’s Scrolls* (卷上). Those **bound** by **wealth** or **beauty**, like **Fei Zhong** and **E Lai** under **Jie** and **Jiu**, are of this kind.

They **utilize their own intentions**—if they wish to **enter**, they enter; if they wish to **exit**, they exit; if they wish to **draw near**, they draw near; if they wish to **stay distant**, they stay distant; if they wish to **approach**, they approach; if they wish to **depart**, they depart; if they wish to **seek**, they seek; if they wish to **ponder**, they ponder. The eight matters from **self-entering and self-exiting** downward are all in accordance with the **subject’s** intentions, following their own desires.

Thus, they can **steadfastly resolve their will** toward the **ruler**, and no external force can **intervene**. Like the **ant mother** (*yímǔ*) following its young—when it **exits**, there is no **trace**; when it **enters**, there is no **boundary**; it **goes alone and returns alone**, and none can **halt** it.

The **ant mother** (*yímǔ*), also called **locust mother** (*huánglà*), resembles a spider, dwelling in a **burrow** with a **cover**. It nurtures its young by covering the burrow’s entrance, and when it **exits and enters**, there is **no initial trace**—thus, nothing can **halt** it.

Now, the **subjects** of **inner harmony** (*nèijiàn*) **yield flexibly** to the **ruler**, **binding themselves securely** without **leaving any gaps**. This is also due to **inner harmony**.

The **inner harmony** (*nèi*) lies in **advancing persuasive speech**, while the **binding** (*jiàn*) lies in **securing their plans**. When persuasive speech is **advanced**, they **bind themselves internally** to the **ruler**. Hence, it is said that the **inner harmony** (*nèi*) lies in **advancing persuasive speech**.

They **weigh the situation** to **plan accordingly**—if the **ruler** does not **grasp** or **accept** their plans, they are **discarded**. Thus, it is said that the **binding** (*jiàn*) lies in **securing their plans**.

Those who wish to **persuade** must **conceal their true intentions** and **weigh the situation**; those who **plan** must **follow what is convenient**. If they **persuade** while **concealing their intentions**, their words **will succeed**. If they **plan** while **following convenience**, their plans **will be adopted**. Through **subtle deliberation** of **feasibility** and **open discussion** of **advantages and losses**, they **guide the ruler’s will**.

When **opportunities arise** and **timing is right**, they **align with the ruler’s plans**. *"Opportunity"* refers to the **Dao/Way unfolding**—when the **Dao/Way** **defends** and **advances**, their words **respond to the moment’s needs**, aligning with the **ruler’s** plans.

They **carefully consider** the **ruler’s** **binding** and **respond appropriately** to **timing**—when **planning** and **deliberating**, they **advance** to the **ruler**, securing their own position, and then **respond** to the **ruler’s** needs, ensuring their words **align with the ruler’s heart**.

If there is **internal discord**, it cannot be **implemented**. If their **plans** do not **align with the ruler’s**, they cannot be **executed**. Thus, they **probe the ruler’s current inclinations**, **adapt to what is convenient**, and **seek to change** their plans. When their **initial plans** prove unfit, they **reassess**, **adjust**, and **act according to the moment’s needs** to **alter their strategies**.

To **seek internal harmony** through **change**, they **employ the method of "taking with the tube"** (*guǎnqǔjiàn*). When they **take with the tube**, it **becomes distant**; when they **seek internal harmony** through **change**, it **becomes secure**. It is said that when **advancing**, they must **first use persuasive language**; when **responding**, they must **employ adaptable words**. If **past matters** are already **settled**, their words must **be persuasive**; if **future matters** have not yet **manifested**, their words must **be flexible**.

Those skilled in **change** thoroughly **know the terrain’s** (*dìshì*) **conditions**, thus **grasping the Dao/Way of heaven** (*tiān*). Knowing the **Dao/Way of heaven**, they **harmonize with the four seasons**, causing **ghosts and spirits** to **align with yin and yang**.

Those skilled in **change** refer to those who **master the principles** of **adaptable strategies**. Thoroughly **knowing the terrain’s** (*dìshì*) **conditions**, they can **grasp the Dao/Way of heaven**. Hence, it is said that they **thus grasp the Dao/Way of heaven**. Knowing the **Dao/Way of heaven**, they **follow the natural order** of the **four seasons**. Hence, it is said that they **harmonize with the four seasons**.

**Ghosts and spirits** are those that **assist yin and yang** in **nurturing life**. When the **Dao/Way** **unifies heaven and earth**, they can **cause ghosts and spirits** to **align in virtue** with **yin and yang**.

Thus, they can **nurture the people**. When they **observe the ruler’s** **plans and affairs**, they **know their intentions**.

Their **nurturing of the people** lies in **observing their plans and affairs** to **know their intentions**. If there are **plans that do not align**, it is because they are **unfamiliar**.

When they **align yet do not bind**, it is **yang** (*yang*) **drawing near externally** while **yin** (*yīn*) **stays distant internally**. There may be **separation and reunion** without **secure binding**—when **yang** (*yang*) **externally draws near**, while **yin** (*yīn*) **internally stays distant**.

If there are **plans that do not align**, the **Sage** will not **endeavor** them. *"Not align"* refers to **round holes for square pegs**; hence, the **Sage** will not **endeavor** such plans.

Thus, those who **draw near despite distance** possess **hidden virtue**; those who **stay distant despite closeness** lack **harmony of intent**. *"Hidden virtue"* refers to **private bonds** of **yin** (*yīn*).

Those who **approach yet are rejected** have **unfavorable strategies**; those who **depart yet return seeking** have **opportunities arising mid-affair**. It is said that when **words** do not **align with the moment**, and **affairs** are **settled only after realization**, it is because **opportunities arose mid-affair**.

Those who **advance yet do not approach** have **improper implementation**; those who **hear voices from afar yet ponder them in return** are **aligned with their plans** and **await decisive action**. It is said that when their **actions** **align with their own plans**, they **wait to execute them in sequence**, hence *"hear voices from afar yet ponder them in return"*.

Thus, it is said:
*"If one does not see their kind yet acts accordingly, they will meet with opposition; if one does not grasp their true intent yet persuades them, they will be met with disapproval."*

It is said that if one does not **grasp their true intent and kind**, yet **persuades them**, it is like **driving northward while facing south** or **Chen Xiao** traveling to **Qin**—thus, they will **meet with disapproval and opposition**.

If they **grasp their true intent**, they can **control their movements**—when they **encounter favorable winds**, like **swans** (*hóng*) or **fish** (*yú*) in **vast waters**, they **flow freely**, and none can **halt** them. Thus, they can **direct their actions** at will.

This **method** allows for **free entry and exit**, **secure binding or opening**. This **method** refers to **grasp of their true intent**—then **entry and exit** are **unrestricted**, and **binding or opening** are **as they wish**.

chunks.original_text: 故圣人立事，以此先知而挞万物。 言以得情立事，故能先知可否，万品所以结固而不离者，皆由得情也。 由夫道德仁义，礼乐计谋， 由夫得情，故能行其仁义道德以下事也。 先取《诗》、《书》，混说损益，议去论就。 混，同也。 谓先考《诗》、《书》之言，以同己说，然后损益时事，议论去就也。 欲合者用内，欲去者用外。 内谓情内，外谓情外。 得情自合，失情自去，此盖理之常也。 外内者必明道数，揣策来事，见疑诀之。 言善知内外者，爻明识道衍之数，预揣来事，见疑能次也。 策无失计，立功建德。 既能明道衍，故策无失计。 策无失计，乃可以立功建德也。 治民入产业，曰挞而内合。 理君臣之名，使上下有序。 入赋税之业，使远近无差。 上下有序，则职分明。 远近无差，则摇役简。 如此则为国之基。 故日挞而内合也。 上暗不治，下乱不寤，挞而反之。 上暗不治其任，下乱不寤其萌，如此天下无邦，域中旷主，兼昧者可行其事，侮己者由是而兴。 故日挞，而反之。 内向得而外不留，说而飞之。 言自贤之主，自以所行为得，而外不留贤者之说。 如此者，则为作声誉而飞扬之，以钓观其心也#17。 若命自来，己迎而御之， 君心既善，己叉自有命来召，己既迎而御之，以行其志。 若欲去之，因危与之。 翔而后集，意欲去之，因将危与之辞矣。 环转因化，莫之所为，退为大仪。 去就之际，反覆量宜，如员环之转，因彼变化，虽傍#18者莫知其所为，如是而退，可谓全身大仪。 仪者，法也。 抵职第四 抵，击实也。 织，衅隙也。 墙崩因隙器，坏因衅而击实之#19。 则墙器不败，若不可救，因而除之，更有所营，置人事亦由是也。 物有自然，事有合离。 此言合离，若#20乃自然之理。 有近而不可见，远而可知。 近而不可见者，不察其辞也； 远而可知者，反往以验来也。 察辞观行，则近情可见。 反往验来，则远事可知。 古，犹今也。 故反考往古，则可验来。 故日反往以验来。 铁者，坛也； 坛者，娴也； 娴者，成大隙也。 隙大，则崩毁将至，故宜有以抵之也。 织始有朕，可抵而塞，可抵而却，可抵而息，可抵而匿，可抵而得。 此谓抵铁之理也。 映者，隙之将兆，谓其微也。 自中成者可抵而塞，自外来者可抵而却，自下生者可抵而息，其萌微者可抵而匿，都不可治者可抵而得。 深知此五者，然后善抵帜之理也。 事之危也，圣人知之，独保其用，因化说事，通达计谋，以识细微。 形而上者谓之圣人，故危兆才形，朗然先觉，既明且哲。 故独保其用也。 因化说事，随机逞衍，通达计谋，以经纬，识细微而预防之也。 经起秋毫之末，挥之於太山之本。 汉高祖以布衣登皇帝位，殷汤由百里而驭万邦。 经，始也； 挥，动也。

The Sage establishes affairs by first knowing through this grasp of intent and thus controlling all things. It is said that by grasping intent to establish affairs, one can foresee what is favorable or not. All things, whether bound or unchanging, are thus rooted in grasping intent.

From the Way and virtue, to ren and righteousness, to rites and music, to strategies and schemes—all stem from grasping intent, enabling the practice of ren, righteousness, and virtue in all undertakings.

First, one examines the *Shijing* and *Shujing*, blending and adjusting interpretations, deliberating what to retain or discard. *Hun* means "to harmonize." This refers to first considering the words of the *Shijing* and *Shujing*, aligning them with one’s own reasoning, then adjusting and refining current affairs, debating what to accept or reject.

To unite, one employs the inner; to discard, the outer. *Inner* refers to intent within; *outer* refers to intent without. When intent is grasped, unity follows naturally; when intent is lost, separation ensues—this is the constant principle.

To discern inner and outer, one must master the Dao and its patterns, anticipating events through strategy, resolving doubts with precision. It is said that those skilled in inner and outer understanding perceive the unfolding of the Dao’s patterns, foresee events, and resolve doubts in sequence.

With no miscalculations in strategy, one establishes merit and builds virtue. Having mastered the Dao’s unfolding, one’s strategies are without error. Without error in strategy, one can then establish merit and build virtue.

To govern the people and manage resources, one must *control and harmonize inwardly*. To order the names of lord and subject, ensuring hierarchy is clear. To regulate taxes and labor, ensuring no disparity between near and far. When hierarchy is clear, duties are distinct. When disparity is absent, burdens are light. Thus, this becomes the foundation of a state. Hence, it is said: *control and harmonize inwardly*.

When the ruler is blind and ungoverned, the people are chaotic and unaware, one must *control and reverse* the situation. When the ruler neglects his duties and the people are unaware of their unrest, the world becomes a land without states, a realm without masters, and those in darkness may act as they please, while those who scorn you will rise. Hence, it is said: *control and reverse*.

When inner alignment is achieved and nothing is left externally, one may persuade and elevate. It is said that a virtuous ruler, confident in his actions, does not retain the praise of others. Such a one creates reputation and spreads it abroad, testing others’ intentions.

If one is summoned, one welcomes and responds. When the ruler’s heart is virtuous, if a summons comes, one greets and obeys it to fulfill one’s purpose. If one wishes to depart, one does so through calculated risk. Like birds that take flight before settling, one departs by offering perilous terms.

Through cyclical transformation and adaptation, no action is forced—this is the way of great propriety. At the juncture of departure or arrival, one weighs what is fitting, turning like a wheel, adapting to change. Though others may not perceive the intent, such retreat is the ultimate in preserving oneself and upholding propriety. *Propriety* is *law*.

**Chapter Four: Looming Collapse (Dǐ Zhí)**
*Dǐ* means to strike firmly; *zhí* refers to cracks and fissures. When walls collapse due to fissures, or structures fail due to hidden flaws, one must strike firmly to reinforce them. Thus, walls and structures will not fail. If ruin is inevitable, one removes it and rebuilds, placing people and affairs accordingly.

Things have their natural order; affairs have their unions and separations. This speaks of unions and separations as natural principles. Some things are near yet unseen, others far yet known. What is near yet unseen is due to not examining their words; what is far yet known comes from reflecting past events to judge the present.

By examining words and observing actions, one can perceive near intent. By reflecting past events to judge the present, one can foresee distant affairs. The past is like the present. Thus, by reviewing the past, one can verify the future. Hence, it is said: *reflect the past to judge the present*.

*Tie* is the altar; the altar is *xián*; *xián* is the beginning of great fissures. When fissures grow vast, collapse is imminent, so one must strike firmly to reinforce.

At the outset, cracks may be *loomed* (mapped) and sealed, struck to repel, struck to suppress, struck to conceal, or struck to resolve. This is the principle of *looming collapse*.

*Ying* refers to the emergence of fissures—its subtle beginnings. What arises internally can be sealed by striking; what comes externally can be repelled; what rises from below can be suppressed; what is nascent can be concealed; what is beyond remedy can be accepted. Deep understanding of these five aspects reveals the true logic of *looming collapse*.

When danger looms, the Sage perceives it, safeguarding their methods, adapting to transform affairs, mastering strategies and schemes to discern the subtle. The Sage operates beyond form—thus, when danger first appears, they are already aware, both clear and wise. Hence, they safeguard their methods.

By adapting to transform affairs, they respond to circumstances, mastering strategies and schemes to weave and measure, discerning the subtle to preemptively guard against it. From the finest hair’s breadth, they act to sway the roots of great mountains.

The Han Emperor Gaozu rose from humble origins to the imperial throne; Tang of the Shang ruled from a hundred li to govern all under heaven. *Jīng* is the beginning; *huī* is movement.

When the signs of external turmoil first emerge—conspiracies lurking like sprouting weeds—all such schemes arise from *dǐzhì* (抵帜), the strategic response to fissures in the Dao, serving as its defense. *[#21]*

When governance falters and external signs of chaos sprout—when rebellious plots begin to take root—sage counsel is invoked to devise strategy. *[#22]* This is because the art of *dǐzhì* lies in seizing these moments. Thus, when the fissures appear, the Way’s defense may be enacted. Hence it is said: *"To block the gap of the banner is to unfold the Way."*

When the realm fractures, with no enlightened ruler above and nobles lacking virtue, then schemers and traitors rise, the worthy are sidelined, the Sage exiled, and deceitful opportunists flourish. Rulers and ministers mislead one another, leading to collapse and mutual destruction—father and son turn against each other, estranged and hostile. This is called the *sprouting of rebellious seeds* (萌牙). Such is the *banner of chaos* (帜坛) for the state. *[伐射]* means to provoke conflict and strike one another.

When the Sage perceives the sprouting of rebellious seeds, they respond with law. If the age can be governed, they block it to seal it off; if not, they block it to seize it. Sometimes they block thus, sometimes they block otherwise—sometimes they counter it, sometimes they overturn it. To block thus is to seal it; to block otherwise is to seize it. To counter it is to aid its logic; to overturn it is to take the land by force.

The governance of the Five Emperors was sealed by blocking; the deeds of the Three Kings were seized by blocking. The Five Emperors’ rule could still be rectified in their time, hence *"blocking to seal it"*—thus the practice of abdication in favor of the worthy. The Three Kings’ era was beyond rectification, hence *"blocking to seize it"*—thus the wars of conquest.

When feudal lords clash, no single victory can be counted upon—at such times, the ability to block determines supremacy. *[This refers to the Age of the Five Hegemons, where dominance came from above.]*

From the union and separation of Heaven and Earth’s cyclical rise and fall, there must always be fissures in the banner—these cannot be ignored. *[合离]* refers to *Yin-Yang negation and affirmation*; the Dao’s true observation reveals that even Heaven and Earth have moments of negation and affirmation, creating these fissures—how much more so for humanity! Thus, it is said: *"These cannot be ignored."*

To discern them through *yáohé* (掉阖)—to wield this Way—is the mark of the Sage. *[牌阖]* is also negation and affirmation. Those who embody the Great Dao to govern human affairs are the Sage. The Sage is Heaven and Earth’s envoy, following humanity to serve the cosmic order—hence *"Heaven and Earth’s envoy."*

If no opportunity arises for blocking, they remain hidden, awaiting the moment. When the moment comes, they act. If it can be aligned with the above, if it can be restrained below—*aligning with the above* means blocking to seal, aiding the age’s governance; *restraining below* means blocking to seize, forcing submission to oneself. *[#23]*

To act in accordance and follow the Way is to guard the sacred essence of Heaven and Earth. *[#24]* Those who follow this Way may occupy the supreme position—thus, they guard the sacred essence of Heaven and Earth.

*(End of Ghost Valley Classic, Volume One)*

chunks.original_text: 飞，谓作声誉以飞扬之。 箝，谓牵持缄束令不得脱也。 言取人之道先作声誉以飞扬之，彼必露情竭志而无隐，然后因其所好牵持缄束令不得转移。 凡度权量能，所以征远来近。 几度其权略，量其村能，为远。 作声誉者所以征远而来近也。 谓贤者所在或远或近，以此征来，若燕昭尊郭魄，即其事也。 立势而制事，必先察同异，别是非之纽阁， 言远近既至，乃立赏罚之势，制能否之事。 事势既立，铃先察党与之同异，别言语之是非。 见内外之辞，知有无之数， 外谓浮虚。 ，内谓情实，有无谓道衍能否。 又铃见其情伪之辞，知其能否之数。 决安危之计，定亲疏之事。 既察同异，别是非，见内外，知有无，然后与之次安危之计，定亲疏之事则贤不肖可知也。 然后乃权量之，其有隐括，乃可征，乃可求，乃可用。 权之所以知其轻重，量之所以知其长短。 轻重既分，长短既形，乃施隐括以辅其曲直。 如此，则征之亦可，求之亦可，用之亦可。 引钩箝之辞，飞而箝之。 钩，谓诱致其情。 言人之材性各有差品，故钩箝之辞亦有等级。 故引钩箝之辞，内惑而得其情日钩，！ 外誉而得其情日飞。 得情即箝持之，令不得脱移，故日钩箝，故日飞钩箝。 钩箝之语，其说辞也，乍同乍异。 谓说钩箝之辞，或牌而同之，或合而异之，故日乍同乍异也。 其不可善者，或先征之而后重累， 不可善，谓钩箝之辞所不能动。 如此叉先命征召之。 重累者，谓其人既至，然后状其村所有。 其人既至，然后都状其村卫所有，知其所能，人或因此从化者也。 或先重以累而后毁之， 或有虽都状其所有，犹未从化，然后就其村衍短者訾毁之，人或过而从之，言不知化者也。 或以重累为毁，或以毁为重累。 或有状其所有，其短自形，此以重累为毁也。 或有历说其短，村卫便着，此以毁为重累也。 为其人难动，故或重累之，或訾毁之，所以驱诱令从化。 其用，或称财货、琦璋、珠玉、璧白、采色以事之， 其用，谓人既从化，将用之，铃先知其性行好恶，动以财货、采色者，欲知其人食康也。 或量能立势以钩之， 量其能之优劣，然后立去就之势，以钩其情，以知智谋。 或伺候见焖而箝之。 谓伺彼行事，见其娴#2而箝持之，以知其勇怯也。 其事用抵帜， 谓此上事用抵帜之衍而为之。 将欲用之天下，必度权量能，见天时之盛衰，制地形之广狭，蛆睑之难易，人民货财之多少，诸侯之交孰亲孰疏、孰爱孰憎。 将用之於天下，谓用飞箝之衍，辅於帝王。 度权量能，欲知帝王村能可辅成否。 天时盛衰，地形广狭，人民多少，又欲知天时地利人和，合其泰否。 诸侯之交，亲疏爱憎，又欲知从否之众寡。 心意之虑怀，审其意，知其所好恶，乃就说其所重，以飞箝之辞，钩其所好，以箝求之。 既审其虑怀，知其好恶，然后就其所最重者而说之。 又以飞箝之辞，钩其所好。 既知其所好，乃箝而求之。 所好不违，则何说而不行哉。 用之於人，则量智能，权材力，料气势，为之枢机，以迎之随之，以箝和之，以意宜之。 此飞箝之缀也。 用之於人，谓用飞箝之衍於诸侯也。 量智能，料气势者，亦欲知其智谋能否也。 枢，所以主门之动静，机所以主弩之放发。
