**"Fei" (Flying)** refers to raising one’s reputation to exalt and elevate it. **"Jian" (Clamping)** refers to restraining and binding so that they cannot escape.

The method of taking a person begins by raising their reputation to exalt them, and they will inevitably reveal their true intentions and exhaust their resolve without concealment. Only then can one, through their preferences, restrain and bind them so they cannot shift or turn.

In assessing talent and ability, the purpose is to summon those from afar and bring those nearby. By gauging their strategies and measuring their capacities—whether distant or near—one determines their potential. Raising their reputation is how one summons those from afar and brings those nearby.

For instance, when the virtuous are either distant or near, one employs this method to attract them, as in the case of King Zhao of Yan honoring Guo Ju, a matter of historical record.

To establish influence and control affairs, one must first discern distinctions and similarities, separating the threads of right and wrong. Once those from afar and near have arrived, one then establishes the authority of rewards and punishments, regulating the success or failure of their actions.

With the situation thus set, one must first examine the alliances and divisions—whether they align or oppose—and distinguish the truth or falsehood in their words. Observing their inner and outer expressions, one knows the presence or absence of their true capabilities. The outer refers to superficial appearances, the inner to genuine substance; presence or absence refers to the Dao’s unfolding of their abilities or failures.

Again, by observing their true or deceptive words, one discerns whether their capabilities are genuine or feigned. One then resolves matters of safety and peril, determining relationships of closeness and distance.

Having discerned distinctions, separated right from wrong, observed inner and outer expressions, and known presence or absence, one can then arrange matters of safety and peril, and settle affairs of closeness and distance—thus distinguishing the worthy from the unworthy.

Only then does one weigh and measure them. If they harbor hidden intentions, one can then summon, seek, and employ them. Weighing determines their lightness or heaviness; measuring determines their length or shortcoming. Once their lightness or heaviness is revealed, and their length or shortcoming takes form, one applies hidden strategies to aid their alignment or deviation.

Thus, whether summoning, seeking, or employing them becomes possible.

Using the words of **hook-and-clamp**, one flies and clamps them. **"Hook"** refers to luring and revealing their true nature. The talents and dispositions of people vary in rank, so the words of hook-and-clamp also have gradations.

Thus, when employing hook-and-clamp words, if one confuses them internally to reveal their true nature, it is called **hook**; if one praises them externally to reveal their true nature, it is called **fly**. Once their true nature is obtained, one clamps and restrains them so they cannot escape or shift—hence, **hook-and-clamp**, hence **flying hook-and-clamp**.

The language of hook-and-clamp is flexible, sometimes aligning, sometimes diverging. That is, when employing hook-and-clamp words, one may either feign agreement to unite them or feign opposition to separate them—hence, **sometimes aligning, sometimes diverging**.

If they cannot be swayed by this, one may first summon them and then impose burdens. **"Cannot be swayed"** means the hook-and-clamp words fail to move them. Thus, one first issues commands to summon them. **"Imposing burdens"** refers to, once they arrive, revealing their true capacities.

Once they arrive, one then fully reveals their true abilities and defenses, knowing what they can do—some may thus follow and transform. Or, one may first impose burdens and then disparage them. Some, even after revealing their true abilities, still do not follow and transform, so one then exposes their shortcomings to disparage them—those who err may thus follow, indicating they did not understand transformation.

Or, one may use imposing burdens as disparagement, or disparagement as imposing burdens. Some reveal their true abilities, yet their shortcomings become evident—this is using burdens as disparagement. Others, after detailing their shortcomings, are shamed into compliance—this is using disparagement as burdens.

Because they are difficult to move, one may either impose burdens or disparage them, driving and luring them into transformation.

In employing them, one may use wealth, treasures, jade, pearls, white jade, or adornments to serve them. **"Employing them"** means, once they have followed and transformed, one must first know their nature, habits, likes, and dislikes, then move them with wealth or adornments to test their loyalty.

Or, one may measure their abilities and establish influence to hook them—gauging their strengths and weaknesses, then setting the conditions of approach or withdrawal to hook their true nature and discern their intelligence and strategy.

Or, one may observe their actions, see their proficiency, and clamp them—meaning one watches their conduct, sees their skill, and restrains them to know their courage or cowardice.

In applying this method, one uses **blocking and signaling**—meaning these above methods are extensions of blocking and signaling.

When intending to employ them in the world, one must measure their abilities, observe the flourishing or decline of the times, assess the breadth or narrowness of the land, the difficulty or ease of the terrain, the abundance or scarcity of the people and resources, and the alliances of the feudal lords—who is close, who is distant, who is loved, who is hated.

**"Employing them in the world"** means applying the extensions of flying and clamping to assist the emperor. Measuring abilities determines whether the emperor’s capacities can be aided to completion. Observing the times’ flourishing or decline, the land’s breadth or narrowness, and the people’s abundance or scarcity further determines whether the harmony of Heaven, Earth, and humanity aligns with the age’s prosperity or adversity. Examining the feudal lords’ alliances—who is close, who is distant, who is loved, who is hated—further determines whether they will follow or oppose.

Having carefully considered their intentions and inclinations, one knows their likes and dislikes, then speaks to what they value most, using flying-and-clamping words to hook their desires and clamp them in pursuit.

Having carefully examined their intentions and inclinations, knowing their likes and dislikes, one then addresses what they hold most dear. Again, using flying-and-clamping words, one hooks their desires. Having known their desires, one clamps and seeks them. If their desires are not defied, what persuasion would they refuse?

When employing this on people, one measures their intelligence and abilities, weighs their talents and strength, gauges their qi and influence, and sets the pivotal mechanisms to welcome, follow, clamp, and harmonize them according to intent. This is the **continuation of flying and clamping**.

**"Employing this on people"** means applying the extensions of flying and clamping to the feudal lords. Measuring intelligence and abilities, gauging qi and influence also seeks to know their strategic capabilities.

chunks.original_text: 言既知其诸侯智谋能否，然后立法，镇其动静，制其放发，犹枢之於门，机之於弩，或先而迎之，或后而随之，皆箝其情以和之，用其意以宜之。 如此则诸侯之权可得，而执己之恩又得而固。 故日飞箝之缀也，谓用飞箝之衍连於人也。 用於人，则空往而实来，缀而不失，以究其辞，可箝而从，可箝而横，可引而束，可引而西，可引而南，可引而北，可引而反，可引而覆。 用於人，谓以飞箝之卫任使人也。 但以声誉扬之，故日空往。 彼则开心，露情归附於己，故日实来。 既得其情，爻缀而勿失。 又令敷奏以言，以究其辞。 如此，则从横束西南北。 反覆惟在己之箝引，无思不服。 虽覆能复，不失其度。 虽有覆败，铃能复振，不失其节度，此箝之终也。 作合第六 大道既隐，正道不得坦然而行，故将合於此，必作於彼，令其不疑，然后可行其意，即伊吕之去就是也。 凡趋合倍反，计有适合。 言趋合倍反，虽参差不齐，然后施之计谋，理乃适合。 化转环属，各有形势，反覆相求，因事为制。 言倍反之理，随化而转，如连环之属。 然其去就，各有形势，或反或覆。 理自相求，莫不因彼事情为之立制也。 是以圣人居天地之问，立身御世，施教扬声明名也，必因事物之会，观天时之宜，因之所多所少，以此先知之，与之转化。 所多所少，谓政教所宜多所宜少也。 既知多少所宜，然后为之增喊。 故曰以此先知。 谓用倍反之理知之也。 转化，谓转变以从化也。 世无常贵，事无常师。 能仁为贵，故无常贵。 立善为师，故无常师。 圣人常为无不为，所听无不听#3， 善爻为之，故无不为。 无稽之言不听，故无所听。 成於事而合於计，谋与之为主， 於事叉成，於谋又合。 如此者与众立之，推以为主也。 合於彼而离於此，计谋不两忠。 合於彼，叉离於此，是其忠谋不得两施也。 必有反杵，反於是，性於彼，杵於此，反於彼。 其术也， 既有#4不两施，宜行反件之卫。 反杵者意欲反合於此，铃行件於彼。 件者设疑其事#5，令昧者不知觉其事也。 用之天下，必量天下而与之； 用之国，必量国而与之； 用之家，必量家而与之； 用之身，必量身材能气势而与之。 大小进退，其用一也。 用之者，谓反性之衍。 量者，谓其事业有无。 与，谓与之亲。 几行件者，必称其事业所有而亲媚之，则暗主无从而觉，故得行其卫也。 所行之衍，虽有大小进退之异，然而至於称．事扬亲则一，故日其用一也。 必先谋虑计定，而后行之以飞箝之术。 将行反怖之衍，爻须先定计谋，然后行之，又用飞箝之衍以弥缝之。 古之善背向者，乃协四海，包诸侯性合之地而化转之，然后以之求合。 言古之深识背向之理者，乃合同四海，兼并诸侯，驱置件合之地，然后设法变化而转移之。 众心既从，乃求其真主而与之合也。 故伊尹五就汤，五就桀，然后合於汤； 吕尚三就文王，三入殷而不能有所明，然后合於文王。 伊尹所以就桀纣者，以性之令不疑，彼既不疑，然后得合於其真主矣。 此知天命之箝，故归之不疑也。 以天命系於殷、汤、文王，故二臣归二主不疑也。 非至圣人达奥不能衔世，非#6劳心苦思不能原事，不悉心见情不能成名，材质不惠不能用兵，忠实无真不能知人。

「Once one has discerned the strategic capabilities—both strengths and weaknesses—of the feudal lords, laws are then established to regulate their movements, as the pivot governs the door’s opening and closing, and the mechanism governs the firing of the crossbow. Sometimes one leads them by welcoming, sometimes follows by yielding, always restraining their emotions to harmonize them and guiding their intentions to suit one’s own purpose. Thus, the feudal lords’ loyalty can be secured, and the ruler’s favor can be firmly maintained.

This is called the **continuation of flying and clamping**—applying the extensions of flying and clamping to people. When used on people, it means sending out empty words while receiving sincere responses, binding them without losing them, and probing their speech to discern their true intent. They may comply with clamping, they may resist it, they may be drawn in or repelled, they may be guided east or west, south or north, or even turned back or overturned. Yet when used on people, it refers to deploying the **flying-and-clamping stratagem** to manipulate them. Only by spreading one’s reputation does this work—hence, "sending out empty words." They, in turn, open their hearts and reveal their true emotions, submitting to you—hence, "receiving sincere responses." Once their emotions are secured, they are bound by the **continuation of flying and clamping** and not abandoned. Further, by spreading their words and observing their speech, one can make them follow, resist, or be bound in any direction. Their reversal or overthrow lies solely in your clamping and guiding, for there is no thought that cannot be subdued. Though they may overturn, they can be restored, never losing their proper measure. Though they may falter or fail, the **flying-and-clamping stratagem** can recover and reassert them, never losing its rhythm and control—this is the **ultimate application of clamping**.

**The Sixth Principle: Unity in Opposition**
The Dao/Way being hidden, the proper path cannot proceed openly, so when one seeks to unite, one must first oppose. This ensures they have no doubt, allowing one to then carry out their intentions—just as the departure of Yi Yin and Lü Shang was the prelude to their unity.

In all cases of seeking unity through opposition, there must be a fitting strategy.
When one seeks unity through opposition, even if the responses are uneven, the application of strategy will make them align. Through transformation and adaptation, they follow suit, each with their own form and momentum, their reversals and overthrows interdependent, and measures established according to circumstances.
The principle of opposition is self-referential: it shifts with the transformation, like links in a chain. Yet their departures and arrivals each have their own patterns—some reverse, some overturn. The principle itself seeks alignment, and no matter the circumstances, measures are established accordingly.

Thus, the sage, positioned between heaven and earth, establishes their standing to govern the world, spreading teachings and proclaiming their name, always adapting to the confluence of circumstances and observing the suitability of the times. They consider what should be expanded or reduced, using this to foreknow and align with transformations. What should be expanded or reduced refers to the proper application of governance and teaching. Once knowing what must be expanded or reduced, one acts accordingly. Hence, "foreknow"—using the principle of opposition to understand.

**Transformation and Adaptation** refers to shifting and conforming to the changes of others.
The world has no fixed nobility, nor do matters have a fixed master.
Ren (benevolence) makes one noble, hence no fixed nobility.
Establishing virtue makes one a master, hence no fixed master.
The sage is always acting without fixed action, always listening without fixed listening—
By using the **continuation of flying and clamping**, they act without restraint.
They do not listen to baseless words, hence no fixed listening.

When matters are completed and strategies align, the sage takes the lead in guiding them.
In matters, they are already accomplished; in strategy, they are already harmonized.
Thus, they are established with the multitude as their leader.
When aligned with one and separated from another, loyalty cannot serve two masters.
When aligned with one but separated from another, their loyalty cannot be fully applied to both.
There must be **opposition through reversal**—
Reversing to this, nature to that, and then reversing again to that.
Its method is this:
Since loyalty cannot be fully applied to both, it is proper to employ the **stratagem of reversal and fear** to manipulate them.

**Reversal and Opposition** means reversing to unite with this, then acting to oppose that.
To act through reversal means to create doubt in their affairs, so that the confused cannot perceive the truth.

When deploying this across the world, one must measure the world and align with it;
When deploying this within a state, one must measure the state and align with it;
When deploying this within a family, one must measure the family and align with it;
When deploying this in personal conduct, one must measure one’s own abilities, strength, and influence, and align with them.
Great or small, advance or retreat—its use remains consistent.
When deploying this, it refers to the extension of opposition.
To measure means to assess the presence or absence of their circumstances.
To align means to cultivate their favor.
Before executing the **stratagem of reversal**, one must first affirm their circumstances and curry their favor, then the hidden ruler will have no way to perceive or awaken, thus allowing the deployment of the **stratagem of reversal** to succeed.

Though the extensions of its application may vary in scale—great or small, advance or retreat—yet when one properly affirms their circumstances and cultivates their favor, it remains consistent in use, hence "its use remains consistent."

One must first deliberate on strategy and define plans before executing them with the **flying-and-clamping stratagem**. When deploying the **extension of reversal and fear**, one must first establish the strategy and plans, then execute them, again using the **flying-and-clamping stratagem** to reinforce and fill the gaps.

The ancients who mastered the art of opposition and reversal
Unified the Four Seas, encompassed the feudal lords’ loyalty, and transformed the land of unity—then sought to align.
Those who deeply understood the principle of opposition and reversal
Unified all under heaven, united the feudal lords, and drove them to the land of unity—then employed methods to transform and shift them.
Once their hearts were aligned, they sought their true ruler and united with them.
Hence, Yi Yin five times approached Tang, five times approached Jie, before uniting with Tang;
Lü Shang three times approached King Wen, three times entered Yin, yet could not clarify his purpose—before uniting with King Wen.
Yi Yin approached Jie and Zhou because their nature demanded no doubt, and since they had no doubt, he could then unite with their true ruler.
This is the **clamping of heavenly command**, hence their submission without doubt.
Heavenly command was tied to Yin, Tang, and King Wen, so the two ministers submitted to the two rulers without doubt.
Without the utmost sage reaching the depths of the Dao/Way, one cannot govern the world;
Without laboring over the mind and exhausting thought, one cannot fathom matters;
Without fully attending to emotions and discerning truth, one cannot establish reputation;
Without refined talent and virtue, one cannot wield armies;
Without genuine sincerity, one cannot know people.»

chunks.original_text: 故性合之道，己必自度材能，知睿量长短，远近孰不如， 夫件合之道，不能行於胜己，而叉用之於不我若，故知谁不如，然后行之也。 乃可以进，乃可以退，乃可以纵，乃可以横。 既行件合之道於不如己者，则进退纵横唯吾所欲耳。 揣篇第七 古之善用天下者，必量天下之权而揣诸侯之情。 量权不审不知强弱轻重之称，揣情不审不知隐匿变化之动静。 何谓量权，曰度於大 小，谋於众寡，称货财之有无。 古之善用天下者，必量天下之权而揣诸侯之情。 量权不审，不知强弱轻重之称。 揣情不审，不知隐匿变化之动静。 何谓量权。 日度於大小，谋於众寡｀，称货财有无之数，料人民多少#7，饶乏有余，不足几何，辨地形之险易孰利孰害，谋虑孰长孰短，君臣之亲疏孰贤孰不肖，与宾客之知睿孰少孰多，观天时之祸福孰吉孰凶，诸侯之亲孰用孰不用，百姓之心去就变化孰安孰危，孰好孰憎。 反侧，孰便#8能知。 如此者，是谓权量。 天下之情叉见於权也，善修量权，其情可得而知之。 知其情而用之者，何适而不可哉。 揣情者，必以其甚喜之时往而极其欲也。 其有欲也，木能隐其情，必以其甚惧之时往而极其恶也。 其有恶也，不能隐其情，情欲必失#9其变。 夫人之性甚喜则所欲着，甚惧则所恶彰。 故因其彰着而往极之。 恶欲既极，则其情不隐。 是以情欲因喜惧之变而失#10也。 感动而不知其变者，乃且错其人勿与语，而更问所亲，知其所安。 虽因喜惧之时以欲恶感动，尚不知其变。 如此者乃且置其人无与之语，徐徐更问斯人之所亲，则其情欲所安可知也。 夫情变於内者，形见於外。 故常必以其见者而知其隐者，此所谓测探揣情。 夫情貌不差，内变者铃见外貌。 故常以其外见而知其内隐。 观色而知情者，铃用此道。 此所谓测深揣情也。 故计国事者，则当审权量。 说人主，则当审揣情。 谋虑情欲，必出於此。 审权量，则国事可计，审揣情，则人主可说。 至於谋虑情欲，皆揣而后行，故曰谋虑情欲，又出於此也。 乃可贵，乃可贱，乃可重，乃可轻，乃可利，乃可害，乃可成，乃可败，其数一也。 言审於揣衍，则贵贱成败唯己所制，无非揣衍所为，故日其数一也。 故虽有先王之道，圣智之谋，非揣情，隐匿无所索之。 此谋之大本也，而说之法也。 先王之道，圣智之谋，虽弘旷玄妙，若不兼揣情之衍，则彼之隐匿从何而求之。 然则揣情者，乃成谋之本而说之法制也#11。 常有事於人，人莫先事而至，此最难为。 挟揣情之衍者，叉包独见之明，故有事於人，人莫能先也。 又能穷几尽#12变，故先事而至。 自非体玄极妙，则莫能为此矣。 故日此难为者也。 故曰揣情最难守司，言必时其谋虑。 人情险於山川，难於知天。 今欲揣度而守司之，不亦难乎。 故日揣情最难守司。 谋虑出於人情，爻当知其时节，此其所以最难也。 故观绢飞蠕动，无不有利害，可以生事。 美生事者，几之势也。 绢飞蠕动，微虫耳，亦犹怀利害之心。 故顺之则喜悦，逆之则勃怒，况於人乎，况於鬼神乎。 是以利害者理所不能无，顺逆者事之所铃行。 然则招利，逆之政害，理之常也。 观此可以成生事之美。 生事者铃审几微之势，故日：生事者几之势也。

「Thus, the **Way of harmonizing nature**, one must first assess one’s own talents and abilities, understanding the strengths and weaknesses of one’s **sagely discernment** and **long-term vision**—whether near or distant, who is superior and who is inferior.

The **Way of harmonizing** cannot be applied to those who surpass oneself, but rather to those who do not. Hence, one must know who is inferior before acting. Only then can one advance, retreat, expand, or contract. Once the **Way of harmonizing** is applied to those inferior to oneself, then advancement, retreat, expansion, and contraction are solely as one desires.

**Chapter Seven: *Assessing Power and Discerning Emotions***
The ancient masters who excelled in governing the world would measure the **power** of the world and discern the emotions of the feudal lords. If they did not carefully measure **power**, they would not know the distinctions between strength and weakness, weight and lightness. If they did not carefully discern emotions, they would not know the hidden shifts and changes in their movements and stillness.

What is meant by measuring **power**? It is to gauge the scale of greatness and smallness, to strategize based on the multitude or scarcity of forces, and to evaluate the presence or absence of wealth and resources. The ancient masters who excelled in governing the world would measure the **power** of the world and discern the emotions of the feudal lords. If they did not carefully measure **power**, they would not know the distinctions between strength and weakness, weight and lightness. If they did not carefully discern emotions, they would not know the hidden shifts and changes in their movements and stillness.

Measuring **power** means:
- Gauging the scale of greatness and smallness,
- Strategizing based on the multitude or scarcity of forces,
- Evaluating the presence or absence of wealth and resources,
- Calculating the abundance or scarcity of the populace,
- Assessing whether there is surplus or deficit, and by how much,
- Determining the advantages and disadvantages of terrain—whether it is perilous or easy,
- Evaluating the strengths and weaknesses of strategic planning,
- Distinguishing the merit or demerit of ministers—whether they are virtuous or unworthy,
- Judging the wisdom or lack thereof among guests and allies,
- Observing the auspicious or inauspicious signs of Heaven’s timing,
- Deciding which feudal lords to engage and which to disregard,
- Measuring the stability or danger of the people’s hearts—whether they incline toward or away from you,
- And whether they love or hate you.

Through careful observation, one can discern what is convenient. Thus, one can know their emotions. If one does this, their emotions can be understood, and no matter the situation, one can act accordingly.

**Discerning emotions** requires approaching them when their desires are most pronounced to fully explore their cravings. When they have cravings, even a **wooden** figure cannot conceal their emotions. One must then approach them when their fears are most intense to fully explore their aversions. When they have aversions, they cannot conceal their emotions. Emotions and desires will inevitably reveal their changes.

If one is moved by their emotions yet does not perceive these changes, then one should avoid speaking to them and instead question those close to them, to know where their comfort lies. Even if one approaches them during moments of joy or fear to probe their desires and aversions, one may still not know their changes. Thus, one should avoid speaking to them and gradually question those close to them, and their true desires and comforts can then be known.

Emotions that change within are reflected in outward appearance. Therefore, one must always use what is visible to infer what is hidden—this is called **probing and discerning emotions**. Emotions and outward expressions never diverge; internal changes are always mirrored in external appearance. Thus, one must always use outward appearance to infer internal emotions.

Those who observe facial expressions to discern emotions are indeed employing this **Way**. This is called **probing the depths and discerning emotions**.

Therefore, when calculating state affairs, one must carefully assess **power**. When advising a ruler, one must carefully discern emotions. Strategic planning and understanding emotions and desires must emerge from this. If one carefully assesses **power**, then state affairs can be calculated; if one carefully discerns emotions, then one can advise the ruler.

As for strategic planning and understanding emotions and desires, all must be discerned before action is taken. Hence, it is said that strategic planning and understanding emotions and desires also emerge from this.

Then one can determine what is precious or worthless, what is weighty or light, what is advantageous or harmful, what can succeed or fail—all depend on this. If one is precise in **discerning and probing**, then preciousness, worthlessness, success, and failure are all determined by oneself, with nothing outside of **discerning and probing**. Hence, it is said that all depends on this.

Thus, even with the **Way** of the ancient sages and the sagely strategies of the wise, without **discerning emotions**, one cannot uncover the hidden and concealed. This is the fundamental principle of strategy and the method of persuasion. The **Way** of the ancient sages and the sagely strategies of the wise, though vast and profound, mysterious and wondrous, if not combined with the **probing of emotions**, then how can one seek their hidden and concealed aspects?

Therefore, **discerning emotions** is the root of successful strategy and the foundation of persuasion.

There are always matters concerning people, yet people cannot anticipate these matters before they arise—this is the most difficult to achieve. Those who wield the **probing of emotions** also possess the insight of **unique perception**, hence they can anticipate matters concerning people before anyone else.

They can also exhaust all possibilities and perceive all changes, thus anticipating matters before they arise. Without embodying the profound and mastering the mysterious, none can achieve this. Hence, it is said that this is the most difficult to achieve.

Therefore, it is said that **discerning emotions** is the most difficult to master and govern, meaning one must always time their strategic planning. Human emotions are more treacherous than mountains and rivers, and more difficult to fathom than Heaven’s workings. Now, if one wishes to **discern and govern** them, is it not difficult?

Hence, it is said that **discerning emotions** is the most difficult to master and govern. Strategic planning arises from human emotions; one must know their timing and rhythms. This is why it is the most difficult.

Therefore, even the slightest movement of a silkworm—just a tiny insect—contains the potential for advantage or harm, and can give rise to matters. The beauty of **generating affairs** lies in seizing these subtle opportunities. The silkworm’s slight movements are but a humble creature, yet they still carry the seeds of advantage or harm. Thus, if one follows them, they bring joy; if one opposes them, they provoke anger. How much more so with humans, how much more so with ghosts and spirits?

Therefore, advantage and harm are inevitable in affairs, and following or opposing them is the natural course of events. Hence, to invite advantage and avoid harm is the constant principle. Observing this can lead to the beauty of **generating affairs**.

**Generating affairs** lies in carefully assessing subtle opportunities—hence, it is said that the beauty of **generating affairs** lies in seizing these subtle opportunities.»

「This is the art of **divining emotions** and **adapting speech**, crafting discourse only after assessing the situation.

Once the emotions are divined, speech is then refined and followed accordingly—thus, it is said that **adapting speech** must first be shaped into discourse before it can be applied. In the eighth chapter of *The Art of War*, **"Divining"** is the **oath**#13 of the inner strategy. **"Divining"** refers to the one who assesses the emotions and then aligns with their desires.

Hence, **"Divining"** is the extension of **assessing**. The inner **oath** means that emotions and desires stir within, while their manifestations appear externally. **"Divining"** is the act of perceiving these external signs and inferring the inner emotions. Therefore, it is said: **"Oaths"** are the foundation of **divining**.

When employing **divining**, there must be a **Way**. That **Way** must remain concealed.
**Divining** is the means to gauge their emotional inclinations;
**Adapting** is the means to stimulate and align with their inner **oaths**.
To use **divining and adapting**, one must first establish the principle.
Thus, it is said: *"When employing it, there must be a **Way**."*

Then, to measure emotions by emotions, emotions being inherently subtle and concealed, it is said: *"That **Way** must remain hidden."*

By **adapting subtly**, one tests and probes their desires, and the inner **oaths** will surely respond. When they respond, they will inevitably act as desired.
Once the emotions are divined and their inclinations known, one then **adapts subtly** to their desires, and when their desires are met, emotions will surely stir.
Testing and probing them, thus the inner **oaths** will respond.

So, when the **oaths** respond, one must withdraw subtly to fulfill their intended actions.
This is called **blocking fate and concealing intent**, hiding one’s true appearance and evading emotions so that others remain unaware—thus, one’s plans succeed without misfortune.

The ruler, having already determined the actions, can then **adapt** to fulfill them.
The minister’s affairs are best when left **unseen**, for completion brings an end—thus, one withdraws subtly.
If one does not align with this strategy, the credit for success will go to the ruler.
This is akin to **blocking fate and concealing intent**, **hiding appearance and evading emotions**.

When emotions are concealed and intent is blocked, how can others know?
If others do not know the means by which one **restrains** their borrowed ruin, then one’s affairs can be completed without **restraint**.

**"Divining"** lies here, **"oaths"** lie there—aligning and responding to them, there is no affair that cannot be accomplished.
This **adapting** is so subtle, yet its effects are naturally evident.
The observer sees only the results and not the subtlety itself.
Thus, when employing this method, success is assured—there is no affair that cannot be accomplished.

The ancient masters of **adapting** were like those who cast a hook into the depths—baiting it and hiding the line, they were sure to catch the fish.
Hence, it is said: *"The ruler completes affairs without others knowing, conquers battles without others fearing."*

The fisherman reveals the bait but conceals the hook—thus, the fish does not see the bait, yet the hook is obtained.
The **virtuous** observe the results of their actions but conceal their **adapting**—thus, others do not know, yet they are naturally swayed.
Therefore, it is said: *"The ruler completes affairs without others knowing."*

Victory in battle stems from **adapting** well—when **adapting** is concealed, there is no source from which to fear, hence it is said: *"The ruler conquers battles without others fearing."*

The **Sage** plans in secrecy, hence it is called **mysterious** (*shen*);
They accomplish it openly, hence it is called **illuminated** (*ming*).
**Mysterious** planning is concealed and hidden, daily actions unknown—like the **Dao/Way**’s inscrutable path, hence it is called **mysterious**.
When affairs are completed and plans fulfilled, their brilliance shines clearly—hence it is called **illuminated**.

So, the saying *"The ruler completes affairs without others knowing"* means they do not see the means of advantage, yet they recognize the **Way**;
*"The ruler conquers battles without others fearing"* means they trust the **Way** and are unaware of the reasoning behind it—hence, they liken it to **mysterious and illuminated** (*shenming*).

The **Sage** embodies the **Dao/Way** and establishes teachings, harmonizing with Heaven and Earth to effect transformations. They **conceal** their brilliance and **hide** their paths, **reserving** their actions while **displaying** their **virtue**.
Thus, people cannot comprehend their **borrowed ruin** (*shen*), yet they follow the **Dao/Way** without knowing its reasoning—hence, they liken it to **mysterious and illuminated**.

Constantly waging war through **non-contention** (*buzheng*), they **restrain** disaster within their own hearts and minds, using **non-contention** as their method of war.
No armies are raised—**virtue** flows naturally, and the people are all unaware of the reasoning behind their **fearlessness**.
One **adapts** with their anger;
One **adapts** with their balance, one **adapts** with their rectitude—」

chunks.original_text: 有以喜，有有以名，有以行； 有以廉，有以； 有以利，有以卑。 几此十者，皆摩之所由而发村性参差息盈虚，怒者积德也积善也，禁邪於未萌，故玄风遐扇故不知所以服，比之於神明。 事务变化。 故摩者亦消因几而动之。 静也； 正者动也； 名者而民安之而民道之故国用不功成事言人之直#14也； 喜者，悦发也； 行者，成也； 廉者，洁也； 信者，明#15也； 利者，求也； 卑者，谄也。 名贵发扬，故日发也。 行贵成功，故日成也。 故圣人所独用者，众人皆有之，然无成功者，其用之非也。 言上十事圣人独用，以为摩而能成功立事，然众人莫不有之#16。 所陕用之、非道不能成#17。 故谋莫难於周密，说莫难於悉听，事莫难於必成。 此三者，唯圣人#18然后能之。 谋不周密，则失溪而害成。 说不悉听，则违顺而生疑。 事不叉成，则止篑而有废。 皆有所难能任之而无难者，其唯圣人乎。 故谋必欲周密，必择其所与通者说也。 故曰：或结而无隙也。 为通者说谋铃虚受，如受石投水，开流而纳泉。 如此，则何隙而可得。 故日．一结而无隙也。 夫事成必合於数，故日道数与时相偶者也。 夫谋成又先考合於衍数，故道衍时三者相偶合，然后事可成而功业可立也。 说者听必合於情，故曰情合者听。 进说而能令听者，其唯情合者乎。 故物归类，抱薪趋火，燥者先燃； 平地注水，湿者先濡。 此物类相应於势，譬犹是也。 此言内符之应外摩也如是。 言内符之应外摩，得类则应，譬犹水流就湿，火行就燥也。 故日摩之以其类焉，有不相应者； 乃摩之以其欲焉，有不听者。

「One **adapts** with their joy,
One **adapts** with their reputation, one **adapts** with their deeds;
One **adapts** with their integrity, one **adapts** with their **virtue**;
One **adapts** with their profit, one **adapts** with their humility.

These ten aspects of **non-contention** (*buzheng*) are all ways to **stir** (*mó*) the people’s **varying** (*cānchā*) **nature** (*xìng*), their **breathing** (*qì*) of **fullness** and **emptiness**.
Those who **adapt** with their anger accumulate **virtue** and **power** (*shàn*), restraining evil before it sprouts—
Thus, the **Dao/Way’s** subtle winds spread far and wide,
And the people remain **unaware** of why they submit—
They liken it to **mysterious and illuminated**.

Matters shift and change.
Thus, those who **stir** (*mó*) must also **adapt** to the **factors** (*qǐ*) that move them.

The **still** (*jìng*) is **non-contention** (*buzheng*);
The **rectified** (*zhèng*) is **adaptation** (*mó*).
**Reputation** (*míng*) is **adapted** to ensure the people are at ease and follow—
Thus, the state’s affairs are accomplished without effort.
**Joy** (*xǐ*) is **adapted** to bring delight;
**Deeds** (*xíng*) are **adapted** to achieve completion;
**Integrity** (*lián*) is **adapted** to bring purity;
**Trust** (*xìn*) is **adapted** to bring clarity.
**Profit** (*lì*) is **adapted** to seek gain;
**Humility** (*bēi*) is **adapted** to flatter.

**Reputation** (*míng*) must be **exalted** and **promoted**—
Hence, it is called **exaltation** (*fā*).
**Deeds** (*xíng*) must be **completed**—
Hence, it is called **completion** (*chéng*).

Thus, what the **Sage** (*shèngrén*) uses alone,
Others also possess,
Yet none achieve success—
Their use is incorrect.

It is said that the **Sage** alone **adapts** these ten matters,
Using **non-contention** (*buzheng*) to achieve success and establish affairs,
Yet common people all have them as well.

If their use is **borrowed ruin** (*shen*), not the **Dao/Way**—
Then success cannot be attained.

Thus, **planning** is most difficult when it must be **thorough**,
**Persuasion** is most difficult when it must be **fully heard**,
And **affairs** are most difficult when they must be **certainly completed**.

These three challenges—
Only the **Sage** (*shèngrén*) can then accomplish them.

If **planning** is not **thorough**,
Then the **opportunity** (*xī*) is lost, and the **endeavor** (*chéng*) is harmed.
If **persuasion** is not **fully heard**,
Then **harmony** (*shùn*) is defied, and **doubt** (*yí*) arises.
If **affairs** are not **cross-completed** (*cházhéng*),
Then **work is abandoned midway** (*zhǐzhuì*), and **ruin** (*fèi*) follows.

All these are difficult for others to bear,
Yet none find difficulty in them—
Only the **Sage** can do so.

Thus, **planning** must be **thorough**,
And **persuasion** must be **fully heard**—
One must **choose** those with whom they can **communicate** (*tōng*) to speak.

Hence, it is said:
*"Some bonds are sealed without gaps."*

To those who can **communicate** (*tōng*), one **adapts** their **planning**—
**Receiving** (*shòu*) it as **empty** (*xū*), like water receiving a stone,
Opening currents to **harbor** (*nà*) springs.
Thus, no gaps can be found—
Hence, it is said:
*"One bond is sealed without gaps."*

If **affairs** are to be **completed**,
They must **align** with **fate** (*shù*).
Thus, it is said:
*"The **Dao/Way** of **fate** (*shù*) and **timing** (*shí*) must **correspond** with **fortune** (*yǎnshù*)."*

If **planning** is to succeed,
It must first **consider** aligning with **fortune** (*yǎnshù*).
Thus, the **Dao/Way** of **fortune** (*yǎnshù*), **timing** (*shí*), and **fate** (*shù*) must all **correspond**—
Then **affairs** can be **completed**, and **achievements** (*gōngyè*) can be **established**.

If **persuasion** is to be **heard**,
The **listener** must **align** with their **sentiments** (*qíng*).
Thus, it is said:
*"The **listener** must **align** with their **sentiments** (*qíng*)."*

To **advance** (*jìn*) **persuasion** and ensure it is **heard**—
Only those who **align** with **sentiments** can do so.

Thus, **things** return to their **kindred** (*lèi*).
Carrying wood toward fire,
The **dry** (*zào*) ignites first;
Pouring water on level ground,
The **moist** (*shī*) is first **soaked**.

This is how **things** of the same **kindred** (*lèi*) **respond** to **circumstances** (*shì*).
It is like this as well.

This speaks of the **inner resonance** (*nèifú*) **responding** to **external adaptation** (*wàimó*).

If **kindred** (*lèi*) is **obtained** (*dé*), then **response** (*yìng*) follows—
Like water flowing to the **moist** (*shī*), fire advancing to the **dry** (*zào*).

Thus, it is said:
*"**Adapt** with their **kindred** (*lèi*)—
Yet if there are those who do not **respond**,
Then one must **adapt** with their **desires** (*yù*)—
Yet if there are those who do not **listen** (*tīng*)."*

chunks.original_text: 故曰独行之道。 善於摩者其唯圣人乎。 故日独行之道者也。 夫几者不晚，成而不抱，久而化成。 见几而作，何晚之有。 功成不拘，何抱之久。 行此二者可以化天下。 权篇第九 说之者说之也，说之者资之也。 说者，说之於彼人也。 说之者，有资於彼人也。 资，取也。 饰言者假之也，假之者益损也。 说者所以文饰言语，但假借以求入於彼，非事要也。 亦既假之，须有损益。 故日假之者损益之谓也。 应对者利辞也，利辞者#19轻论也。 谓彼有所问，卒应而对之者，但便利辞也。 辞务便利，故所论之事自然利辞，非至言也#20。 成义者明之也，明之者符验也。 窍实事务以成义理者，欲明其真伪也。 真伪既明，则符验自着。 故日明之者#21符验也。 言或反覆，欲相却也。 难言者却论也，却论者钓几也。 言或不合，反覆相难，所以却论前事也。 却论者，铃理精而事明，几微可得而尽矣。 故日却论者钓几也。 求其深微，日钓也。 佞言者谄而于忠， 馅者，先意承欲，以求忠名，故日馅而于忠。 谀言者博而于智， 博者，繁称文辞，以求智名，故日博而于智。 平一黄者央而于勇， 次者，纵舍不疑，以求勇名，故曰次而于智。 戚言者权而于信， 戚者，忧也，谓象忧戚而陈言也。 权者，策选进谋，以求信名，故日权而于信。 静言者反而于胜。 静言者，谓象清净而陈言。 反者，先分不足以窒非，以求胜名，故日反而于胜。 先意成欲者谄也，繁称文辞者博也，策选进谋者权也，纵舍不宜者央也，先分不足而窒非者反也。 己实不足，不自知而内讼，而反攻人之过，窒他谓非，如此者反也。 故口者几关也，所以闭情意也； 耳目者心之佐助也，所以窥问见奸邪。 故曰：参调而应，利道而动。 口者所以发言语，故曰口者机关也。 情意宜否在於机关，故日所以关闭情意也。 耳目者所以助心通理，故日心之佐助也。 心得耳目，即能窥见问隙，见彼奸邪，故日窥问见奸邪。 耳心目三者调和而相应感，则动铃成功，吉无不利。 其所无不利者#22，则以颇道而动。 故日参调而应，利道而动者也。 故击言而不乱，翱翔而不迷，变易而不危者，观要得理。 苟能睹要得理，便可曲成不失。 故虽系言纷葩不乱，输翔越越不迷，变易改常而不危者也。 故无目者不、可示以五色，无耳者不可告以五音。 五色为有目者施，故无目不可得而示其五色。 五音为有耳者作，故无耳不可得而告其五音。 此二者为下文分也。 故不可以往者无所开之也，不可以来者无所受之也。 物有不通者，圣人#23故不事也。 此不可以往说於彼者，为彼暗滞无所可开也。 彼所不来说於此者，为此浅局无所可受也。 夫浅局之与暗滞，常闭塞而不通，故圣人不事也。 古人有言日：口可以食，不可以言。 言者，有讳忌也。 众口烁金，言有曲故也。 口食可以肥百体，故可食也。 言或可以招百殃，故不可以言也。 言者触忌讳，故日有忌讳也。 金为坚物，众口能烁之，则以众口有私曲故也。 故日言有曲故也。 人之情，出言则欲听，举事则欲成。 可听在於合彼，可成在於顺理。 此为下起端也。 是故智者不用其所短而用愚人之所长，不用其所拙而用愚人之所工，故不困也。 智者之短不胜愚人之长，故用愚人之长也。

The **Way** of solitary action.
Only those skilled in **adaptation** (*mó*) could be the **Sage**.
Thus, the **Way** of solitary action is as such.

The **opportune** (*jǐ*) is never too late—
When accomplished, it is not clung to;
When enduring, it transforms naturally.
To act upon the **opportune**—what tardiness could there be?
When the deed is done, it is not constrained—
What lingering could there be?

Practicing these two can transform the world.

**Chapter Nine: The Art of Persuasion**
The one who persuades does so by **endowing** (*zī*).
The persuader **endows** the other.
**Endowing** means **taking** (*qǔ*).
**Embellishing speech** is a **borrowing** (*jiǎ*)—
**Borrowing** means **augmenting or diminishing** (*yì*).

The persuader **embellishes** speech to **appease** the other,
Yet it is not the **essence** of the matter.
Since it is **borrowed**, there must be **augmentation or diminution**.
Thus, **borrowing** means **augmenting or diminishing**.

The **responder** uses **convenient words**—
**Convenient words** are **light discourse** (*qīnglùn*).
When asked, one **responds** and **replies**—
Yet it is merely **convenient words**.
Since words seek **convenience**, the discussed matter naturally becomes **light discourse**,
Not **true speech** (*zhìyán*).

The **completer of meaning** **clarifies**—
**Clarifying** means **verification**.
Examining **substantial matters** to establish **principles**,
Seeking to **verify** truth and falsehood.
Once truth and falsehood are **clarified**, **verification** naturally follows.
Thus, **clarifying** means **verification**.

When words **contradict**, it is to **repel**—
**Difficult speech** is **repelling discourse**—
**Repelling discourse** is **fishing for the opportune** (*diào jǐ*).
When words do not align, they **contradict and challenge**,
Thus **repelling** prior discourse.
**Repelling discourse**—
When logic is **precise** and matters **clear**, the **subtle** can be fully **exhausted**.
Thus, **repelling discourse** is **fishing for the opportune**.

To seek the **profound and subtle**, it is called **fishing**.

**Flattering speech** is **sycophantic yet claims loyalty**—
**Stuffing** (*xiàn*) means **anticipating intent** to fulfill desires,
Seeking the name of **loyalty**, hence **sycophantic yet claims loyalty**.

**Flattering words** are **verbose yet claim wisdom**—
**Verbose** means **prolific in rhetoric** to seek the name of **wisdom**, hence **verbose yet claim wisdom**.

**Bold speech** is **reckless yet claims courage**—
**Reckless** means **unhesitating abandonment**, seeking the name of **courage**, hence **reckless yet claims courage**.

**Mournful speech** is **scheming yet claims sincerity**—
**Mournful** means **feigning sorrow** in speech.
**Scheming** means **strategizing and advancing counsel** to seek the name of **sincerity**, hence **scheming yet claims sincerity**.

**Calm speech** is **contradictory yet claims victory**—
**Calm speech** means **feigning purity** in speech.
**Contradictory** means **prematurely denying** to **block the false**, seeking the name of **victory**, hence **contradictory yet claims victory**.

**Anticipating intent to fulfill desires** is **sycophancy**,
**Prolific in rhetoric** is **verbosity**,
**Strategizing and advancing counsel** is **scheming**,
**Unhesitating abandonment** is **recklessness**,
**Prematurely denying to block the false** is **contradiction**.

When one’s **true self** is insufficient,
Yet **unaware**, they **internally dispute**,
And **counterattack** others’ faults,
**Blocking** others’ objections—
This is **contradiction**.

Thus, the **mouth** is the **mechanism**—
It **closes** emotions and intentions;
The **ears and eyes** are the **auxiliaries** of the **heart**—
They **spy** on questions and **expose deceit**.

Thus it is said:
**Harmonize the three** and **respond**,
**Benefit the Dao** and **act**.
The **mouth** is for **uttering speech**, hence the **mechanism**.
Emotions and intentions depend on the **mechanism**, hence **closing** them.
The **ears and eyes** assist the **heart** in **understanding principles**, hence **auxiliaries**.
When the **heart** uses **ears and eyes**, it can **spy on gaps** and **see deceit**, hence **exposing deceit**.

When the **ears, heart, and eyes** are **harmonized** and **responsive**,
Their **action** will **succeed**—
Nothing will be **unfavorable**.
Their **unfavorableness** is **nonexistent** because they **move with the Dao**.
Thus, **harmonize the three and respond**, **benefit the Dao and act**.

Thus, when **speaking is struck** yet **not disordered**,
When **soaring** yet **not confused**,
When **changing** yet **not perilous**—
This is **grasping the essential** and **obtaining principle**.

If one can **perceive the essential** and **grasp principle**,
Then **flexibility** will **succeed without loss**.

Thus, though **speech is tangled yet not disordered**,
Though **soaring is boundless yet not confused**,
Though **changing** departs from **constancy yet is not perilous**—
This is so.

Thus, the **blind** cannot be shown **five colors**,
The **deaf** cannot be told of **five tones**.
**Five colors** are for those with **eyes**,
Hence the **blind** cannot be **shown** them.
**Five tones** are for those with **ears**,
Hence the **deaf** cannot be **told** of them.
These two are **divisions** for what follows.

Thus, what cannot be **sent forth** has **no opening** for it,
What cannot be **received** has **no acceptance** for it.
There are **things that do not communicate**—
Hence the **Sage** does not **attend** to them.
What cannot be **persuaded** in the other is because they are **obtuse and stagnant**, with **no opening**.
What the other does not **persuade** here is because they are **shallow and narrow**, with **no acceptance**.

The **shallow and narrow** and the **obtuse and stagnant**
Are always **blocked** and **uncommunicative**,
Hence the **Sage** does not **attend** to them.

The ancients said:
*The mouth can eat, but not speak.*
**Speech** has **taboos and prohibitions**.
**Many mouths** can **melt gold**—
This is because **speech has hidden motives**.
The **mouth** can **nourish** the **hundred bodies**, hence it can **eat**.
Yet **speech** can **summon** the **hundred calamities**, hence it cannot **speak**.
**Speech** **touches taboos and prohibitions**, hence **taboos and prohibitions**.
Gold is a **durable thing**, yet **many mouths** can **melt** it—
This is because **many mouths** have **private motives**.
Thus, **speech has hidden motives**.

Human **nature**—
When **speaking**, they desire to be **heard**;
When **acting**, they desire **success**.
What is **hearable** depends on **aligning** with the other,
What is **successful** depends on **following principle**.
This is the **beginning** for what follows.

Thus, the **wise** do not use their **weaknesses** but use the **strengths** of the **foolish**,
Do not use their **clumsiness** but use the **skills** of the **foolish**,
Hence they are **not constrained**.
The **wise**’s **weaknesses** cannot **overcome** the **foolish**’s **strengths**,
Hence they use the **foolish**’s **strengths**.

chunks.original_text: 智者之拙不胜愚人之工，故用愚人之工也。 常能弃拙短而用工长，故不困也。 言其有利者，从其所长也； 言其有害者，避其所短也。 人能从利之所长，避害之所短，故出言铃见听，举事铃有成功也。 故介虫之悍也，必以坚厚； 螫虫之动也，必以毒螫。 故禽兽之用其长，而谈者知用其用也。 言介虫之坚厚以自藏。 螫虫之动也，行毒螫以自卫，此用其所长也。 故能自免於害。 至於他鸟兽莫不知用其长，以自保全。 谈者感此，亦知其所用而用也。 故日辞言五，曰病，日怨#24，日忧，曰怒，曰喜。 五者有一，铃失中和而不平畅。 故曰：病者感衰气而不神也， 病者恍惚，故气衰而不神也。 怨者肠绝而无主也， 怨者内动，故肠绝而言无主也。 忧者闭塞而不泄也， 忧者快忆，故闭塞而言不泄也。 怒者妄动而不治也， 怒者郁勃，故妄动而言不治也。 喜者宣散而无要也。 喜者摇荡，故宣散而言无要。 此五者，精则用之，利则行之。 此五者既失於平常，故用之在精，而行之在利。 其不精利，则废而止之也。 故与智者言依於博，与拙者言依於辨，与辨#25者言依於要，与贵者言依於势，与富者言依於高，与贫者言依於利，与贱者言依於谦，与勇者言依於敢，与过者言依於锐。 此其术也，而人常反之。 此量宜发言之衍也，不达者反之，则逆理而不免成#26於害也。 是故与智者言将此以明之，与不智者言将此以教之而甚难为也。 与智者语将以其明斯衍，与不智者语以此衍教之，然人迷日因久，教之不易，故难为也。 故言多类，事多变。 故终曰言不失其类，故事不乱。 言者条流舛难，故多类也。 事则随时而化，故多变也。 若言不失类，事亦不乱。 终日不变而不失其主，故智贵不妄。 不乱，故不变，故其主有常。 能令有常而不变者，智之用也，故其智可贵而不妄。 听贵聪，智贵明，辞贵奇。 听聪则真伪不乱，知明则可否自分，辞奇则是非有证#27。 三者能行，则功成事立，故须贵之。 谋篇第十 为人凡谋有道情。 得其所因，必得其所因，以求其则其情可求。 见情而谋则事无不济。 审得其情，乃立三仪。 曰中，曰下。 参以立焉言审情之卫，爻立上智、中才、下愚之顺道而动者，故郑人之取玉也，三仪者，曰上，以生奇。 奇不知其所拥，始於古之所从。 三者参以验之，然后奇计可得而生。 奇计既生，莫不通达，惑也。 夫度材量能，故不知其所拥蔽。 然此奇计非自今也南也。 故同情而俱相亲者乃始於古盖从於顺也。 载司南之车为其不揣情者亦事之司其俱成者也； 同欲而相疏者其偏害者也； 诸同情，欲共谋立事。 事若俱成，后叉相亲； 若乃一成一害，后必相疏，理之常也。 同恶而相亲者，其俱害者也，同恶而相疏者，偏害者也。 同恶，谓同为彼所恶。 后若俱害，情叉相亲； 若乃一全一害#28，理铃相疏，亦理之常也。 故相益则亲，相损则疏，其数行也。 此所以察同异之分，其#29类一也。 同异之分，用此而察。 故墙坏於其。 隙，木毁於其节，斯盖其分也。 墙木毁由於隙节，况於人事之变生於同异。 故曰斯盖其分。 故变生於事，事生谋，谋生计，计生议，议生说，说生进，进生退，退生制。 因以制於事，故百事一道，而百度一数也。

The **wise**’s clumsiness cannot overcome the **foolish**’s skill, hence they use the **foolish**’s skill.
If one can always abandon their clumsiness and use the **foolish**’s skill, they will not be constrained.

When speaking of what is beneficial, one follows their strengths;
When speaking of what is harmful, one avoids their weaknesses.
If one follows the strengths of what is beneficial and avoids the weaknesses of what is harmful,
Then their speech will be heard, and their actions will succeed.

Thus, the **armored insect**’s fierceness must rely on its **solidity**,
The **stinging insect**’s movement must rely on its **venom**.
Hence, **birds and beasts** use their strengths,
And the **orator** knows how to use their advantages.

The **armored insect** hides itself with its **solidity**,
The **stinging insect** moves with venom to defend itself—
This is using their strengths.
Thus, they can avoid harm.

Even other birds and beasts do not fail to use their strengths to preserve themselves.
The **orator**, observing this, also knows what to use and how to use it.

Thus, there are **five kinds of speech**:
**Illness**, **grievance**, **worry**, **anger**, and **joy**.
If any one of these five arises, it disrupts **harmony** and **clarity**.

Thus:
**Illness** arises from **weakened qi** and **lack of spirit**—
The ill are **dazed**, so their qi is weak and their spirit is absent.
**Grievance** arises from **ruptured intestines** and **lack of mastery**—
The grieved are inwardly agitated, so their intestines are ruptured and their speech lacks control.
**Worry** arises from **blockage** and **no release**—
The worried are **restless**, so they are blocked and their speech does not flow.
**Anger** arises from **reckless movement** and **lack of restraint**—
The angry are **stifled and surging**, so they move recklessly and their speech is uncontrolled.
**Joy** arises from **dissipation** and **lack of focus**—
The joyful are **shaken**, so they scatter and their speech lacks purpose.

These five, when **refined**, are used;
When **advantageous**, they are applied.
Since these five deviate from **moderation**, their use must be **refined**, and their application must be **advantageous**.
If they are neither refined nor advantageous, they are abandoned.

Thus:
When speaking with the **wise**, rely on **breadth**;
With the **clumsy**, rely on **clarity**;
With the **eloquent**, rely on **concision**;
With the **noble**, rely on **authority**;
With the **wealthy**, rely on **elevation**;
With the **poor**, rely on **benefit**;
With the **lowly**, rely on **humility**;
With the **bold**, rely on **daring**;
With the **reckless**, rely on **sharpness**.

This is the **method**, yet people often reverse it.
This is the **measure** for appropriate speech—
Those who do not understand reverse it,
And thus act against **principle**, failing to avoid harm.

Hence:
When speaking with the **wise**, use this to **illuminate** them;
When speaking with the **unwise**, use this to **teach** them—yet it is difficult.
To speak with the **wise**, present this **method** clearly;
To speak with the **unwise**, teach them this **method**—
But since people’s confusion deepens over time, teaching them is difficult.

Thus, **speech** has many **categories**, and **actions** have many **changes**.
Hence, it is said:
If speech does not lose its **category**, then actions will not be disordered.
Speech is **diverse and intricate**, hence many **categories**.
Actions adapt to **circumstances**, hence many **changes**.
If speech does not lose its **category**, then actions will not be disordered.

To remain unchanging yet not lose **principle**—
This is why the **wise** value **not acting rashly**.
Not being disordered, they do not change,
Thus their **principle** remains constant.
Those who can maintain constancy without change—
This is the **use of wisdom**, hence their wisdom is **precious and not rash**.

Listening values **acuity**,
Wisdom values **clarity**,
Speech values **originality**.
If listening is **acute**, truth and falsehood are not confused;
If wisdom is **clear**, right and wrong are self-evident;
If speech is **original**, right and wrong have **proof**.

If these three are practiced, then **achievement** and **success** are secured—
Hence they must be **valued**.

**Chapter Ten: Planning**
In human affairs, planning follows **human nature**.
Obtain the **foundation**, and the **foundation** must be obtained,
Then seek its **pattern**, and **human nature** can be sought.
Seeing **human nature** and planning, then no matter is left unfinished.

Carefully obtaining **human nature**, one establishes the **Three Complements**.
They are: **Middle**, **Low**.

Using these three to verify, then **strange strategies** can arise.
The **Three Complements** are:
**Upper**—to generate **strangeness**.
**Strangeness** does not know its **origin**, beginning from ancient **patterns**.

The three are used together to verify,
Then **strange strategies** can emerge.
Once **strange strategies** arise, they are universally effective—
Yet they are **obscured**.

Measuring **talent** and **ability**, one does not know their **limitations**.
Yet these **strange strategies** did not originate today or yesterday.
Thus, those of **shared nature** and **affinity** begin from antiquity, following **principle**.

The **South-pointing chariot** is used for those who do not **weigh circumstances**—
Yet it is also a **guide** for those whose affairs succeed together.
Those of **shared desire** but **estranged**—
These are those who **harm each other**.
All who share **nature** and **desire** to **plan and act together**:
If their affairs succeed together, later they will be **affectionate**;
If one succeeds and one is harmed, later they will be **estranged**—this is **principle**.

Those who share **hatred** and are **affectionate**—
These are those who **harm each other together**.
Those who share **hatred** but are **estranged**—
These are those who **harm each other partially**.
**Shared hatred** means they are **hated by the same**.
Later, if both are harmed, their **nature** will be **affectionate**;
If one is spared and one is harmed, **principle** dictates they will be **estranged**—
This too is **principle**.

Thus, **benefit brings closeness**, **harm brings estrangement**—
This is the **constant law**.

This is how one discerns the **division of similarity and difference**—
Their **categories** are the same.

The **division of similarity and difference** is examined using this.
Thus, walls collapse at their **cracks**,
Wood breaks at its **knots**—
This is their **division**.

Walls and wood are destroyed because of **cracks and knots**,
How much more so in **human affairs**, where **changes arise from similarity and difference**!
Thus, it is said: This is their **division**.

Thus, **changes arise from affairs**,
Affairs arise from **planning**,
Planning arises from **strategy**,
Strategy arises from **debate**,
Debate arises from **persuasion**,
Persuasion arises from **advancement**,
Advancement arises from **retreat**,
Retreat arises from **control**.

Using **control** to govern **affairs**,
Thus, all **affairs** follow **one path**,
And all **methods** follow **one principle**.

chunks.original_text: 言事有本根，各有从来，譬之卉木因根而有枝条花叶，故曰#30变隙，然后生於事业。 生事业者，必须计谋。 成计谋者，铃须议说。 议说铃有当否，故须进退之。 既有黜陆，须事以为法，而百事百度何莫由斯而至，其道数一也。 夫仁人轻货，不可诱以利，可使出费； 勇士轻难，不可惧以患，可使据危； 智者达於数，明於理，不可欺以诚，可示以道理，可使立功，是三才也。 使轻货者出费，则费可全； 使轻难者据危，则危可安； 使达数者立功，则功可成。 总三材而用之，可以光耀千里，岂徒十二乘而已。 故愚者易蔽也，不肖者易惧也，贪者易诱也，是因事而裁之。 以此三衍，取彼三短，可以立事立功也。 谋者因事兴虑，宜知之而裁之。 故日因事而裁之。 故为强者积於弱也，有余者积於不足也，此其道卫行也。 柔弱胜於刚强，故积弱可以为强大。 直若曲，故积曲可以为直。 少则得众，故积不足可以为有余。 然则以弱为强，以曲为直，以不足为有余，斯道卫之所行，故日道衍行也。 故外亲而内疏者说内，内亲而外疏者说外。 外阳相亲而内实疏者，说内以除其内疏。 内实相亲而外阳疏者，说外以除其外疏也。 故因其疑以变之，因其见以然之， 若内外无亲而怀疑者，则因其疑而变化之。 彼或因见而有所见，则因其所见而然之。 因其说以要之，因其势以成之， 既然见彼或有可否之说，则因其说要结之可否。 既形便有去就之势，则因其势以成就之。 因其恶以权之，因其患以斥之。 去就既成，或有恶息，则因其恶也，以权量之； 因其息也，为斥除之。 摩而恐之，高而动之， 息恶既除，或恃胜而骄者，便切摩以恐，惧之高危，以感动之。 微而正之，符而应之， 虽恐动之，尚不知变者，则微有所引据以证之，为设符验以应之。 拥而塞之，乱而惑之，是谓计谋。 虽有为设引据符验，尚不知变者，此或深不可救也，使拥而塞之，乱而惑之，因抵而得之。 如此者可以计谋之用也。 计谋之用，公不如私，私、不如结，结而无隙者也。 公者扬于王庭，名为聚讼，莫执其咎，其事难成。 私者不出门庭，慎密无失，其功可立。 故公不如私。 虽复潜谋，不如与彼要结。 二人同心，物莫之问，欲求其隙，其可得乎。 正不如奇，奇流而不止者也。 正者，循理守常，难以速进。 奇者，反经合义，事同机发。 故正不如奇。 奇计一行，则流通而莫知止也。 故日：奇流而不止者也。 故说人主者必与之言奇，说人臣者必与之言私。 与人主言奇，则非常之功可立； 与人臣言私，则保身之道可全。 其身内其言，外者疏； 其身外其言，深者危。 身在内而言外，泄者叉见疏也； 身居外而言深，切者叉见危也。 无以人之近所不欲而强之於人，无以人之所不知而教之於人。 谓其事虽近，彼所不欲，莫强与之，将生恨怒也。 教人当以所知，今反以人所不知教之，犹以暗除暗，岂为益哉。 人之有好也，学而顺之； 人之有恶也，避而讳之，故阴道而阳取之也。 学顺人之所好，避讳人之所恶，但阴自为之； 非彼所逆，彼叉感悦，明言以报之。 故日：阴道而阳取之也。 故去之者纵之，纵之者乘之。 将欲去之，铃先听纵，令极其过恶。 过恶既极，便可以法乘之。

「Speaking of affairs, they have **fundamental roots** and **origins**—
Each has its own source, like plants and trees that grow from roots into branches, twigs, flowers, and leaves.

And then **affairs and undertakings** emerge.

Those who bring forth **affairs and undertakings** must first devise **strategy and planning**.
Those who perfect **strategy and planning** must first engage in **debate and persuasion**.
**Debate and persuasion** must be weighed for their **correctness or error**,
Thus, **advancement and retreat** are required.

Once **dismissal and elevation** are determined,
**Affairs** must be set as **precedent**,
And then all **undertakings and methods**—what is there that does not arise from this?
Their **Dao and principles** are singular.

The **virtuous person** holds **wealth in light regard**,
Cannot be tempted by **gain**,
But can be moved to **expend**;
The **brave warrior** scorns **hardship**,
Cannot be deterred by **calamity**,
But can be urged to **embrace peril**;
The **wise strategist** grasps **principles** and understands **logic**,
Cannot be deceived by **false sincerity**,
But can be shown **reason and rightness**,
And thus **achieve merit**—
These are the **Three Talents**.

If you lead those who hold **wealth in light regard** to **expend**,
Then **wealth** can be preserved;
If you guide those who scorn **hardship** to **embrace peril**,
Then **peril** can be **calmed**;
If you inspire those who grasp **principles** to **achieve merit**,
Then **merit** can be **accomplished**.

Combining these **Three Talents** and applying them,
One can **illuminate** a thousand *li* (leagues),
Why limit oneself to mere **twelve strategies** alone?

Thus, the **foolish** are easily **obstructed**,
The **unworthy** are easily **intimidated**,
The **greedy** are easily **enticed**—
This is **adapting to circumstances**.

Using these **three strengths**,
And **countering** those **three weaknesses**,
One can **establish undertakings** and **achieve merit**.

The **planner** must **study circumstances** and **adapt accordingly**.
Thus, it is said: **Adapt to circumstances**.

Therefore, the **strong** must **accumulate weakness**,
And the **abundant** must **accumulate insufficiency**—
This is the **Dao of flexibility** in practice.

**Softness overcomes hardness**,
Thus, **accumulating weakness** can bring **great strength**.
**Straightness follows curvature**,
Thus, **accumulating curvature** can achieve **straightness**.
**Fewness gains multitude**,
Thus, **accumulating insufficiency** can yield **abundance**.

Hence, **using weakness as strength**,
**curving as straightness**,
**insufficiency as abundance**,
This is the **Dao of flexibility** in action,
Thus, it is called: **The Way of Adaptive Practice**.

Therefore, when advising a ruler whose **inner trust is distant** while **outerly close**,
Speak of the **inner**;
When advising a subject whose **inner trust is close** while **outerly distant**,
Speak of the **outer**.

If **outerly close in appearance** but **innerly distant in truth**,
Then speak of the **inner** to **remove internal estrangement**.
If **innerly close in truth** but **outerly distant in appearance**,
Then speak of the **outer** to **remove external estrangement**.

Thus, **exploit their doubts** to **transform** them,
**Confirm their perceptions** to **settle** them—
If **inner and outer** are not close and one harbors **doubt**,
Then **exploit their doubt** and **change** them.
If they **perceive** something and **hold a view**,
Then **confirm their perception** to **establish** it.

**Leverage their arguments** to **bind** them,
**Exploit their momentum** to **complete** it—
Once **views** are shaped, there are **positions of approach or withdrawal**,
Then **exploit their momentum** to **fulfill** it.
Once **positions** are set, if **evil persists**,
Then **weigh their evil** to **counterbalance** it,
And **dismiss their remnants** to **repel** them.

**Gently press** to **frighten** them,
**Heighten risks** to **stir** them—
Once **evil is dismissed**, if they **rely on victory** and **become arrogant**,
Then **press them gently** to **instill fear**,
And **expose them to peril** to **shake** their confidence.

**Subtly correct** to **align** them,
**Use omens** to **respond**—
Though **fear and agitation** may take hold,
If they still **do not understand change**,
Then **subtly present evidence** to **verify** it,
And **set up signs** to **confirm** the truth.

**Surround and block** them,
**Disrupt and confuse** them—
This is called **strategy and planning**.

Though **evidence and signs** are presented,
If they still **do not understand change**,
This is perhaps **too deep to remedy**—
Then **surround and block** them,
**Disrupt and confuse** them,
And **counter their resistance** to **gain** them.

Thus, one can **employ strategy and planning**.

The **application of strategy and planning**,
**Public methods** are not as effective as **private**,
**Private** is not as effective as **binding**—
**Binding** means **no gaps**.

**Public methods** are proclaimed in the **royal court**,
Known as **litigious assembly**,
Where **no one bears blame**,
And their **undertakings are hard to fulfill**.
**Private methods** do not leave the **inner court**,
Are **cautious and precise**,
And their **merits can be achieved**.

Thus, **public methods are not as effective as private**.

Even **secret planning** is not as effective as **binding with them**.
Two people with **unified hearts**,
No **external force** can **pierce** them—
To seek their **gaps**, how possible is it?

**Directness** is not as effective as **indirectness**—
**Indirectness** is **unending flow**.

**Directness** follows **logic** and **holds to constancy**,
Is **difficult to advance swiftly**.
**Indirectness** **inverts principles** yet **aligns with rightness**,
**Undertakings** **match the moment** like **crossbows** firing.

Thus, **directness is not as effective as indirectness**.
When **indirect strategies** are **executed once**,
They **circulate endlessly** and **no one knows their end**.

Thus, it is said: **Indirectness flows without stopping**.

Therefore, when advising a **sovereign**,
One must speak of **indirectness**,
And when advising a **minister**,
One must speak of **privacy**.

Speaking of **indirectness** to a **sovereign**,
Then **extraordinary merit** can be **achieved**;
Speaking of **privacy** to a **minister**,
Then **self-preservation** can be **fully secured**.

If their **body is inwardly aligned** yet their **words outwardly distant**,
Then the **superficial** become **estranged**;
If their **body is outwardly distant** yet their **words inwardly profound**,
Then the **deeply placed** are **in peril**.
If one’s **body is inward** yet their **words outward**,
Then the **leaky** are **again estranged**;
If one’s **body is outward** yet their **words deep**,
Then the **urgent** are **again in peril**.

Do not **force upon others** what they **nearly dislike**,
Do not **teach others** what they **do not know**.

If the **undertaking** is **close at hand** yet they **dislike it**,
Do not **force** it upon them—
They will **harbor resentment and anger**.
When **teaching others**, use what they **already know**—
Now to **teach them what they do not know** is like **using darkness to dispel darkness**,
How can this be **beneficial**?

People have **likes**—
**Study** and **align** with them;
People have **dislikes**—
**Avoid** and **conceal** them,
Thus, **hidden paths** are **taken** while **open paths** are **chosen**.

**Study** and **align** with what people **like**,
**Avoid** and **conceal** what people **dislike**—
Do this **in secret**;
Not **contrary** to their **nature**,
They will **respond with joy**—
Then **clearly state** to **reward** them.

Thus, it is said: **Hidden paths are taken while open paths are chosen**.

Therefore, to **remove** them, **grant freedom**,
And to **grant freedom**, **exploit their momentum**—
When you wish to **remove** them,
First **listen to their freedom**,
Let them **push their transgressions to extremes**.

Once their **transgressions are extreme**,
Then **apply the law** to **counter** them.

And all **methods** follow **one principle**.

chunks.original_text: 故日：纵之者乘之也。 貌者，不美又不恶，故至情托焉。 貌者，谓察人之貌以知其情也，谓其人中和平淡，见善不美，见恶不非。 如此者可以至情托之。 故曰：至情托焉。 可知者可用也，不可知者谋者所不用也。 谓彼情宽密，可令知者，可为用谋，故日可知者可用也。 其不宽密，不可令知者，谋者不为用谋也，故日不可知者谋者所不用也。 故曰事贵制人，而不贵见制於人。 制人者握权也，见制於人者制命也。 制命者，言命为人所制也。 故圣人之道阴，愚人之道阳， 圣人之道内阳而外阴，愚人之道内阴而外阳。 智者事易，而不智者事难。 以此观之，亡不可以为存，而危不可以为安，然而无为而贵智矣。 智者宽恕，故易事； 愚者猜忌，故难事。 然而不智叉有危亡之祸，以其难事，故贤者莫得申其计画，则亡者遂亡，危者遂危，欲求安存不亦难乎。 今欲存其亡，安其危，则他莫能为，惟智者可矣。 故日：无为而贵智矣。 智用於众人之所不能知，而能用於众人之所不能见。 众人所不能知，众人所不能见，智独能用之，所以贵於智矣。 既用，见可否，择事而为之，所以自为也； 见不可，择事而为之，所以为人也。 亦既用智先己而后人，所见可否，择事为之，将此自为； 所不可见，择事而为之，将此为人。 亦犹伯乐教所亲相驽聆，教所僧相千里也。 故先王之道，阴言有之，日天地之化在高与深； 圣人之制道在隐与匿，非独忠信仁义也，中正而已矣。 言先王之道贵於阴密。 寻古遗言，证有此理，曰：天地之化唯在高深，圣人之制道唯在隐匿。 所隐者中正，自然合道，非专在仁义忠信也。 故日：非独忠信仁义。 道理达於此义之#32，则可与言。 言谋者晓达道理，能於此义达畅，则可与语至而言极矣。 由能得此，则可与谷远近之义#33。 谷，养也。 若能得此道之义，则可与居大宝之位，养远近之人，诱於也寿之域也。 决篇第十一 为人凡央物，必托於疑者，善其用有#34福，恶其有患，善#35至於诱也。 有疑然后央，故日叉托於疑者。 几人之情用福则善，有息则恶。 福息之理未明，疑之所由生。 故日善其用福，恶其有息。 然善於次疑者，铃诱得其情，乃能断其可否也。 终无惑偏有利焉，去其利，则不受也。 奇之所托。 怀疑日惑，不正日偏。 次者能无惑偏，行者乃有通济，然后福利生焉。 若乃去其福利，则疑者不受其次。 更使托意於奇也。 趋异变常，日奇#36。 若有利於善者，隐托於恶，则不受矣，致疏远。 谓疑者本其利善，而次者隐其利善之情，反托之於恶，则不受其次，更致疏远矣。 故其有使失利，其有使离害者，此事之失。 言上之二者或去利托於恶，疑者既不受其次，则所行罔能通济。 故有失利罹害之败。 凡此皆次事之失也。 圣人所以能成其事者有五：有以阳德之者，有以阴贼之者，有以信诚之者，有以蔽匿之者，有以平素之者。 圣人善变通，穷物理，几所次事期於叉成。 事成理着者，以阳德次之； 情隐言伪者，以阴贼次之； 道成志直者，以信诚次之； 奸小祸微者，以蔽匿次之； 循常守故者，以平素次之。 阳励於一言，阴励於二言，平素枢机以用，四者微而施之。 励，勉也。 阳为君道，故所言叉励於一。

Thus, it is said: **"To indulge is to exploit them."**

**Appearance**—
Neither beautiful nor ugly, hence **truthful emotions** are **entrusted** to it.
**Appearance** refers to observing people’s **demeanor** to discern their **emotions**,
That is, when they see good, they do not praise it,
And when they see evil, they do not condemn it.
Those who act thus can **entrust** their **truthful emotions** to it.
Hence, it is said: **"Truthful emotions are entrusted to it."**

What can be **known** can be **employed**,
What cannot be **known** is what the **planner** does not **employ**.
It is said that their **emotions** are broad and subtle,
Those who can be made to **know** can be **employed** in **planning**,
Hence, it is said: **"What can be known can be employed."**
Those whose **emotions** are not broad and subtle,
Those who cannot be made to **know** are not **employed** in **planning**,
Hence, it is said: **"What cannot be known is what the planner does not employ."**

Therefore, **matters** are **valued** in **controlling others**,
And not in being **controlled** by others.
**Controlling others** is **holding authority**,
Being **controlled** by others is **submitting to fate**.
**Submitting to fate** means one’s **fate** is **controlled** by others.
Hence, the **Dao/Way** of the **sage** is **hidden**,
The **Dao/Way** of the **fool** is **open**,
The **Dao/Way** of the **sage** is **internally open** yet **externally hidden**,
The **Dao/Way** of the **fool** is **internally hidden** yet **externally open**.

The **wise** find **matters** easy,
The **unwise** find **matters** difficult.
From this perspective, **perishing** cannot be **preserved**,
And **danger** cannot be **made secure**,
Yet it is said: **"The Way of non-action values wisdom."**

The **wise** are **forgiving**,
Hence **matters** are easy for them;
The **foolish** are **suspicious**,
Hence **matters** are difficult for them.
Yet even the **unwise** may suffer **perishing** or **danger**,
Because their **matters** are difficult,
Thus the **virtuous** cannot **fully implement** their **strategies**—
Then the **perishing** will **perish**, the **dangerous** will **remain dangerous**,
And to **seek security** and **preservation** is not also difficult?
Now, if one wishes to **preserve** the **perishing**,
And **secure** the **dangerous**,
Then none but the **wise** can do it.
Hence, it is said: **"The Way of non-action values wisdom."**

Wisdom is **employed** where the **multitude** cannot **know**,
Yet can be **employed** where the **multitude** cannot **see**.
What the **multitude** cannot **know**,
What the **multitude** cannot **see**,
Only the **wise** can **employ** it,
Thus wisdom is **valued** above all.

Once **employed**,
If what is **seen** is **appropriate**,
Choose **matters** and act upon them—
This is to act for **oneself**;
If what is **seen** is **inappropriate**,
Choose **matters** and act upon them—
This is to act for **others**.
It is also said:
When wisdom is **employed**, first for **oneself**, then for **others**,
If what is **seen** is **appropriate**,
Choose **matters** and act upon them—
This is to act for **oneself**;
If what is **not seen** is **inappropriate**,
Choose **matters** and act upon them—
This is to act for **others**.
It is like **Bo Le** teaching the **cherished** yet **discarding the unworthy**,
And **rewarding the diligent** yet **abandoning the sluggish**.

Hence, the **Dao/Way** of the **ancient kings** had **hidden words**,
Saying: **"The transformation of Heaven and Earth lies in loftiness and depth."**
The **sage’s** **establishment** of the **Dao/Way** lies in **concealment** and **obscurity**,
Not merely in **loyalty, sincerity, benevolence, and righteousness**,
But in **moderation and rectitude** alone.
It is said that the **Dao/Way** of the **ancient kings** values **hidden subtlety**.
Examining the **ancient remnants**,
Verifying that this **principle** exists,
It is said: **"The transformation of Heaven and Earth lies only in loftiness and depth,
The sage’s establishment of the Dao/Way lies only in concealment and obscurity."**
What is **concealed** is **moderation and rectitude**,
Naturally **harmonizing** with the **Dao/Way**,
Not **exclusively** in **benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, and sincerity**.
Hence, it is said: **"Not merely in loyalty, sincerity, benevolence, and righteousness."**

When the **principles** of the **Dao/Way** are **understood** to this extent,
Then one can **discuss** them.
It is said that the **planner** **grasps** the **principles** of the **Dao/Way**,
If one can **reach** this **extent** and **be fluent**,
Then one can **speak** to the **highest** and **most profound** **levels**.
From **obtaining** this,
One can then **discuss** the **far and near** **principles**#33.
**Discuss** means **nurture**.
If one **obtains** this **Dao/Way’s principle**,
Then one can **hold** the **great treasure** **position**,
**Nurture** the **far and near** people,
And **lead** them to the **domain of longevity**.
**Decision** Chapter Eleven

In **ordinary matters**,
When **entrusting** to **people**,
One must **entrust** to those who **doubt**,
For **good use** brings **blessing**,
And **bad use** brings **calamity**—
**Good** extends to **leading** them.
Only after **doubt** does one **entrust**,
Hence, it is said: **"Again, entrust to those who doubt."**

**Nearly** **people’s** **emotions**,
When **blessing** is **employed**, are **good**,
When **calamity** is **employed**, are **evil**.
The **principles** of **blessing** and **calamity** are **not yet clear**,
Thus **doubt** arises from them.
Hence, it is said: **"Good use brings blessing, evil use brings calamity."**

Yet, those who **follow** after **doubt**,
First **lead** them to **obtain** their **emotions**,
Then can **determine** their **appropriateness or inappropriateness**.
**Ultimately**, there is **no confusion** or **partiality**,
Only **benefit** can arise.
Remove their **benefit**,
And they will **not accept** it.
This is the **strange** **entrustment**.

**Holding doubt** is **confusion**,
**Not being upright** is **partiality**.
Those who **follow** without **confusion** or **partiality**,
Then the **doer** will have **success and guidance**,
And **blessing and benefit** will arise.
If one **removes** their **blessing and benefit**,
Then the **doubters** will **not accept** their **followers**.
**Further**, **entrust** one’s **intentions** to the **strange**.

**Tending toward novelty** and **changing constancy**,
Is called **strange**#36.
If there is **benefit** in **goodness**,
And one **conceals** and **entrusts** it to **evil**,
Then they will **not accept** it,
And it will **lead to estrangement**.
It is said that the **doubters**, **based on their benefit**,
And **goodness**, yet the **followers** **conceal** their **benefit** and **goodness**,
And **entrust** it to **evil**,
Then the **doubters** will **not accept** their **followers**,
And it will **lead to estrangement**.

Hence, there are those who **cause loss of benefit**,
And those who **cause separation from harm**—
This is the **failure** of **matters**.
It is said that the **two upper** **methods**,
Sometimes **remove benefit** and **entrust to evil**,
The **doubters**, having **not accepted** their **followers**,
Then what is **done** will **not succeed** in **guidance**.
Hence, there are **failures** in **loss of benefit** and **suffering harm**.
All these are the **failures** of **matters**.

The **sage** can **accomplish** their **matters** through **five methods**:
There are those who **employ** **open virtue**,
Those who **employ** **hidden guile**,
Those who **employ** **sincerity and trust**,
Those who **employ** **concealment and obscurity**,
And those who **employ** **moderation and simplicity**.
The **sage** excels in **adaptation and flexibility**,
Exhausts the **principles** of **things**,
And **nearly** **matters** **are completed** through them.
When **matters** are **completed** and **principles** are **established**,
**Open virtue** is **employed**;
When **emotions** are **hidden** and **words** are **false**,
**Hidden guile** is **employed**;
When the **Dao/Way** is **established** and **intentions** are **straightforward**,
**Sincerity and trust** are **employed**;
When **deceit** is **minor** and **harm** is **slight**,
**Concealment and obscurity** are **employed**;
When **following constancy** and **holding to the old**,
**Moderation and simplicity** are **employed**.
**Open virtue** is **encouraged** with **one word**,
**Hidden guile** is **encouraged** with **two words**,
**Moderation and simplicity** serve as the **pivot and mechanism** for **employment**,
And the **fourth** is **subtle** yet **applied**.
**Encourage** means **exhort**.
**Open** is the **Dao/Way** of the **ruler**,
Hence what is **spoken** is **also encouraged** with **one word**.
