chunks.original_text: 一，无为也。 阴为臣道，故所言叉励於二。 二，有为也。 君道无为，故以平素为主。 臣道有为，故以枢机为用。 言一也，二也，平素也，枢机也，四者其所施为，铃精微而契妙，然后事行而理不难。 於是度以往事，验之来事，参之平素，可则央之； 君臣既有定分，然后度往验来，参以平素，计其是非，於理既可，则为之次也。 公王大人之事也，危而美名者，可则决之； 危由高也，事高而名美者，则为次之。 不用费力而易成者，可则庾之； 所谓惠而不费，故为次之。 用力犯勤苦然而不得已而为之者，则 可庾之； 所谓知之所无奈何#37，安之若命，故为之次。 去患者，可则央之； 从福者，可则次之。 去息从福之人，理之大顺，故为次之也。 故夫央情定疑，万事之机#38。 以正乱治，央成败，难为者。 治乱以之正，成败之次，失之毫厘，差之千里。 枢机之发，荣辱之主，故曰难为。 故先王乃用曹龟者，以自庾也。 夫以先王之圣智，无所不通，犹用着龟以自次，况自斯已下而可以专己自信，不博谋於通识者哉。 符言第十二 发言必验，有若符契，故日符言。 安徐正静，其被节无不肉#39。 被，及也。 肉，肥也，谓饶裕也。 言人若居位，能安徐正静，则所及人节度无不饶裕。 善与而不静，虚心平意，以待倾损， 言人君善与事结，而不安静者，但虚心平意以待之，倾损之期叉至矣。 有#40主位。 主於位者安徐正静而已。 目贵明，耳贵聪，心贵智。 目明则视无不见，耳聪则听无不闻，心智则思无不通。 是三者无拥，则何措而非当也。 以天下之目视者则无不见，以天下之耳听者则无不闻，以天下之心虑者则无不知。 昔在帝尧，聪明文思，光宅天下，盖用此道也。 辐赓并进，则明不可塞， 夫圣人不自用，其聪明思虑而任之天下。 故明者为之视，聪者为之听，智者为之谋。 若云从龙，风从虎，需然而莫之御。 辐嗅并进，不亦宜乎。 若日月照临，其可塞哉。 故日：明不可塞也。 有主明。 主於明者以天下之目视也。 德之术，曰勿坚而拒之， 崇德之衍在於恢弘博纳。 山不让尘，故能成其高； 海不辞流，故能成其深，圣人不拒众，故能成其大。 故日：勿坚而拒之也。 许之则仿守，拒之则闭塞。 言许而容之，众铃归而防守。 拒而逆之，众叉违而闭塞。 归而防守，则危可安，违而闭塞，则通更壅。 夫崇德者，安可以不弘纳哉。 高山仰之可极、探渊度之可测，神明之位．术正静，其莫之极欤。 高莫过山犹可极，深莫过渊犹可测。 若乃神明之位#41卫正静，迎之不见其前，随之不见其后，其可测量乎哉。 有主德。 主於德者在於含弘而勿距也。 用赏贵信，用刑贵正。 赏信，则立功之士致命捐生； 刑正，则受#42戮之人没齿无怨也。 赏赐贵信，必验耳目之所见闻，其所不见闻者，莫不间化矣。 言施恩行赏，耳目所见闻，则能验察不谬，动叉当功。 如此，则信在言前，虽不见闻者，莫不合化也。 诚畅於天下神明，而况奸者干君。 言每赏从信，则至诚畅於天下，神明保之如赤子，天禄不倾如泰山。 又况不逞之徒，欲奋其奸谋，干於君位者哉。 此犹腐肉之齿，利剑锋接铃无事矣。 有主赏。 主於赏者贵於信也。
chunks.translated_text:
One—**non-action**. The **shadow** is the **path of the subject**, hence what is spoken is also **exhorted with two words**.
Two—**action**. The **ruler’s path** is **non-action**, hence **moderation and simplicity** are the **primary**.
The **subject’s path** is **action**, hence **pivot and mechanism** are **employed**.

When **one** is spoken, when **two** is spoken, when **moderation and simplicity** are applied, when **pivot and mechanism** are used—these four methods in their **application** are **refined and subtle**, **harmonizing with the profound**, then **affairs proceed** and **principles face no difficulty**.

Thus, **measuring past events**, **verifying future ones**, **consulting moderation and simplicity**, if **proper**, then **employ it**.
When **ruler and subject** have **fixed roles**, then **measure the past**, **verify the future**, **consult moderation and simplicity**, **calculate right and wrong**—if **in accord with principle**, then **employ it as a method**.

In **public and royal affairs** of **great lords**, when **dangerous yet glorious**—if **proper**, then **decide upon it**.
Danger arises from **height**—when **affairs are lofty** and **reputation glorious**, then **employ it as a method**.

When **effort is spared** and **success is easy**—if **proper**, then **employ it**.
This is called **"benevolence without expenditure"**, hence **employ it as a method**.

When **effort is exerted**, **labor is strenuous**, yet **inevitable**—then **employ it**.
This is called **"knowing what cannot be helped"**, **"accepting it as fate"**, hence **employ it as a method**.

To **remove calamity**—if **proper**, then **employ it**.
To **follow blessing**—if **proper**, then **employ it**.
To **reject calamity** and **follow blessing** is the **greatest harmony of principle**, hence **employ it as a method**.

Thus, **settling doubts with sincerity** is the **pivot of ten thousand affairs**.
To **restore order from chaos**, to **determine success or failure**—this is **difficult to execute**.
Order is restored by **uprightness**, success or failure is **decided by method**—a **hair’s breadth** off, and the **result is miles apart**.
The **triggering of mechanisms** is the **source of honor and disgrace**, hence it is said: **difficult to execute**.

Thus, the **ancient kings** used **tortoise shells and milfoil** to **consult themselves**.
Though the **ancient kings’ sagacity** was **omniscient**, they still **cast divination** to **determine methods**. How much more should those **below them** dare to **rely solely on themselves**, without **seeking counsel from the wise**?

**The Twelfth Canon: Concordant Speech**
When **words are spoken**, they **must be verified**, like **seals and contracts**, hence it is called **Concordant Speech**.

**Calm, composed, upright, and tranquil**—those they **reach** are **nourished**.
*"Reach"* means **extend**; *"nourished"* means **abundant**.
When a **person in position** can be **calm, composed, upright, and tranquil**, then **all they influence** are **well-regulated and abundant**.

**Giving generously yet remaining tranquil**, with a **vacant heart and even mind**, awaiting **depletion or loss**—
When a **ruler** is **skilled in bestowing favors** yet **not tranquil**, only by **vacant heart and even mind** can they **await it**, for **depletion or loss** will **surely arrive**.

**The sovereign’s virtue** lies in **position**.
Those who **hold position** must be **calm, composed, upright, and tranquil**.

**Eyes value clarity**, **ears value acuity**, **mind values wisdom**.
**Clear eyes** see **nothing unseen**, **acute ears** hear **nothing unheard**, **wise mind** thinks **nothing unperceived**.
If these three are **unobstructed**, then **what action is not appropriate**?

To **see with the world’s eyes** is to **see nothing unseen**, to **hear with the world’s ears** is to **hear nothing unheard**, to **plan with the world’s wisdom** is to **know nothing unknown**.
In the **age of Emperor Yao**, **bright and enlightened**, **cultivating the world**, he **employed this method**.

**Radiance and fragrance advance together**, then **clarity cannot be blocked**.
The **sage does not act alone**—their **brightness and wisdom** are **delegated to the world**.
Thus, the **clear-seeing govern**, the **acute-hearing listen**, the **wise advise**.
Like **following the dragon**, **wind following the tiger**, **inevitable yet unchecked**.
**Radiance and fragrance advance together**—how could it be otherwise?
Like **sun and moon shining**, how could they be **blocked**?
Hence it is said: **clarity cannot be blocked**.

**The sovereign’s virtue** lies in **clarity**.
Those who **hold clarity** do so by **seeing with the world’s eyes**.

**The art of virtue** is: **do not rigidly reject**.
**Nurturing virtue** lies in **expansiveness and inclusivity**.
Mountains **do not reject dust**, hence they **achieve height**; seas **do not spurn tides**, hence they **achieve depth**.
The **sage does not repel the multitude**, hence they **achieve greatness**.
Thus it is said: **do not rigidly reject**.

**Permit them, and they will guard**; **reject them, and they will close off**.
If you **permit and embrace**, the **multitude will return and defend**.
If you **reject and oppose**, the **multitude will rebel and stagnate**.
To **nurture virtue**, how can one **fail to be expansive and inclusive**?

Mountains **can be measured in height**, depths **can be fathomed**—yet **divine and enlightened positions**, **upright and tranquil**, **cannot be measured**.
Mountains **cannot exceed height**, depths **cannot exceed depth**—yet **divine and enlightened positions**—when **approached, no front is seen**; when **followed, no rear is seen**. How can they be **measured**?

**The sovereign’s virtue** lies in **virtue**.
Those who **hold virtue** do so by **embracing expansiveness and not resisting**.

**Rewards must be trustworthy**, **punishments must be just**.
**Trustworthy rewards** make **meritorious officers** **risk life for duty**.
**Just punishments** ensure **those executed** **die without resentment**.

**Rewards must be trustworthy**—**verify what eyes and ears witness**; what is **unseen and unheard** will **inevitably transform**.
When **bestowing favors and rewards**, if **ears and eyes verify** without **error**, and **actions align with merit**, then **trust precedes speech**, and even the **unseen and unheard** will **harmonize**.

Those who **hold rewards** value **trustworthiness**.

chunks.translated_text:
**The Threefold Sovereignty of Heaven, Earth, and Humanity**

One is **Heaven’s**, one is **Earth’s**, and one is **Humanity’s**.
Heaven has the **order of逆顺** (inverse and compliance),
Earth has the **principles of孤虚** (loneliness and emptiness),
Humanity has the **divisions of通塞** (flow and obstruction).
Those who hold **the Mandate of Heaven** must all know these.

In **all directions—above, below, left, right, front, and back**—
where is the **wandering star (荧惑)**?
For **all directions—above, below, left, right, front, and back**,
there are **proper alignments of yin and yang**, **facing and turning**—
these are what **governors and officials must not fail to understand**.
Moreover, **荧惑** is **Heaven’s legal star**—
where it resides brings **disaster to the blue-green** (east),
and its **auspicious or inauspicious influence is particularly pronounced**.
Thus it is said:
Even **a sagely monarch** must **scrutinize where 荧惑 resides**.
Therefore, one must also **know this**.

**The Sovereign’s Questions**
The sovereign who **questions** must **discern the Dao of the Three Powers (三才)**.
The **heart governs the nine orifices**,
the **ruler is the leader of the five senses**.
The **nine orifices move as the heart directs**,
and the **five senses act as the ruler commands**.
For those who do **good**, the ruler **bestows rewards**;
for those who do **wrong**, the ruler **inflicts punishments**.
**Rewarding the good and punishing the wrong** is the **great principle of governance**.
The ruler **follows the means by which governance is sought**—
if he **responds accordingly**, there will be **no labor**.
**Responding** means **granting what is requested**;
**requesting** means **seeking without fulfillment**.
If **requests are met**, then **giving and receiving are not arbitrary**;
if **what is given is received**, then **actions proceed without delay**.
Moving in accordance with **nature**, what **labor is there**?
The **sage employs this**, and thus **can reward appropriately**.
Following **principle**, it **endures without fail**.
Responding to **requests**, there is **no greater joy**.
Even without **jade and silk**, the **encouragement is as if rewards were given**.
Yet if **one acts against principle**, **disaster comes swiftly**.
Following **principle**, it **endures long**—
this is the **sovereign who responds**.

**The Sovereign’s Response**
The sovereign who **responds** must **follow principle**.
The ruler **cannot be neglectful**.
If the ruler is **neglectful**, then **crafty ministers arise**, and **the people are oppressed and rebellious**.
**Neglect** means **not comprehending the principles of things**.
When **principles are not fully known**, then **crafty ministers cause chaos**.
**Business (家)**—like **crafts**—becomes **unstable**,
and **inner and outer affairs are disconnected**.
How can one **know what to open**?
**Business (家)** here means **enterprise**.
Since **crafty ministers are in chaos**, what they **undertake is unstable**,
and **inner and outer affairs are blocked**—
**obstacles abound on all paths**.
How can one **know what to open**?
If **opening and closing are mismanaged**, the **source of good governance is unseen**.
**Opening and closing** refer to **牌阖** (the art of strategic disclosure and concealment).
Since **牌阖’s principles are not applied**, the **source of good governance remains hidden**.

**The Sovereign’s Comprehensive Knowledge**
The sovereign who **comprehends** must **know the principles of all things**.
One is **long-sightedness (长目)**,
two is **flying ears (飞耳)**,
three is **establishing clarity (树明)**.
Using **the eyes of all under Heaven to see**, hence **long-sightedness**.
Using **the ears of all under Heaven to hear**, hence **flying ears**.
Using **the minds of all under Heaven to deliberate**, hence **establishing clarity**.
With **clarity**, one **knows a thousand li away**,
and **what is hidden and subtle**—
this is called **penetrating all under Heaven**.
**Delinquents cannot conceal their schemes** in their hearts.
For **using the minds of all under Heaven to deliberate**,
there is **nothing unknown**—
thus, **a thousand li away**, **hidden and subtle matters** are **all discerned**.
Since **hidden things are exposed**, those who **plot evil** will **abandon their schemes in their hearts**.
Thus it is said: **They cannot but change**.

**The Sovereign’s Reverence**
The sovereign who **reveres** must **possess keen intelligence and refined thought**.
Following **names to achieve reality**, one **remains secure and complete**.
When **reality matches the name**, this is **security**.
**Names and reality** generate each other,
and **oppose each other in their essence**.
Following **names to achieve reality**,
and **from reality generating names**—
when **names and reality are not deficient**, **essence resides within**.
Thus it is said:
**When names are correct, reality arises from them**,
**and reality arises from principle**.
**Names are correct and naturally arise from reality**,
**reality is established and naturally arises from principle**.
**Principle arises from the virtue of names and reality**—
if there is **no principle**, then **names and reality naturally generate virtue**.
**Virtue arises from harmony**, and **harmony arises from correctness**.

**The Sovereign’s Names**
The sovereign who **names** must **align with reality**.
The treatises *Zhuàn Wán* and *Guāng Luàn* are **lost**.
Some have **filled in the gaps with Zhuāng Zhou’s *Zhuàn Kuāng*** in sequence.
**Note:** The *Ghost Valley Classic* **exalts stratagems and deceives sagely wisdom**.
While **Zhuāng Zhou’s *Zhuàn Kuāng*** **portrays the sage as a tool for great thieves**,
and **sagely laws as failures of Jiè and Kùi**,
it claims that **those who disrupt all under Heaven are sages**.
It seems to **encourage abandoning sagely wisdom**,
**driving an age into chaotic obscurity**—
this is **far from the book’s intent** and **has no merit**.
Some say *Zhuàn Wán* and *Zhuàn Kuāng* are **the lost sections of the *Inner Classic*** (本经中经).
**End of Ghost Valley’s scroll.**

chunks.original_text: 阴符者，私志於内，物应於外。 若合符契，故曰阴符。 由本以经未，故曰本经。 盛神法五龙。 五龙，五行之龙也。 龙则变化无穷，神则阴阳不测，故盛神之道法五龙也。 盛神中有五气，神为之长，心为之舍，德为之人。 养神之所归诸道。 五气，五藏之气也，谓神、魂、魄、精、志也。 神居四者之中，故为之长。 心能合容，故为之舍。 德能制邪#1，故为之人#2。 然养事之#3，宜归之於道。 道者，天地之始，一其纪也，物之所造，天之所生，包宏无形化气，先天地而成，莫见其形，莫知其名，谓之神灵。 无名，天地之始。 故曰：道者，天地之始也。 道始所生者一，故日一其纪也。 言天道混成，阴阳陶铸，万物以之造化，天地以之生成，包容弘厚，莫见其形。 至於化育之气，乃先天地而成，不可以状貌诂，不可以名字寻，妙万物而为言者也。 是以谓之神灵。 故道者，神明之源，一其化端，是以德养五气。 心能得一，乃有其卫。 神明察道而生，故日道者神明之源也。 化端不一，有时不化，故日一其化端也。 循理有成，谓之德。 五气各能循理，则成功可政，故日德养五气也。 一者，无为而自然者也。 心能无为，其衍自生，故日心能得一，乃有其衍也。 卫者，心气之道，所由舍者，神乃为之使。 心气合自然之道，乃能生衍。 衍之有道由合#4，则神乃为之使。 九窍十二舍者，气之门户，心之总摄也。 生受之天，谓之真人。 真人者，与天为一。 十二合者，谓目见色，耳闻声，鼻受香，。 知味，身觉触，意思事，根境互相停合，故日十二合也。 气侯由之出入，故日气之门户也。 唯心之所操秉，故日心之总摄也。 凡此皆受之於天，不亏其素，故日真人。 真人者，体同於天，故日与天为一也。 而知之者内修炼而知之，谓之圣人。 圣人者，以类知之。 内修炼，谓假学而知之者也。 然圣人虽圣，犹假学而知。 假学即非自然。 故日以类知之也。 故人与生，一出於化物。 言人相与生，在天地之问，其得一耳。 既出之后，随物而化，故有不同也。 知类在家，有所疑惑，通於心术，卫必有不通。 窍，谓孔窍也。 言之事类在於九窍，然窍之所疑叉与衍相通。 若乃心无其衍，卫铃不通也。 其通也，五气得养，务在舍神，此之谓化。 心衍能通，五气自养。 然养五气者，务神#5令来归舍，神既来合，自然随理而化也。 化有五气者，志也； 思也； 神也； 德也。 神其一长也，静和者养气。 养气得其和，四者不衰，四边威势，无不为。 存而舍之，是谓神化。 归於身，谓之真人。 言能化者在於全五气。 神其一长者，言能齐一志思而君长之。 神既一长，故能静和而养气。 气既养，德叉和焉。 四者，志思神德也。 四者能不衰，则四边威势，无有不为。 常存而合之，则神道变化自归於身。 神化归身，可谓真人。 真人者，同天而合道，执一而养产万类，怀天心，施德养，无为以包，志虑思意而行威势者也。 士者，通达之神盛，乃能养志。 一者，无为也。 言真人养产万类，怀抱天心，施德养育，皆以无为为之。 故日执一而产养万类。 至於志意思虑，运行威势，莫非自然循理而动。 故日无为以包也。 然通达此道，其唯善为士乎。 既能盛神，然后乃可养志者也。
chunks.translated_text:
**The Inner Canon of *Yin-Fu* – Seven Chapters (Continued)**

**Yin-Fu** is the private intention within, the response of things without.
Like matching seals and contracts, hence it is called *Yin-Fu*.
From its root to its unfolding, hence it is called the **Root Canon**.
It embodies the **Five Dragons**—the Dragons of the Five Phases.
The Dragon transforms without end, the **qi** is unfathomable in yin and yang—
thus the **Way** of nurturing the **spirit** follows the Five Dragons.

Within nurturing the **spirit** are the Five **qi**:
the **spirit** is their sovereign,
the **heart** their dwelling,
**virtue** their envoy.
The **Way** is where nurturing the **spirit** ultimately returns.

The Five **qi** are the **qi** of the Five Zang:
the **spirit**, the **hun**, the **po**, the **jing**, and the **zhi**.
The **spirit** dwells among the four others, hence it is their sovereign.
The **heart** can harmonize and contain, hence it is their dwelling.
**Virtue** can subdue evil #1, hence it is their envoy #2.
Yet matters of nurturing should return to the **Way**.

The **Way** is the origin of heaven and earth,
the single thread of all things.
It is the source of all things, what heaven generates,
encompassing boundless formless **qi**,
existing before heaven and earth,
its form unseen, its name unknown—
thus it is called **spirit-soul**.
Without name, it is the origin of heaven and earth.
Hence it is said: The **Way** is the origin of heaven and earth.
The **Way**’s initial generation is One,
hence it is called the **single thread**.
Speaking of the **Way**’s mixed creation,
how yin and yang mold and refine—
all things are born and transformed through it,
heaven and earth generated by it,
boundless and vast, its form unseen.
As for the **qi** of nurturing and growth,
it precedes heaven and earth in formation,
cannot be described by form or defined by name,
yet it subtly permeates all things—
thus it is called **spirit-soul**.
Therefore, the **Way** is the source of **spirit-brightness**,
the single principle of transformation.
Thus **virtue** nurtures the Five **qi**.

The **heart** can attain the One,
and thus its **wei** #4 arises.
**Spirit-brightness** discerns the **Way** and is born—
hence it is said: The **Way** is the source of **spirit-brightness**.
If the principle of transformation is not singular,
there are times when transformation does not occur—
hence it is said: the **single principle of transformation**.
Following principle to completion is called **virtue**.
Each of the Five **qi** follows principle,
and thus success can be achieved—
hence it is said: **virtue** nurtures the Five **qi**.

The One is that which acts without action and is naturally so.
The **heart** can act without action,
and its unfolding arises spontaneously—
hence it is said: The **heart** attains the One,
and thus its unfolding arises.

**Wei** is the **Way** of the **heart’s qi**,
the path by which it dwells—
the **spirit** is its envoy.
When the **heart’s qi** aligns with the natural **Way**,
unfolding arises.
The unfolding’s **Way** comes from alignment #4—
thus the **spirit** is its envoy.

The nine orifices and twelve dwellings are the gates and thresholds of **qi**,
the **heart’s** total governance.
Received from heaven at birth, it is called the **True Person**.
The **True Person** is one with heaven.
The twelve alignments are:
the eyes seeing color,
the ears hearing sound,
the nose receiving fragrance,
the tongue tasting flavor,
the body sensing touch,
the mind contemplating affairs—
the roots and fields mutually interpenetrating and aligning,
hence called the twelve alignments.
**Qi** enters and exits through them,
hence they are the gates and thresholds of **qi**.
Only the **heart** governs them,
hence they are the **heart’s** total governance.
All these are received from heaven,
unspoiled in their original nature—
hence it is called the **True Person**.
The **True Person**’s body is identical to heaven,
hence it is said: one with heaven.

Yet those who know this internally refine and cultivate,
and are called **Sages**.
The **Sage** knows by analogy.
Internal refinement is learning through study—
though the **Sage** is wise, still relying on learning.
Learning is not natural—
hence it is said: knowing by analogy.

Thus, when people are born,
they all emerge from the transformation of things.
Speaking of people born together in heaven and earth,
they share the One.
After emerging, they follow things and transform—
thus they differ.

Knowing by analogy at home,
there are doubts and confusions.
The orifices #5 pertain to the nine openings,
yet their doubts also connect with unfolding.
If the **heart** lacks unfolding,
the **wei** is blocked.
When it is unblocked,
the Five **qi** are nurtured—
the task is to dwell the **spirit**,
this is called transformation.

When the **heart’s** unfolding is unblocked,
the Five **qi** are naturally nurtured.
Yet nurturing the Five **qi** requires
the **spirit** to return and dwell.
When the **spirit** returns and aligns,
transformation follows principle naturally.

The Five **qi** of transformation are:
**zhi**, **sī** #6, **spirit**, and **virtue**.
The **spirit** is their sovereign—
calm and harmonious, it nurtures **qi**.
When **qi** is nurtured in harmony,
the four do not decay.
Their fourfold influence and power
achieves all things.
Preserving and dwelling them is called **spirit-transformation**.
Returning to the body, it is called the **True Person**.

Speaking of those who can transform:
it lies in perfecting the Five **qi**.
The **spirit** is their sovereign—
speaking of unifying **zhi** and **sī** to rule them.
The **spirit** being sovereign,
it can be calm and harmonious, nurturing **qi**.
When **qi** is nurtured,
**virtue** is also harmonized.
The four are **zhi**, **sī**, **spirit**, and **virtue**.
If the four do not decay,
their fourfold influence and power
achieves all things.
Constantly preserving and aligning them,
the **Way** of the **spirit** transforms and returns to the body.
When **spirit-transformation** returns to the body,
it is called the **True Person**.

The **True Person** aligns with heaven and harmonizes with the **Way**,
holds the One to nurture all things,
embracing the **heart** of heaven,
applying **virtue** and nurturing—
without action, encompassing all,
using **zhi**, **sī**, thought, and intention
to wield influence and power.

The **scholar** is one whose **spirit** is fully awakened,
thus able to nurture **zhi**.
The One is without action.
Speaking of the **True Person** nurturing all things,
embracing the **heart** of heaven,
applying **virtue** and nurturing—
all done without action.
Hence it is said: holding the One to nurture all things.
As for **zhi**, thought, and intention,
moving influence and power—
all are natural and follow principle.
Hence it is said: without action, encompassing all.

Yet who can fully grasp this **Way**?
Only the virtuous **scholar** can.
Having awakened the **spirit**,
only then can **zhi** be nurtured.

chunks.original_text: 养志法灵龟。 志者，察是非。 龟者，知吉凶。 故日：养志法灵龟。 养志者和通，心气之思不达也。 言以心气不达也。 故须养志，以求通也。 有所欲，志存而思之。 志者，欲之使也。 欲多志，则心散，心散，则志衷； 志衰，则思不达也。 此明纵欲者不能养气志，故所思不达者也。 故心气一，则欲不惶； 欲不惶，则志意不衰； 志意示衰，则思理达矣。 此明寡欲者能养其志，欲思理达矣。 理达则和通，和通则乱气不烦於胸中。 和通，则则莫不调畅，故故乱气自消。 故内以养气，外以知人。 养志则心通矣，知人则分职明矣。 心通则一身泰，职明则天下平。 将欲用之於人，必先知其养气志，知人气盛衰而养其气志，察其所安，以知其所能。 将欲用之於人，谓之养志之卫用人也。 养志则气盛，不养则气衰。 盛衰既形，则其所安所能可知矣。 然则善於养志者，其唯寡欲乎。 志不养，则#6心气不固； 心气不固，则思虑不达； 思虑不达，则志意不实； 志意不实，则应对不猛； 应对不猛，则失志而心气虚； 志失而心气虚，则丧其神矣。 此明丧神始於志不养也。 神丧则髻鬃，髻霏则参会不一。 髡鬃，不精明之貌。 参会，谓志心神三者之交会也。 神不精明，则多违错，故参会不得其一。 养志之始，务在安己。 己安，则志意实坚。 志意实坚，则威势不分。 神明常固守，乃能分之。 安者，谓少欲而心安也。 威势既不分散，神明常来固守。 如此，则威精分，势震动物也。 上分，谓散亡也。 下分，谓我有其威而能动彼。 故日乃能分也。 实意法剩蛇。 意有#7委曲，蛇能屈伸，故实意法腾蛇也。 实意者，气之虑也。 意实则气平，气平则虑审。 故曰实意者气之虑。 心欲安静，虑欲深远。 心安静则神明荣，虑深远则计谋成。 神明荣则志不可乱，计谋成则功不可间。 智不可乱，故能成其计谋。 功不可闲，故能宁其邦国。 意虑定，则心遂安，则其所行不错。 神者，得则凝。 心安，则物无为而顺理，不思而玄览。 故虽心之所不错#8，神自得之。 得之，则无不成矣。 凝者，成也。 识气寄，奸邪得而倚之，诈谋得而惑之，言无由心矣。 寄，谓客寄，言气非真，但客寄耳。 故奸邪得而倚之，诈谋得而惑之。 如此，则言皆胸臆无复由心矣。 故信心术，守真一而不化，待人意虑之交会，听之候之也。 言心卫诚明而不亏，真一守固而不化。 然后待人接物，彼铃输诚尽意，智者虑能，明者献策，上下同心，故能交会也。 用天下之耳听，故物侯可知矣。 计谋者，存亡枢机，虑不会，则听不审矣。 候之不得，计谋失矣，则意无所信，虚而无实。 计得则存，计失则亡。 故日：计谋者存亡之枢机。 虑不合物，则听者不为己听。 不审着#9。 听既不审，候岂得哉。 乖候而谋，非失而何。 计既失矣，意何所恃，惟有虚伪，无复诚实。 故计谋之虑，务在实意。 实意爻从心衍始#10，－故日铃在心卫始也。 无为而求，安静五脏，和通六腑，精神魂魄固守不动，乃能内视反听，定志思之大虚，待神往来。 言欲求安心之道，叉寂澹无为。 如此，则五脏安静，六腑通和，精神魂魄各守所司，澹然不动，则可以内视无形，反听无声。 志虑定#11，太虚至，神明千万往来归於己也。
chunks.translated_text:
Nurturing the **zhi** follows the **Linggui** [灵龟].

**Zhi** discerns right and wrong,
while the **Linggui** foretells auspicious and inauspicious omens.
Hence it is said: nurturing **zhi** follows the **Linggui**.

Nurturing **zhi** means harmonizing and unifying,
so that the **heart-qi**’s thoughts are unrestricted.
It is said: the **heart-qi** is unrestricted.
Thus, one must nurture **zhi** to seek unification.

When there is desire, **zhi** is stored and pondered.
**Zhi** is the guide of desire.
If desires multiply, **zhi** scatters;
when **zhi** scatters, it becomes weak;
when **zhi** weakens, thoughts are not realized.
This shows that those who indulge desires cannot nurture **qi** and **zhi**,
and thus their thoughts are not realized.

When the **heart-qi** is unified, desires do not overwhelm;
when desires do not overwhelm, **zhi** and intention do not weaken;
when **zhi** and intention do not weaken, thoughts reach their essence.
This shows that those with few desires can nurture their **zhi**,
and thus their thoughts reach their essence.

When essence is realized, harmony and unification arise,
and turbulent **qi** does not vex the chest.
Harmony and unification mean all things are attuned and unrestricted,
so turbulent **qi** naturally dissipates.

Thus, internally one nurtures **qi**,
externally one knows others.
Nurturing **zhi** makes the **heart** unified,
knowing others clarifies their roles.
A unified **heart** brings tranquility to the self,
clear roles bring peace to the world.

To employ others, one must first know their nurtured **qi** and **zhi**,
discern their strengths and weaknesses to nurture their **qi** and **zhi**,
and observe their comfort to know their capabilities.
To employ others is called the **Wei** [卫] of nurturing **zhi**.

Nurturing **zhi** strengthens **qi**,
neglecting it weakens **qi**.
When strength and weakness manifest,
their comfort and capabilities become known.

Thus, those skilled in nurturing **zhi** are those with few desires.
If **zhi** is not nurtured, the **heart-qi** is not steadfast;
if the **heart-qi** is not steadfast, thoughts are not realized;
if thoughts are not realized, **zhi** and intention are not firm;
if **zhi** and intention are not firm, responses lack vigor;
if responses lack vigor, **zhi** is lost and **heart-qi** becomes hollow;
if **zhi** is lost and **heart-qi** is hollow, the **spirit** is forfeited.
This shows that losing the **spirit** begins with failing to nurture **zhi**.

When the **spirit** is lost, the hair and beard wither,
and the convergence of **zhi**, **heart**, and **spirit** is disjointed.
Withered hair and beard signify a lack of clarity.
Convergence refers to the interplay of **zhi**, **heart**, and **spirit**.
If the **spirit** lacks clarity, errors multiply,
and thus the three cannot align in unity.

The beginning of nurturing **zhi** lies in self-cultivation.
When self is cultivated, **zhi** and intention become firm.
When **zhi** and intention are firm, **virtue** and power are undivided.
**Spirit** and clarity must be steadfastly guarded to divide them.
Cultivation means few desires and a tranquil **heart**.

When **virtue** and power are not divided,
**spirit** and clarity are ever-present and steadfast.
Thus, **virtue** is refined and power moves all things.
**Virtue** refined means dispersion is lost,
power moving means one’s **virtue** can influence others.
Hence it is said: only then can they be divided.

Firm intention follows the **Tengshe** [腾蛇].
Intention has twists and turns,
while the **Tengshe** bends and stretches,
hence firm intention follows the **Tengshe**.

Firm intention is the **qi**’s contemplation.
When intention is firm, **qi** is balanced;
when **qi** is balanced, contemplation is precise.
Thus it is said: firm intention is the **qi**’s contemplation.

The **heart** desires tranquility,
contemplation desires depth.
A tranquil **heart** honors **spirit** and clarity,
deep contemplation perfects strategies.
When **spirit** and clarity are honored, **zhi** cannot be disordered;
when strategies are perfected, achievements cannot be obstructed.
**Zhi** cannot be disordered, so strategies are fulfilled.
Achievements cannot be obstructed, so the realm is secured.

When intention and contemplation are settled,
the **heart** naturally becomes tranquil,
and all actions are without error.
The **spirit**, when obtained, becomes concentrated.
When the **heart** is tranquil,
things act without effort and follow their nature,
requiring no thought yet perceiving the profound.
Thus, even if the **heart**’s actions are without error,
the **spirit** naturally attains it.
When attained, nothing remains unaccomplished.
Concentration means fulfillment.

If **qi** is lodged externally,
the deceitful gain leverage,
and false schemes cause confusion,
so words no longer emanate from the **heart**.
Lodged means guest lodging—**qi** is not genuine, only borrowed.
Thus, the deceitful gain leverage,
and false schemes cause confusion.
So words become mere chest utterances, no longer from the **heart**.

Thus, one must uphold **heart**-methods,
guard the **True One** without transformation,
and await the convergence of others’ intentions and contemplations,
listening and observing them.

It is said: the **heart** guards sincerity and clarity without loss,
the **True One** is steadfast and unchanging.
Only then, when interfacing with others,
do sincere and earnest individuals fully express their intentions,
the wise offer their strategies,
and the enlightened present their plans,
so that all align in harmony.

Using the **heavenly ear** to listen,
one can discern the omens of things.
Strategies are the pivot of life and death;
if contemplation does not converge,
listening will not be precise.
If observation fails, strategies are lost,
and intention finds nothing to rely on—
only emptiness remains, devoid of substance.
Strategies succeed, life is preserved;
strategies fail, death ensues.
Hence it is said: strategies are the pivot of life and death.

If contemplation does not align with things,
listening serves no purpose.
If listening is not precise,
how can observation succeed?
Contradicting observation while scheming—
what else is this but failure?
If strategies fail, on what can intention depend?
Only hollow pretense remains, no longer sincere.

Thus, the contemplation of strategies
must begin with firm intention.
Firm intention originates from the **heart**’s **Wei** [卫].
Without action yet seeking,
cultivating tranquility for the five **zang** [脏],
harmonizing the six **fu** [腑],
so that **spirit**, **shen**, **hun**, and **po** guard their domains unmoving,
one can then internally gaze and reflectively listen,
settling **zhi** in the boundless void,
awaiting the **spirit**’s comings and goings.

It is said: to seek the way of tranquil **heart**,
one must be serene and without action.
Thus, the five **zang** are tranquil,
the six **fu** are harmonized,
**spirit**, **shen**, **hun**, and **po** each guard their roles,
calm and unmoving,
so one can internally perceive the formless
and reflectively hear the soundless.
When **zhi** and contemplation are settled,
the **Great Void** arrives,
and myriad **spirits** and clarities converge upon oneself.

chunks.original_text: 以观天地开辟，知万物所造化，见阴阳之终始，原人事之政理，不出户而知天下，不窥牖而见天道，不见而命，不行而至。 唯神也，寂然不动，感而遂通天下之故。 能知於不知，见於不见，岂待出户牖阀之，然后知见哉。 固以不见，而命不行而至也。 是谓道知，以通神明，应於无方而神宿矣。 道，无思也，无为也。 然则道知者，岂用知而知哉。 以其无知，故能通神明，应於无方，而神来舍矣#12。 宿，犹舍也。 分威法伏熊。 精虚动物谓之威，发近震远谓之分。 熊之搏击，铃先伏而后动，故分威法伏熊。 分威者，神之覆也。 覆，犹衣被也。 震神明衣被，然后其职#13可分也。 故静固志意，神归其舍，则威覆盛矣。 言致神之道，铃须静意固志，自归其舍，则神之威覆隆盛矣。 舍者，志意之宅也。 威覆盛，则内实坚。 内实坚，则莫当。
chunks.translated_text:
Through observing the unfolding of Heaven and Earth,
one knows the myriad things’ creation and transformation,
sees the completion and origin of **Yin** and **Yang**,
and grasps the principles of human affairs.
Without stepping outside, one knows the world;
without peering through windows, one sees the **Dao** of Heaven.
One issues decrees unseen,
and attains without movement.

Only the **spirit** does this—
serene and unmoving,
yet responsive and thus in harmony with the world’s essence.
To know what is unknown,
to see what is unseen,
does one truly need to step outside or peer through windows and doors?
No, for decrees are issued unseen,
and attainment comes without movement.

This is called **Dao-knowing**,
which harmonizes with **spirit** and **ming**,
responding to the boundless while the **spirit** abides.

The **Dao** is without thought,
without action.
Yet **Dao-knowing**—
does it require knowing to know?
Because it is without knowing,
it can harmonize with **spirit** and **ming**,
respond to the boundless,
and welcome the **spirit**’s arrival.

**Abiding** is akin to **dwelling**.
The **Wei** [威] and **division** of **law** [法] subduing the bear:
**Qi** [精] and **emptiness** [虚] moving creatures is called **Wei**,
and **near** or **far** is called **division**.

When the bear strikes,
the **spirit** first **dwells** and then moves,
thus the **division** of **Wei** and **law** subdues the bear.
**Wei** is the **spirit**’s **covering**—
**covering**, like **garments** and **cloaks**.
When **spirit** and **ming** are **cloaked** in stillness,
then their roles can be **divided**.

Thus, when one cultivates **serene** stillness and **firm** resolve,
the **spirit** returns to its **dwelling**,
and the **Wei**’s **covering** flourishes.
To perfect the **spirit**’s return,
one must cultivate **serene** stillness and **firm** resolve,
so that the **spirit**’s **Wei** and **covering** are grand and resplendent.

**Dwelling** is the **abode** of resolve and intent.
When **Wei** and **covering** are flourishing,
then the **inner substance** [内实] is firm.
If the **inner substance** is firm,
then nothing can oppose it.

chunks.original_text: 莫当，则能以分人之威，而动其势如其天。 外威既盛，则内志坚实。 表裹相副，谁敢当之，物不能当之。 物不能当，则我之威分矣。 威分动，则物皆肃然，畏其人之若天也。 以实取虚，以有取无，若以镒称珠。 言威势既盛，人物肃然，是我实有而彼虚无。 故能以我实取彼虚，以我有取彼无。 其#14取之也，动爻相应，犹称珠以成镒。 二十四铢为镒者也。 故动者必随，唱者必和。 挠其一指，观其余次，动变见形，无能间者， 言威分势震物犹风，故能动叉有随，唱叉有和。 但挠其指，以名呼之，则韦物毕至，然徐徐以次，观其余众，犹性安之，各令得所。 於是风以动之，变以化之，犹泥之在钧，韦器之形自见。 如此，则天下乐，推而不厌，谁能问之也。 审於唱和，以问见问，动变明而威可分。 言审识唱和之理，故能有问爻知。 我既知问，亦既见问，即能问，故能明於动变而威可分者。 将欲动变，必先养志，伏意以视问。 既能养志，伏意视之其问，则变动之衍可成矣。 知其固实者自养也，让己者养人也。 故神存兵亡，乃为之形势。 谓自知志意固实者，此可以自养也。 能行礼让於己者，乃可以养人也。 如此，则神存於内，兵亡於外，乃可为之形势也。 散势法惊乌。 势散而后物服，犹乌击禽获。 故散势法惊乌也。 散势者，神之使也。 势由神发，故势者神之使。 用之，必循问而动。 无问，则势不行，故用之，叉循问而动。 威肃内盛，推问而行之，则势散。 言威敬#15内盛行之，又因问而发，则势自然而散矣。 夫散势者，心虚志溢。 心虚则物无不包，志溢则事无不次，所以能散其势。 意失#16威势，精神不专，其言外而多变。 志意衰微而失势，精神挫钮而不专，则言疏外而谲变。 故观其志意为度数，乃以揣说图事，尽圆方，齐长短。 知其志意隆替，然后可为之度数。 度数既立，乃后揣说之。 图其事也，叉尽圆方之理，齐#17短长之用也。 无则不散势。 散势者，待问而动，动势分矣。 散不得问，则势不行。 故散势者待间而动。 动而得问，势自分矣。 故善思问者，必内精五气，外视虚实，动而不失分散之实。 五气内精，然后可以外察。 虚实之理不失，则问叉可知。 有问铃知，故能不失分散之实也。 动则随其志意，知其计谋。 计谋者，志意之所成。 故随其志意铃知其计谋也。 势者利害之央，权变之威。 势败者不以神肃察也。 神不肃察，所以势败。 转圆法猛兽。 言圣智之不穷圆之无止，猛兽。 转圆者事至，若转圆之无止。 转犹兽威无尽。 转圆法无穷之计。 无穷者之心以原不测之智心术。 圣心若镜，物感斯应，故不测之智、心衍之要可通也。 而神道混沌为一义无穷。 以变论万义#18类，说 既以圣心原不测混沌，妙物杳冥变，说无穷之义也。 智略计谋，各有形容或阳，或吉或凶，必有圣人以不测之智而通，通心卫，故虽神道，而能类其万类之或圆或方，事类不同然后谋兴。 谋兴或阴然后事济。 事无常准，故形容不同，圆者运而无穷，方者止而有分，阴则港谋未兆，阳则功用斯彰#19，吉则福至，凶则祸来。 兀此事皆反覆#20。 故日事类不同者也。 故圣人怀此之用，转圆而求其合。 此谓所谋圆方以下六事，既有不同，或多乖谬。
chunks.translated_text:
「If nothing opposes it,
then one can **divide** the **Wei** of others,
and move their **effort** like the **Heavenly** [天].
When **Wei** is flourishing externally,
then the **inner resolve** is firm and solid.
**Form** and **covering** complement each other—
who dares oppose it?
No thing can oppose it.
If no thing can oppose it,
then the **Wei’s division** is complete.

When **Wei’s division** moves,
then all things stand in solemn reverence,
fearing the person as if they were **Heavenly**.
To grasp the **real** and discard the **empty**,
to take the **possessed** and leave the **void**,
is like weighing **pearls** with a **standard measure**.
When **Wei** and **effort** are grand and resplendent,
and figures stand in solemn reverence,
it means I am **real and possessed** while they are **empty and void**.
Thus, one can take their **empty** with my **real**,
and leave their **void** with my **possessed**.
The **taking** [取] is like the **moving of the stalks** [动爻] in response—
just as weighing **pearls** completes the **standard measure**.
Twenty-four **candareens** [铢] make one **standard measure** [镒].
Thus, the **moved** must follow,
the **sung** must harmonize.
**Twist** one finger,
observe the rest—
when the **moving** and **changing** appear in **form**,
no one can intervene.
When **Wei’s division** and **effort** shake things like the **wind**,
then the **moved** has **followers**,
and the **sung** has **harmonizers**.
But **twist** their fingers,
and call them by name,
then the **Wei** and **things** all arrive,
gradually in order,
like **calming nature** [性安],
each allowed to find its place.

Thus, the **wind** moves them,
the **changing** transforms them—
like clay in the potter’s hands,
the **Wei** and **instruments** of **things** reveal their **forms**.
So, the world rejoices,
and it is **pushed** without **satiation**,
who could **question** it?
To **examine** the **harmonizing** and **responding**,
and **question** reveals the **question**—
when the **moving** and **changing** are clear,
then **Wei** can be **divided**.

When one **examines** the **harmonizing** and **responding**,
and **knows** the **question**,
then one can **question**—
thus, one can **clearly** move and change,
and **Wei** can be **divided**.
Before **moving** and **changing**,
one must first **nurture resolve**,
and **conceal intent** to observe the **question**.
Once able to **nurture resolve**,
and **conceal intent** to see the **question**,
then the **unfolding** of **moving** and **changing** can be achieved.

**Knowing** their **fixed resolve** is self-**nurturing**,
**yielding** to others is **nurturing** others.
Thus, **spirit** remains **internal** while **effort** is **external**,
and **form** and **effort** can be established.
This is like the **method of dispersing effort** to startle the **crow** [乌].
**Effort** is dispersed only after **things** submit—
just as the **crow** strikes prey and gains.

Thus, **dispersing effort** is the **spirit’s deployment**.
**Effort** arises from the **spirit’s** movement,
so **effort** is the **spirit’s** deployment.
When used,
it must follow the **question** to move.
Without the **question**,
**effort** cannot proceed—
thus, when used,
it must also follow the **question** to move.
When **Wei** is solemn and **internal resolve** is resplendent,
and it is **pushed** through the **question**,
then **effort** is dispersed.

**Dispersing effort** is when the **heart** is **empty** and **resolve** overflows.
If the **heart** is **empty**,
then **things** are all **encompassed**;
if **resolve** overflows,
then **matters** proceed without **obstruction**—
thus, one can disperse **effort**.
When **intent** is lost to **Wei** and **effort**,
**spirit** is not **concentrated**,
then their **words** are **external** and **deceptive** in **change**.
If **resolve** and **intent** are **weakened** and **lost**,
then **effort** is **defeated**;
if **spirit** is **damaged** and **unfocused**,
then **words** are **loose** and **deceptive** in **change**.

Thus, **observe** their **resolve** and **intent** as **measurements** [度数],
then **infer** and **explain** their **plans** and **matters**.
**Measurements** are fully **rounded** and **square**,
**leveling** the **short** and **long**.
**Know** their **resolve** and **intent** as **ascending** or **declining**,
then one can establish the **measurements**.
Once the **measurements** are set,
then one can **infer** and **explain** them.
To **map** their **matters**,
one must also **fulfill** the **logic of roundness** and **squareness**,
and **harmonize** the **uses of short** and **long**.
Without **measurements**,
**effort** cannot be dispersed.
**Dispersing effort** is waiting for the **question** to move—
when **effort** moves,
it is **divided**.
If **effort** cannot **observe** the **question**,
then it does not proceed.
Thus, **dispersing effort** is waiting for the **opportunity** to move.
When it moves and **obtains** the **question**,
then **effort** is **divided**.

Therefore, those skilled in **thinking through the question**,
must **refine** the **Five Qi** [五气] **internally**,
and **observe** the **empty** and **real** **externally**—
when they move,
they do not lose the **truth** of **division** and **dispersion**.
The **Five Qi** must be **refined internally**,
then one can **externally** **discern**.
If the **logic of empty** and **real** is not **lost**,
then the **question** can also be **known**.
If there is a **question** and one **knows** it,
then one can **not lose** the **truth** of **division** and **dispersion**.

When one moves,
they follow their **resolve** and **intent**,
and **know** their **strategies** and **plots**.
**Strategies** and **plots** are the **forms** of **resolve** and **intent**,
so one follows their **resolve** and **intent** to **know** their **strategies**.

**Effort** is the **pivot** of **benefit** and **harm**,
the **Wei** of **strategic adaptation**.
The **defeated in effort** are those who do not **solemnly observe** with **spirit**.
If **spirit** does not **solemnly observe**,
then **effort** is **defeated**.
The **method of turning roundness** is like the **fierce beast**.
When **strategies** are **endless** and **unfathomable**,
they are like the **fierce beast**.

**Turning roundness** is when **matters** arrive,
like the **endless roundness** of turning.
**Turning** is like the **unending威** of beasts.
**Turning roundness** is the **method** of **unfathomable strategies**.
The **unfathomable** **heart** and **unmeasurable** **mind**,
with **original** and **unfathomable** **techniques**—
the **sage’s heart** is like a **mirror**,
**things** respond as they are **sensed**,
so the **unfathomable** **mind** and **techniques** of the **heart’s unfolding** can be **communicated**.

Yet, the **Dao/Way** of **spirit** is **mixed and indistinct** as one **principle** without **end**.
To **discuss** the **ten thousand variations** of **meaning**,
once the **sage’s heart** **originally** **unfathomably** **mixes** the **indistinct**,
and **wonders** at **things** in **dimness** and **change**,
then the **unfathomable** **meaning** can be **explained**.
**Wisdom** and **strategies**, **plots** and **calculations**,
each have **manifestations**—
either **yang** or **yin**,
either **auspicious** or **inauspicious**,
either **fortune** or **misfortune**.
There must be a **sage** with **unfathomable wisdom** to **communicate**,
to **unfold** the **heart’s intentions**—
thus, even in the **Dao/Way** of **spirit**,
one can **categorize** its **ten thousand types**,
whether **round** or **square**,
as **matters** differ,
then **plots** arise.
When **plots** arise,
either **yin** or **yang**,
then **matters** are **settled**.
**Matters** have no **fixed standard**,
so their **manifestations** differ—
the **round** **operates** endlessly without **division**,
the **square** **stops** with **boundaries**,
**yin** means **plots** are **hidden** and **not yet revealed**,
**yang** means **actions** are **manifest** and **clear**,
**auspicious** means **blessing** arrives,
**inauspicious** means **calamity** comes.
All these **matters** are **reversible**.
Thus, the **sage** **embraces** this **use**,
**turning roundness** to seek its **harmony**.」

chunks.original_text: 故圣人法#21转圆之思，以求顺通合也。 故兴造化者为始，动作无不包大道，以观神明之域。 圣人体道，以为用其动也，神其随也。 天故兴造教化其功，动作先合大道之理，以稽神明之域。 神道不违，然后发施号令。 天地无极，人事无穷，各以成其类，见其计谋，必知其吉凶、成败之所终也。 天地则独长且久，故无极。 人事则吉凶相生，故无穷。 天地以日月不过、陵谷不迁为成，人事以长保元亨、考终厥命为成。 故见其计谋之得失，则吉凶成败之所终皆可知也。 转圆者，或转而吉，或转而凶。 圣人以道先知存亡，乃知转圆而从方。 言吉凶无常准，故取类转圆。 然圣人坐忘遗鉴，体同乎道，故先知存亡之所在，乃后转圆而从其方，弃凶而从吉。 方，谓存亡之所在也。 圆者所以合语，方者所以错事，转化者所以观计谋，接物者所以观进退之意。 圆者通变不穷，故能合彼此之语。 方者分位斯定，故可错有为之事。 转化者改祸为福，故可观计谋之得失。 接物者顺通人情，故可以观进退之意、是非之事也。 皆见其会，乃为要结，以接其说也。 谓上四者叉见会之变，然后总其纲要而结之，则情伪之说可接引而尽矣。 损兑法灵曹。 老子日：塞其兑。 河上公日：兑，目也。 庄子曰：心有眼。 然则兑者，谓以心眼察理也。 损者，谓喊损他虑专以心察也。 兑能知得失，着能知休答，故损兑法灵着也。 损兑者，几危之央也。 几危之理#22，兆动#23之微，非心眼莫能察见。 故日：损兑者，几危之次也。 事有适然，物有成败，几危之动，不可不察。 适然者，有时而然也。 物之成败有时而然，几危之动自微至着。 若非情适远心，知机玄览，则不能知於未兆，察於未形。 使风涛潜骇，危机密发，然后河海之量埋为穷流，一赞之积迭成山岳。 不谋其始，虽悔何之。 故日：不可不察。 故圣人以无为待有德，言察辞合於事。 夫圣人者勤於求贤，密於任使。 故端拱无为以待有德之士。 士之至也，铃敷奏以言。 故日：言察辞也。 又明试以功，故日：合於事也。 兑者知之也，损者行之也。 用其心眼，故能知之。 喊损他虑，故能行之。 损之说之，物有不可者，圣人不为辞也。 言喊损之说，及其所说之物，理有不一可，圣人不生辞以论。 故智者不以言失人之言，故辞不烦而心不虚，志不乱而意不邪。 智者听舆人之讼，采刍莞之言。 虽复辨周，万物不自说也。 故不以己能言而弃人之言。 既有众言，故辞当而不烦，还任众心，故心诚而不伪。 心诚言当，志意岂复乱哉。 当其难易而后为之谋，自然之道以为实。 失事#24而后谋生，改常而后计起。 故心当其难易之际，然后为之谋。 谋失自然之道，则事废而功亏。 故爻因自然之道，以为用谋之实也。 圆者不行，方者不止，是谓大功。 益之损之，皆为之辞。 夫谋之妙者，铃能转祸为福，因败成功，追#25彼而成我也。 彼用圆者谋，令不行； 彼用方者谋，令不止。 ·然则圆行方止，理之常也。 吾谋既发，彼不得其常，岂非大功哉。 至於谋之棋益，皆为生辞以论其得失也。 用分威散势之权，以见其兑，威其机危乃为之次。 夫所以能分威散势者，心眼之由也。 心眼既明，机危之威可知之矣。

Thus, the **sage** follows the **Dao/Way** of **turning roundness** in thought,
to seek **harmony** and **fluidity** in **alignment**.

Therefore, the **origin** of **nurturing** and **transforming** is **creation**,
and all **movement** and **action** encompass the **Great Dao/Way**,
to **observe** the **domain of the numinous and luminous**.

The **sage** embodies the **Dao/Way**,
using **movement** as **function**,
and **spirit** as its **attendant**.

**Heaven** thus **nurtures** and **transforms** through **teachings** and **cultivation**,
its **movement** and **action** first **aligning** with the **principles** of the **Great Dao/Way**,
to **verify** the **domain of the numinous and luminous**.
When the **Dao/Way of spirit** is **unobstructed**,
then **commands** and **orders** are **issued**.

**Heaven and Earth** are **boundless**,
**human affairs** are **endless**,
each **fulfilling** its **kind**—
when one **observes** their **plans**,
one **knows** the **termination** of **auspiciousness** and **inauspiciousness**,
**success** and **failure**.

**Heaven and Earth** endure **longevity** and **duration**,
thus they are **boundless**.
**Human affairs** generate **auspiciousness** and **inauspiciousness** in **sequence**,
thus they are **endless**.
**Heaven and Earth** **achieve** **completion** through the **sun and moon** never **transgressing**,
and **mountains and valleys** never **shifting**,
while **human affairs** **achieve** **completion** through **long preservation** of **primordial **virtue/power** and **prosperity**,
and **verifying** the **fulfillment** of their **destiny**.

Thus, when one **observes** the **gain or loss** of their **plans**,
the **termination** of **auspiciousness**, **inauspiciousness**, **success**, and **failure** can all be **known**.

**Turning roundness**—
sometimes it **turns** to **auspiciousness**,
sometimes it **turns** to **inauspiciousness**.
The **sage**, through the **Dao/Way**, **foreknows** **life and death**,
and thus **knows** to **turn roundness** and **follow squareness**.

Since **auspiciousness** and **inauspiciousness** have no **fixed standard**,
one **selects** **categories** and **turns roundness**.
Yet the **sage**, through **sitting-forgetting** and **abandoning mirrors**,
**embodies** **harmony** with the **Dao/Way**,
and thus **foreknows** where **life and death** reside,
only then **turning roundness** and **following squareness**,
**discarding inauspiciousness** and **following auspiciousness**.

**Squareness** refers to where **life and death** reside.
**Roundness** is for **harmonizing speech**,
**squareness** is for **arranging affairs**,
**transformation** is for **observing plans**,
and **interacting with others** is for **observing intentions** of **advance and retreat**.

**Roundness** **flows** and **adapts** without **exhaustion**,
thus it can **harmonize** the **speech** of **others**.
**Squareness** **divides** and **fixes** its **positions**,
thus it can **arrange** **affairs** of **action**.
**Transformation** **converts** **calamity** into **blessing**,
thus it can **observe** the **gain or loss** of **plans**.
**Interacting with others** **aligns** with **human nature**,
thus it can **observe** the **intentions** of **advance and retreat**,
and **matters of right and wrong**.

All these **meetings** are then **summarized** as **essential conclusions**,
to **connect** their **discourses**.

This refers to the **four above**—
when their **meetings** and **transformations** are **seen**,
then their **principles** and **essentials** are **summarized** and **concluded**,
and the **discourses** of **emotion and deception** can be **fully connected**.

**Diminishing and Perceiving** follow the **method of the numinous**.

**Laozi** said: **"Block its perceiving."**
**River-Up Master** said: **"Perceiving is the eye."**
**Zhuangzi** said: **"The heart has an eye."**
Thus, **perceiving** refers to **discerning principles** with the **heart’s eye**.

**Diminishing** refers to **suppressing other thoughts** and **focusing** the **heart** to **perceive**.

**Perceiving** can **know gain and loss**,
**action** can **know rest and response**,
thus the **method of diminishing and perceiving** follows the **numinous**.

**Diminishing and perceiving** are the **critical moments** of **peril**.
The **principles of peril**—
the **subtle stirrings** of **omen**—
cannot be **seen** without the **heart’s eye**.

Thus it is said:
**"Diminishing and perceiving"** are the **sequels to peril**.
**Affairs** have their **natural occurrences**,
**things** have their **successes and failures**,
and the **stirrings of peril** range from **subtle to manifest**.
If one does not **adapt emotions** and **distance the heart**,
**knowing omens** and **penetrating mysteries**,
then one cannot **know** before **omens appear**,
or **discern** before **forms take shape**.

If **winds and waves** **seethe** in **hidden terror**,
and **perilous moments** **erupt** in **secrecy**,
then even the **vastness of rivers and seas** becomes a **dried-up stream**,
and a **single sigh’s accumulation** piles into **mountains**.
If one does not **plan at the beginning**,
even **regret** has **nowhere to turn**.

Thus it is said: **"It cannot be neglected."**

Therefore, the **sage** **waits idly** with **non-action** for the **virtuous**,
speaking of **discerning words** in **alignment** with **affairs**.

The **sage** is **diligent** in **seeking the worthy**,
**meticulous** in **assigning tasks**.
Thus, **upright and at ease**, he **waits idly** with **non-action** for the **virtuous**.

When the **worthy arrive**,
they **unfold** and **perform** with **speech**.
Thus it is said: **"Discerning words."**
Again, **testing clearly** with **deeds**,
thus it is said: **"In alignment with affairs."**

**Perceiving** is **knowing**,
**diminishing** is **acting**.

if **things** are **unacceptable**,
the **sage** does not **craft arguments**.

Speaking of **diminishing** and its **discourse**,
and the **things** to which it is **applied**,
if **principles** are **not universally valid**,
the **sage** does not **generate words** to **debate**.

Thus, the **wise** do not **lose others’ words** through **their own speech**,
so **words** are **unburdened** and the **heart** is **unstrained**,
**resolve** is **unconfused** and **intent** is **unerring**.

The **wise**, when **hearing disputes** among **common folk**,
**gather** the **speech** of **cutters of grass and carriers of firewood**.
Though **elaborately reasoned**,
**all things** do not **explain themselves**.

Thus, they do not **abandon others’ words** because of their **own abilities**.
Since there are **many words**,
**speech** is **appropriate** and **unburdened**,
returning to **trust the hearts** of **many**,
so the **heart** is **sincere** and **unfeigned**.
When the **heart** is **sincere** and **speech** is **appropriate**,
how could **resolve** and **intent** be **confused**?

When **difficulties and ease** are **judged**,
then **plans** are **made**.
**Natural principles** are taken as **substance**.
**Affairs** are **lost** and then **life** is **planned**,
**constants** are **changed** and then **calculations** **arise**.

Thus, when the **heart** **judges** the **junctions** of **difficulty and ease**,
then **plans** are **made**.
If **plans** **lose** the **Natural Way**,
then **affairs** **fail** and **achievements** **crumble**.

Thus, **lines** **follow** the **Natural Way**,
taking it as the **substance** for **planning**.

**Roundness** does not **act**,
**squareness** does not **stop**—
this is called **great achievement**.

**Benefiting** and **diminishing** are all **crafted in speech** to **debate** their **gain or loss**.

The **subtlety of planning** lies in its ability
to **convert calamity into blessing**,
to **achieve success** from **failure**,
and to **pursue** the **other** to **complete oneself**.

If the **other** uses **roundness** in **planning**,
my **orders** **do not proceed**.
If the **other** uses **squareness** in **planning**,
my **orders** **do not halt**.

Yet **roundness proceeds** and **squareness stops**—
this is the **constant principle**.
When my **plans** are **launched**,
the **other** **loses its constant**—
how could this not be **great achievement**?

As for **planning’s gains and losses**,
all are **crafted in speech** to **debate** their **merits**.

Using the **authority** to **divide threats** and **scatter influence**,
to **reveal perceiving**—
when **peril’s mechanisms** are **dangerous**, this is its **sequence**.

What enables one to **divide threats** and **scatter influence**

chunks.original_text: 既知之，然后能次之。 故善损兑者，譬若决水於千仞之堤，转圆石於万仞之溪。 而能行此者，形势不得不然也#26。 言善损虑以专心眼者，见事审得理明，意次而不疑，志雄而不滞，其犹次水转石，谁能当御哉。 持枢。 枢者，居中以运外，处近而制远，主於转动者也。 故天之北辰谓天枢，门之运转者谓之户枢。 然则持枢者，动运之柄以制物也。 持枢，谓春生夏长，秋收冬藏，天之正也。 言春夏秋冬四时运行，不为而自然也。 不为而自然，所以为正也。 不可干而逆之，逆之者虽成必败。 言理所叉有，物之自然者静而顺之，则四时行焉，万物生焉。 若乃干其时令，逆其气候，成者犹败，况未成者。 元亮日：含气之类，顺之铃悦，逆之叉怒，况天为万物之尊而逆之。 故人君亦有天枢生养成藏， 言人君法天以运动，故日亦有天枢。 然其生养成藏，天道之行也，人事之正，亦复不别耳。 亦复不别干而逆之。 逆之虽盛必衰，此天道人君之大纲也。 言干天之行，逆人之正，所谓倒置之。 故#27日：道非义#28而何。 此持枢之卫恨太简促，畅理不尽，或篇简脱斓，本不能全也。 中经。 谓由中以经，外发於心，本以弥缝於物者也。 故日：中经。 中经，谓振穷趁急，施之能言，厚德之人救物，执穷者不忘恩也。 振，起也； 趁，向也。 物有穷急，当振起而向护之，乃其施之，叉在能言之士、厚德之人。 若能救彼拘执，则穷者怀终不忘恩也。 能言者，俦善博惠。 俦，类也。 谓能言之士解纷救难，虽不失善人之类而能博行恩惠也。 施德者，依道。 言施德之人动能修理，所为不失道也。 而救拘执者，养使小人。 言小人在拘执而能救养之，则小人可得而使也。 盖士当世异时，或当因免阗坑，或当伐害能言，或当破德为雄，或当抑拘成罪，或当戚戚自善，或当败败自立。 阗坑，谓将有兵难，转使沟壑。 士或有所因，而能免斯祸者。 伐害能言，谓小人之道，谗人罔极，故能言之士多被戮害。 破德为雄，谓毁文德，崇兵战。 抑拘成罪，谓人不章，横被缧统。 戚善，谓天下荡荡，无复纲纪，而贤者守死善道，真心不瑜，所谓岁寒然后知松桥后雕也。 败败自立，谓天未悔祸#29，危败相仍，君子穷而铃通，终能自立，若管仲者也。 故道贵制人，不贵制於人也。 制人者握权，制於人者失命。 贵有衍而制人，不贵无卫而为人所制者也。 是以见形为容，象体为貌，闻声和音，解仇阙邮，缀去却语，摄心守义。 此总其目，下别序之。 本经记事者，纪道数其变，要在持枢中经。 此总言本经持枢中经之义，言本经纪事但纪道数而已。 至於权变之要，乃在持枢中经也。 见形为容、象体为貌者，谓爻为之生也。 见彼形象其体，即知其容貌者，谓用爻卦占而知之也。 可以影响形容象貌而得之也。 谓彼人之无守，故可以影响形容象貌占而得之。 有守之人，目不视非，耳不听邪，言必《诗》、《书》，行不僻淫，以道为形，以听为容，貌庄色温，不可象貌而得也。 如是隐情塞郡而去之。 有守之人，动皆正直，举无淫僻，厥后昌盛#30，晖光日新。 虽有辫士之舌，无从而得发。 故隐情塞邮闭藏而去之。
chunks.translated_text:
Once known, then one can arrange it accordingly.
Thus, those skilled in diminishing *yú* [perceiving] are like
unleashing water from a thousand-*rèn* [fathom] dam,
rolling round boulders down a ten-thousand-*rèn* gorge.
Yet those who can execute this—
their form and circumstances leave no alternative.

Speaking of those skilled in curbing deliberation to focus the *heart’s eye*,
they perceive events clearly, grasp principles distinctly,
their intent follows order without doubt,
their resolve is mighty yet unobstructed—
like controlling water or rolling stones,
who could withstand their command?

**Holding the Pivot.**
The Pivot—
residing centrally to govern the outer,
dwelling near to control the distant,
mastering movement—
is the essence of turning.

Thus, the celestial North Star is called the Celestial Pivot,
the turning hinge of a door is called the Door Pivot.
Therefore, to *hold the Pivot*
is to wield the handle of motion to govern things.

*Holding the Pivot* means:
spring generates, summer grows, autumn harvests, winter stores—
the natural order of Heaven.
The four seasons move naturally without contrivance—
this is what makes it the *constant*.

Do not forcibly disrupt or reverse it;
those who do, though they succeed, must fail.
What Heaven’s principles naturally embrace,
if left undisturbed and in harmony,
the four seasons proceed, all things flourish.
Yet if one disrupts the seasons, defies the *qi* and climate,
even success turns to ruin—what of those who fail?

Yuan Liang said:
All beings with *qi* rejoice when obeyed,
rage when defied—
how much more so Heaven, sovereign over all things,
when it is defied?

Thus, the sovereign too has the Celestial Pivot of generation, nurturing, completion, and storage.
The sovereign follows Heaven’s movement,
so too does the sovereign have the Celestial Pivot.
Yet its generation, nurturing, completion, and storage
are the unfolding of Heaven’s *dao*—
the proper order of human affairs,
no different in essence.

Yet still, do not forcibly disrupt or reverse it.
To do so, though one flourishes, must decline—
this is the grand framework of Heaven’s *dao* and the sovereign’s rule.
To disrupt Heaven’s course, to reverse human propriety—
this is inversion.

Thus it is said:
If not *yi* [rightness], what is the *Dao*?

This section on *holding the Pivot* is too brief,
its principles not fully expounded—
perhaps the text is incomplete or lost.

**Central Thread.**
The Central Thread—
originating from within, extending outward through the heart,
rooted in mending what is external.

Thus it is said: *Central Thread.*
The *Central Thread* means:
reviving the desperate, aiding the urgent,
applying aid to those who can speak,
the virtuous saving things while the constrained do not forget gratitude.
*Reviving*—to uplift;
*Trending*—to turn toward.
When things are desperate and urgent,
one must uplift and turn to protect them—
this is their aid.
And it lies with those who can speak,
those of profound virtue.

If they can rescue the constrained,
the desperate will forever harbor gratitude.
Those who can speak—
their kind are benevolent and widely generous.
*Kind*—of the same class.
Those who can speak resolve disputes, save crises,
yet do not lose their virtuous nature,
while broadly extending kindness.

Those who practice virtue act in accordance with the *Dao*.
To say those who practice virtue act rightly—
their deeds never stray from the *Dao*.

Yet to rescue the constrained is to nurture the petty.
The petty, when constrained, can be made governable.
In times of shifting circumstances,
the scholar may:
sometimes avert disaster through strategic retreat,
sometimes strike down those who harm the virtuous,
sometimes break virtue to assert dominance,
sometimes suppress the constrained to form crime,
sometimes mournfully uphold goodness,
sometimes rise from ruin to establish oneself.

*Strategic retreat*—when war looms, turning to avoid destruction.
The scholar may have cause to avert such calamity.
*Strike down those who harm the virtuous*—
the petty’s way is slander without end,
so those who can speak often suffer slaughter.
*Break virtue to assert dominance*—
destroying cultural refinement, glorifying war.
*Suppress the constrained to form crime*—
when one’s merit is unrecognized, they are falsely ensnared.
*Mournfully uphold goodness*—
when the world is chaotic, without order,
the virtuous cling to death-defying integrity,
their true hearts untainted—
as the pine and cypress endure only in winter’s severity.

*Rise from ruin to establish oneself*—
when Heaven does not repent disaster,
danger and ruin follow in succession,
the noble, though impoverished, remain uncorrupted,
and ultimately establish themselves—
as did Guan Zhong.

Thus, the *Dao* values governing others,
not being governed by others.
To govern others is to grasp authority;
to be governed by others is to lose one’s life.
It is noble to have surplus power to govern others,
not noble to lack defense and be governed by others.

Hence:
observe form to discern appearance,
mirror the body to perceive countenance,
listen to tone to harmonize sound,
unravel enmity through gaps,
weave and sever words,
consolidate the heart to uphold *yi* [rightness].

This summarizes the overview;
the details follow below.

The *Classic* records events,
counting the *Dao*’s transformations—
its essence lies in *holding the Pivot* and the *Central Thread*.

This summarizes the *Classic*’s meaning of *holding the Pivot* and the *Central Thread*,
saying the *Classic*’s records merely enumerate the *Dao*’s shifts.
As for the key to adaptability,
it lies in *holding the Pivot* and the *Central Thread*.

*Observe form to discern appearance, mirror the body to perceive countenance*—
this is the *yáo* [stems] generating them.
Seeing another’s form and mirroring their body,
one knows their appearance—
this is divination through *yáo* and *guà* [hexagrams].
One can influence appearance and countenance to discern them.
This means those without principle
can be influenced by appearance and countenance to be divined.

Yet those with principle—
their eyes do not gaze at what is improper,
their ears do not listen to deceit,
their speech is grounded in the *Odes* and *Documents*,
their conduct is not perverse or licentious,
they embody the *Dao* in form,
listen with propriety in appearance,
their demeanor is dignified, their color serene—
they cannot be discerned through appearance or countenance.
Thus, their emotions are concealed,
their intentions sealed,
and they depart unseen.

Those with principle act with unwavering rectitude,
their actions are never perverse or licentious,
and later flourish,
their radiance ever renewed.
Even with the tongues of deceitful scholars,
there is no way to expose them.
Thus, their emotions remain hidden,
their intentions sealed and stored away.

chunks.original_text: 闻声和音，谓声气不同，则恩受不接。 故商角不二，合征羽不相配。 商金角木，征火羽水，递相克食，性气不同，故不相配合也。 能为四声主者，其唯宫乎。 官则土也，土主四季。 四者由之以生，故为四声主也。 故音不和，则不悲不是#31。 以声散伤丑害者，言必逆於耳也。 散伤丑害，不和之音。 音气不和，铃与彼乖，故言其铃逆於耳。 虽有美行盛誉，不可比目合翼相须也。 此乃气不合，音不调者也。 言若音气乖彼，虽行誉美盛，非彼所好，则不可如比目之鱼、合翼之乌两相须也。 其有能令两相求应，不与同气者乎。 解#32仇阙邮，谓解羸微之仇。 刽郡者，阙强也。 辨说之道，其犹张弓，高者抑之，下者举之。 故赢微为仇，从而解之。 强者为邮，从而阙之也。 强邮既阙，称胜者高其功，盛其势。 阙而盛者，从而高其功，盛其势也。 弱者哀其负，伤其卑，行其名，耻其宗。 国而弱者，从而哀其负劣，伤其卑小，污下其名，耻辱其宗也。 故胜者图其功势，苟进而不知退， 知进而不知退，叉有亢龙之悔。 弱者闻哀其负，见其伤，则强大力倍，死而是也。 弱者闻我哀伤，则勉强其力，倍意致死，为我为是也。 郡无极大，御无强大，则皆可胁而并。 言虽为邮，非能强大，其於杆御，亦非强大。 如是者，则以兵威胁，令从己而并其国也。 缀去者，谓缀已之击言，使有余思也。 系，属也。 谓已令去而欲缀其所属之言，令后思而同也。 故接贞信者称其行，厉其志，言可为可复，会之期喜， 欲令去后有思，故接贞信之人，称其行之盛美，厉其志，令不怠。 谓此美行，铃可常为，叉可报复。 会通其人，又令至於喜悦者也。 以他人之庶引验以结往，明疑疑而去之。 言既称行厉志，令其喜悦，然后以他人庶几於此者引之以为成验，以结已往之心，又明已疑疑至诚。 如是而去之，铃思已#33而不忘也#34。 却语者，察伺短也。 言却语之道，铃察伺彼短也。 故言#35多必有数短之处，识其短验之。 言多不能无短，既察知其短，铃记识之，以取验之相也#36。 动以忌讳，示以时禁。 既有其短，则以忌讳动之，时禁示之，其人因以怀惧。 然后结以安其心，收语盖藏而却之。 其人既以怀惧，叉有求服之情，然后结以诚信，以安其惧心。 其向语盖利而却之，则其人之恩威固以深矣。 无见己之所不能於多方之人。 既藏向语，又戒之日：勿於多方人前，见其所不能也。 摄心者，谓逢好学仗术者，则为之称远。 欲将摄取彼心，见其好学使卫，则为作声誉，令#37远近知之也。 方验之道#38，惊以奇怪，人系其心於己。 既为作声誉，方且以道验其仗衍，又以奇怪从而惊动之。 如此，则彼人心系於己也。 效之於人#39，验去乱其前，吾归诚於己。 人既系心於己，又效之於时人，验之於往贤，然后更理其前所为，谓之日：吾所以然者，归诚於彼人之己。 如此，则贤人之心可得，而摄乱者理也。 遭淫色酒者为之术，音乐动之，以为必死，生日少之忧。 言将欲摄#40愚人之心，见淫酒色者为之衍，音乐之可说。 又以过於酒色，秘之死地，生日喊少。 以此可忧之事，以感动之也。 喜以自所不见之事，终可以观漫澜之命，使有后会。

Hearing voices and harmonizing sounds—
when *qi* and tone differ,
favor and response do not align.

Thus, *shang* and *jiao* are not paired,
*zheng* and *yu* do not combine.
*Shang* is metal, *jiao* wood,
*zheng* fire, *yu* water—
each in turn restrains and consumes the other,
their natures and *qi* discordant,
so they do not harmonize.

Only *gong* can master the four tones.
*Gong* is earth, earth governs the four seasons.
From these four seasons all things arise,
thus *gong* is master of the four tones.

When sounds are not harmonized,
they bring neither sorrow nor blame.
Those who scatter injury and ugliness with sound
must speak what offends the ear.
Scattered injury and ugliness—
these are the discordant tones.
When *qi* and sound are not in harmony,
they clash with what is proper,
so it is said their clash offends the ear.

Even with virtuous conduct and great renown,
they cannot pair like *bìmù* fish or *héyì* birds,
mutually relying on one another.
This is because their *qi* does not align,
their tones are not attuned.

Who can make two seek response
without sharing the same *qi*?

To resolve enmity and fill deficiencies—
this means resolving the weak and feeble’s grudges.
The executioner is the deficient one,
the strong are the deficient.
The art of persuasion is like drawing a bow:
the high are lowered, the low are raised.
Thus, the weak and feeble become enemies,
and are resolved.
The strong are the deficient,
and are filled.

Once the deficient are filled,
the victorious exalt their deeds,
magnify their power.
The filled and magnified—
their deeds are exalted,
their power magnified.

The weak lament their failures,
grieve their lowliness,
spread their names in shame,
bring dishonor to their lineage.
The weak, when lamented,
are moved to double their strength,
to die in service.

If there is no extreme might,
no overwhelming force,
then all may be coerced and united.
Though they are the deficient,
they lack neither strength nor mastery.
Thus, with military might,
they are compelled to submit and unite.

To linger after departure—
this means prolonging one’s striking words,
leaving room for further thought.
*Ji*—to bind—
to bind the words of those who have gone,
so that later reflection aligns with them.

Thus, those who are sincere and trustworthy
are praised for their conduct,
their resolve strengthened.
Their deeds are said to be both enduring and repayable,
their meeting marked by joy.
To order them to think again after departure,
praise their noble conduct,
strengthen their resolve,
so they do not grow slack.
These noble deeds—
their virtue is constant,
their repayments assured.
Their meeting is harmonious,
and they are filled with joy.

Using others’ minor virtues as proof
to bind the past,
clarifying doubts with sincerity before departing.
Having praised their conduct and strengthened their resolve,
then using others who nearly match them as proof,
to bind the past intentions,
and to clarify one’s own sincere doubts.
Thus, when departing,
they will think of you and not forget.

To retreat with words—
this means observing their flaws.
The art of retreat with words
is to observe their shortcomings.
Thus, speech is bound to have flaws,
and their flaws are recorded for verification.
Speech cannot be without flaws,
once their flaws are known,
they are remembered for verification.

Act with taboos,
demonstrate timely prohibitions.
Having observed their flaws,
use taboos to move them,
demonstrate prohibitions in season,
so they harbor fear.
Then bind them with sincerity to calm their hearts,
conceal their words and withdraw.

When their words were once advantageous but are now withdrawn,
their gratitude and awe will be deep.

Do not reveal your limitations before many.
Having concealed your words,
warn them: *"Do not, before many, reveal what you cannot do."*

To gather the heart—
when encountering those who love learning and rely on skill,
praise their distant reputation.
To gather their hearts,
seeing they love learning and rely on skill,
create a reputation for them,
so that near and far know of it.

The method of verification—
startle them with the strange,
so their hearts attach to you.
Having created their reputation,
then verify their reliance,
and with the strange startle them.
Thus, their hearts will attach to you.

To emulate them—
verify past chaos,
return sincerity to them.
Their hearts already attached,
then emulate them before others,
verify them with past sages,
then rectify their past actions,
saying: *"This is why I act thus—
my sincerity is for them."*

To encounter those ensnared by lust and wine—
use music to move them,
saying they will surely die,
that their days are few.
To gather the hearts of the foolish,
seeing those ensnared by lust and wine,
music can persuade.
And with excess in wine and lust,
lead them to the brink of death,
saying their days are few.
With these worrisome matters,
move them.

Delight them with what they have not seen,
so they may finally observe the vast and boundless fate,
and meet again later.

they cannot be discerned through appearance or countenance.
Thus, their emotions are concealed,
their intentions sealed,
and they depart unseen.

Those with principle act with unwavering rectitude,
their actions are never perverse or licentious,
and later flourish,
their radiance ever renewed.
Even with the tongues of deceitful scholars,
there is no way to expose them.
Thus, their emotions remain hidden,
their intentions sealed and stored away.

chunks.translated_text:
Again, delight them with music—
things they have never seen,
so that, in the end, they may observe what is boundless.
Yet, how can they be led astray by wine and lust?

If they can take pleasure in this,
then their life and fate will flow boundlessly and without end,
and they will meet again in eternal years.

The foolish cannot be swayed by the Dao/Way—
thus, music is used to capture their hearts.

Those who uphold **righteousness** (*yì*)—
**righteousness** means what is fitting.
To explore the heart is to probe within,
to harmonize with others.
Exploring the heart means attaining their essence,
guiding from without to within,
for all things have their natural inclinations and follow accordingly.
Once their hearts are known,
then the essence is deeply attained.
With their hearts deeply understood,
one can guide from without to within.
If the inner is controlled by me,
then what matter cannot be accomplished?
Thus, all things have their proper place,
none failing to follow as intended.

Hence, the petty (*xiǎorén*) compare themselves to the virtuous,
using **deviant arts** (*zuǒdào*) to manipulate them,
even to the point of ruining families and seizing states.
The petty, through probing the heart,
compare themselves to the virtuous,
using **deviant arts** to wield power.
All matters not of **public virtue** (*gōngzhéng*) are called petty.
They invert the Dao/Way and disrupt the norms,
harm the virtuous and attack the good.
Their methods are **deviant** (*zuǒ*), their opposition is **public** (*gōng*).
A hundred blessings become chaos,
ten thousand affairs fall into disarray,
families are shattered, states are lost—
is this not fitting?

Only the virtuous and wise can guard their families with **righteousness** (*yì*)
and guard their states with the Dao/Way.
The sage values the subtle and wondrous Dao/Way,
for it can transform peril into safety,
rescue the lost and bring them to preservation.

The Dao/Way—
this refers to the **central path** (*zhōngjīng*) of the Dao/Way.

*(Ghost Valley Master Scroll, Part II concludes.)*

use music to move them,

To gather the hearts of the foolish,
seeing those ensnared by lust and wine,
